On March 22, Bush declared at a news conference: ``I do not like broccoli and I haven't liked it since I was a little kid and my mother made me eat it. And I'm president of the United States and I'm not going to eat any more broccoli.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Medicine Sent to Armenian Quake Victims Said Useless or Dangerous
With PM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some of the drugs sent to Soviet Armenia for victims of the 1988 earthquake were useless or even dangerous, experts say, and they warn of similar problems with emergency supplies now being sent to Iran. The Armenian shipments included pharmaceuticals that came from stocks of expired drugs, and others of a type no longer sold, according to an article in the respected British medical journal, The Lancet. ``We know exactly the same problems are happening now in Iran,'' said Dr. Philippe Autier, an epidemiologist and researcher in public health for the Brussels-based European Association for Health and Development. Autier wrote the report in the June 9 issue of the Lancet with members of Doctors Without Borders, a French humanitarian group, and the Soviet Armenian Ministry of Health. ``The quantities of expired and useless drugs are especially worrying,'' it said. ``The supply of massive amounts of drugs for the purpose of humanitarian aid still represents a good way of disposing of stocks of expired drugs or of those that are normally no longer marketable.'' In a telephone interview Monday, Autier said people feel ``forced to do something immediately'' when confronted with the suffering from natural disasters. Adam Kellett-Long, a spokesman for the British Red Cross, said his organization was sending its first shipment of drugs to Iran today after receiving a list of needed medication and supplies from Iran. His organization only has sent drugs that are requested. Iranian officials said that more than 130 planes had arrived since Sunday carrying supplies and medicines. Unlike Armenia, Iran ``is much more controlled. The Iranian Red Crescent has been very strict on what it will accept. But of course there are a lot of other groups and countries involved which may not be taking the same care.'' After the Armenian earthquake on Dec. 7, 1988, which killed 25,000 people, international relief agencies and governments rushed in 5,000 tons of drugs, consumable medical supplies and other equipment, the report said. Medical workers needed injectable painkillers like morphine, antibiotics, anesthetics, intravenous fluids, syringes and needles _ the same supplies now needed in Iran. Drugs worth about $55 million were sent to Armenia, but only about 30 percent of them were available when they were most needed because they arrived unsorted and were impossible to identify, the Lancet report said. None of the boxes was labeled in Armenian and few in Russian, it said. In 24 warehouses in the Armenian capital of Yerevan, 238 kinds of antibiotics were labeled in 21 languages, it said. ``In Spitak, the most badly affected area, pharmacists wasted about two-thirds of their time merely looking for and identifying useful drugs among the relief parcels,'' the report said. Autier said experts know that only 30 to 40 types of medicines are commonly needed in most earthquake relief efforts. About 11 percent of the drugs were useless, including nasal spray and drugs for treating tropical diseases such as malaria and bilharzia, it said. Eight percent of the drugs had expired by the time they arrived, the report said. Some of these drugs, such as tetracycline, were potentially dangerous. For a year following the catastrophe, the Armenian ministry worked with Doctors Without Borders making an inventory of the drugs. By the end of their work, about 21 percent of the drugs were set to expire or already had expired. An incinerator had to be sent to the region because old pharmaceuticals should be burned in temperatures above 2,200 degrees Farenheit and burying them or burning them in the open would be environmentally hazardous, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Buckey Takes Stand Again, Denies Molesting Children
DOC.TEXT: The man acquitted of most counts in the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history testified again in his retrial, denying he molested any children at his family's McMartin Pre-School. Raymond Buckey adamantly denied molestation allegations during a sharp-toned cross-examination Monday by Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero. ``Mr. Buckey, there's no question I'm going to ask you (to which) you're going to say you molested children, is there?'' asked Ms. Ferrero. ``I'm not going to because I didn't,'' said Buckey. Ms. Ferrero then peppered Buckey, 32, with increasingly hostile questions about why he wanted to be a preschool teacher and why he liked being around children. Buckey acknowledged that he once took pictures of children at a day care center in San Diego where he was a volunteer. He said he wanted them for his scrapbook. Why did he want to teach small children? ``It seemed like a happy atmosphere. Children are nice to be around,'' he said. ``It was pretty easy. I saw it as baby-sitting.'' Buckey's first trial ended in January with acquittal on 40 molestation charges and mistrial on 13 counts. He is being retried on eight of those 13 charges. In the first trial, Buckey's 62-year-old mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted of 12 charges. The key witnesses against Buckey in his second trial are three young girls who say they were molested by him. His lawyer, Danny Davis, has suggested that the children were influenced by their parents and therapists to say they were molested. Davis said the defense will rest its case this week and predicted all testimony could end as early as the middle of next week.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Communist Guerrillas Killed; 500 Homes Destroyed in Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers killed 10 Communist rebels in a battle on the central island of Negros and a guerrilla land mine blew up a police jeep north of the capital, killing three policemen, the military said today. In separate fighting in a southern city, followers of rival Moslem clans battled for a second day today. At least eight people have been killed and 500 homes destroyed in the fighting, the military said. On Negros Island, an army patrol encountered about 60 New People's Army rebels Monday in San Carlos town, 330 miles south of Manila, according to police chief Brig. Gen. Raymundo Jarque. He said the soldiers killed 10 rebels in a three-hour gunbattle before the guerrillas withdrew. One soldier died and two others were wounded, Jarque said. In Tabuk, 200 miles north of Manila, an undetermined number of rebels lying in ambush on a highway fired at policemen after a landmine blew up their jeep Monday, a military report said. Three other policemen were wounded in the attack. Jarque said the San Carlos encounter was the fourth clash with the NPA on Negros since the rebels launched an offensive last Friday with an attack on a police station on Escalante town north of San Carlos. Five civilians were killed in that attack. The fighting between Moslem clans erupted Monday in Jolo, capital of Sulu province about 600 miles south of Manila. The battles, between followers of Sulu provincial Vice Gov. Kimar Tulawie and Jolo Mayor Suod Tan, began after the Tulawie clan allegedly attacked the mayor's house to arrest a renegade policeman. The policeman, one of Tan's bodyguards, was said to have been involved in the killing of Tulawie's brother, two cousins and a fourth person on June 3. A military official said the warring factions agreed this afternoon to halt the fighting and pull out of the city. At least 12 people outside the factions, including four soldiers, were wounded in fighting today. Casualties on the two sides could not be immediately determined. The military estimated each side had at least 200 men. Two mortar rounds landing in a village about a mile from Jolo killed two children, a military report said. On Monday, using mortars and other heavy weapons, members of the two clans engaged in sporadic firefights around the downtown area. The military said six people were killed. About 500 houses were razed in the villages of Asturias and Alat, leaving 5,000 people homeless, the state-run Philippine Information Agency reported. Local officials said 15,000 people have been evacuated and the number may double as tensions continue to rise. Schools and offices remained closed. In Zamboanga, the regional development council passed a resolution urging Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos to call leaders of the two groups to a peace talk to avoid further bloodshed. Philppine troops and helicopter gunships were put on standby alert for immediate deployment to Jolo. Col. Samuel Tomas of the Philippine Constabulatory said there was no longstanding feud between the two clans. He said there had been an incorrect report that suspects in the June 3 killings had entered Jolo last Saturday and were in the mayor's custody. Tulawie insisted the report was true and launched the attack, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Tobacco Smoke Blamed For 3,800 Cancer Deaths Among Non-Smokers
DOC.TEXT: A new Environmental Protection Agency study says second-hand tobacco smoke is a human carcinogen, causing about 3,800 lung cancer deaths annually among non-smokers. The study, which is in draft form and has not been evaluated by EPA's independent science advisers, was quickly criticized by a tobacco industry trade association. A statement from the the Tobacco Institute said an analysis by the EPA's Science Advisory Board ``is likely to significantly undermine the very basis of this draft.'' The study, prepared by the EPA's Office of Research and Development, said an evaluation of studies about environmental tobacco smoke, which originates from burning cigarettes, shows that it causes cancer among non-smokers. This conclusion, the study said, ``is based on a total weight of evidence.'' The evidence includes what the report calls ``detectable association at environmental exposure levels'' between cancer and non-smoking family members who live with a smoker. ``Within the population of women who are lifelong non-smokers,'' the study said, ``the excess lung cancer risk of those married to a smoker is large enough to be observed.'' Twenty-four studies from eight countries provide no other broadly applicable explanation for the association between environmental tobacco smoke and lung cancer among non-smokers, the report said. Although only 30 percent of the adult population smokes, the study said, there are detectable levels of cotinine, a metabolic product of nicotine, detected in the blood, saliva and urine of 50 percent to 75 percent of non-smokers tested. The estimate of 3,800 lung cancer deaths annually among non-smokers, the study said, includes approximately 1,750 females who have never smoked, 800 males who have never smoked and 1,250 former smokers of both sexes. About 130,000 people will die of lung cancer every year, about 85 percent of which is caused by smoking directly. Smoking causes an estimated 390,000 premature deaths a year when emphysema and cardiovascular deaths are added to the lung cancer total, according to government estimates. The EPA report said studies also have linked cigarette smoking in the home with increased respiratory disorders among children, particularly infants. ``The cumulative evidence indicates strongly that parental, especially the mother's, smoking is associated with increased incidence of respiratory illnesses in the first one to two years of life,'' the study said. ``Recent studies also solidify the evidence of a link between parental smoking and increased middle ear disease in young children.'' The Tobacco Institute said the EPA draft report has ``technical problems and inadequacies'' and suffers from ``the lack of scientific support.'' ``The statistical manipulations represented by the EPA draft risk assessment constitute, at the very best, speculation without an adequate scientific foundation,'' the Tobacco Institute statement said.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Release Discussion Paper Outlining Political Unification
DOC.TEXT: West Germany today unveiled proposals for full unification by mid-December after joint elections. The plan was made public just five days before the two countries are to merge their economies and social institutions, a move that effectively marks the end of four decades of socialism in East Germany. According to a discussion paper released by the Interior Ministry, unification would become effective the day after united German elections, proposed for either Dec. 9 or Dec. 16. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said he expected the East German Cabinet to begin discussing the proposed elements of the treaty on political unification on Wednesday in East Berlin. The treaty for the accession of East Germany _ its joining with the West _ should be taken up by both German parliaments by early September, he added. The parliaments of both countries last week ratified an initial treaty outlining the monetary, economic and social union that is to take effect Sunday, when the West German mark replaces the nearly worthless East German mark. The victors and vanquished from World War II are still working on the international ramifications of German unity, namely the military posture of a united Germany and what to do about the 380,000 Soviet troops on East German soil. West Germany is a member of the Western NATO alliance, and the Allies have insisted a united Germany remain in NATO. The Soviets have so far rejected that idea. East Germany has been the most strategically important member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, as the first line of defense against the West. Bonn wants to limit the political treaty to only those laws and regulations that differ between East and West Germany and are necessary for political unification. According to the discussion paper, issues which could be left unresolved before unification include the differing abortion laws, a highly controversial issue. In West Germany, a woman must prove medical necessity or financial hardship to have an abortion. In East Germany, abortions are free on demand in the first trimester.

DOC.HEAD: Arrested Student Leader Appears On TV, Denies Charges
DOC.TEXT: A leader of a 53-day anti-Communist student demonstration has declared he was arrested and has been held in a prison hospital on ``groundless charges.'' The interview with Marian Munteanu was broadcast by state TV Monday night in the Jilavea prison hospital outside Bucharest. He was dressed in pajamas, and bandages covered the injuries he suffered when pro-government coal miners beat him and broke up the protest June 14. Munteanu, who also played a role in the popular uprising that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December, was then arrested on charges of instigating the violence. Speaking from his bed, slowly gesturing with bandaged hands, Munteanu said he could not understand how the workers could turn on the students or why he was arrested. He had wounds and bruises to his head, chest and back, and a leg and arm was broken. ``For four years I was a worker myself and I also worked underground,'' said Munteanu, president of the Students' League. ``So I thought I knew the working class. I cannot explain the savage way in which the students were beaten. ``I still have confidence, and I pray to God that justice is done.'' The students had demanded that President Ion Iliescu and other leading ex-Communists be banned from politics for 10 years. Iliescu had asked the miners to restore order in Bucharest and later thanked them ``with all my heart'' for doing so. Iliescu distanced himself from the indiscriminate violence, which prompted Western nations to cut some aid to Romania. Munteanu said he has been under arrest ``on absolutely groundless charges. I have the testimony of thousands of people.'' According to a communique released by the prosecutor's office, Munteanu is the only student among the 177 people arrested in an upsurge of violence June 13-15. On June 13, police headquarters, the Ministry of the Interior and TV headquarters were firebombed after police cleared downtown University Square of protesters. Thousands of miners then took over the streets, beating anyone they suspected of being against the government. The Student League dissociated itself from the violence of June 13, it said Monday. Bucharest University protested ``irresponsible actions'' that devastated the university.

DOC.HEAD: U-M Social Research Institute Will Open Warsaw Branch
DOC.TEXT: The University of Michigan is establishing a Warsaw branch of its Institute for Social Research to study Poland's fast-moving political changes first hand. The Center for Social Research-Osrodek Studiow Spolecznych will be the first collaborative venture in the social and behavioral sciences between the United States and an Eastern European country, institute Director Robert Zajonc said. Scholars in Poland and Ann Arbor will benefit, he said in a recent interview. Five Polish scholars plan to attend an Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research at the University of Michigan this summer. And several University of Michigan researchers have projects under way in Poland. For example, a political science professor, Ronald Inglehart, is studying changing values from generation to generation, and a sociology professor, Duane Alwin, is studying concepts of justice in Eastern Europe. For Zajonc, opening the branch in his native Poland is both a professional and personal achievement. He fled the country in 1940 to escape the Nazis. Professionally, he said, he is excited about the chance to examine Poland's changing society. ``When the government changed, everything changed, and this is an absolutely unique opportunity,'' Zajonc said. ``It was a one-time event, a transformation from communism to capitalism overnight. Political and economic events of this nature don't happen, and if it happens you'd better be there to watch.'' The institute, founded in 1946, has an annual budget of $21 million, mostly from grants and government contracts, and a staff of 90 research scientists, several hundred researchers and more than 300 field interviewers. The branch at the University of Warsaw will have a staff of six scientists and four assistants and an annual budget of about $250,000, provided by the University of Warsaw and U.S. foundations.

DOC.HEAD: Fang Says He Will Continue To Work For Progess In China
With PM-China-Dissidents
DOC.TEXT: Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi, freed by a government eager to improve ties with the West, said today he will continue to work for ``progress and development'' in China. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, arrived in Britain Monday night after the Chinese government agreed to permit them to leave their refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. The couple had sought refuge there after the Chinese government's June 4, 1989, military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. ``As citizens of China, we hope to do whatever we can in the future to help China's continuing progress and development,'' Fang said in a statement issued through the Royal Society in London. The statement was issued after the society canceled tentative plans to present Fang at a news conference. Fang's statement said he and his wife were looking forward to a few days of quiet to ``rest and recuperate, and to have some medical tests.'' ``The past year has been difficult for us, but we have received strong support from the international scientific community and friends everywhere,'' the statement said. ``My wife and I would also like to express our heartfelt appreciation to President Bush, Ambassador (James) Lilley, and the staff at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing.'' The Royal Society, one of the country's oldest and most prestigious scientific organizations, invited the 54-year-old astrophysicist to Britain. He will be a senior visiting fellow at Cambridge University's Institute of Astronomy, the institute's director said. ``We understand that our son in China will be soon be able to study abroad, and we are naturally looking forward to a family reunion,'' Fang said in the statement. Fang and Li have two sons. Fang Ke is a student at Wayne State University in Detroit and Fang Zhe is a student at Beijing University. Fang and Li, a physicist, flew to Britain late Monday night aboard a U.S. Air Force transport jet from Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MOSCOW
Gorbachev Meets Landsbergis; Republic Debates Moratorium On Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Landsbergis returning to Vilnius. Pick up 5th pvs, ``The proposed...'; Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis met with Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Kremlin today, then returned to his republic as its parliament prepared to debate a moratorium on independence. Gorbachev invited Vytautas Landsbergis to the unannounced meeting, apparently to discuss Gorbachev's proposal that the Lithuanian parliament pass a moratorium on its March 11 declaration, said Haris Subacius, a spokesman in the Lithuanian Supreme Council parliament. An aide to Landsbergis also confirmed the meeting, but declined to comment further. Landsbergis returned later to Vilnius for a parliament debate on the moratorium, which has been recommended by Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene. ``The proposed temporary moratorium could save our dignity and at the same time promote the solution of the accumulated problems,'' the official Soviet news agency Tass quoted Mrs. Prunskiene as telling a news conference Monday. Lithuania has been under an Kremlin economic blockade since shortly after its declaration. Soviet authorities partially lifted the embargo by resuming natural gas shipments to a Lithuanian fertilizer factory, amounting to 15 percent of Soviet gas deliveries to Lithuania. Crude oil and gasoline shipments remain cut and many Lithuanian businesses have closed, forcing thousands out of work. The Lithuanian Council of Ministers, which Mrs. Prunskiene heads, accepted Gorbachev's proposal earlier this month. Landsbergis has been less inclined to compromise. Gorbachev proposed the moratorium as a formula to enable him to open talks with the secessionist republic and lift the economic embargo. Details are sketchy, but he appears to be seeking a longterm agreement with Lithuania and its sister Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, to keep them as republics in a newly constituted Soviet Union. His chances of forcing them to retain their old status, or to accept recently passed Soviet rules governing secession, diminished this month when Russia, the largest Soviet republic, passed a resolution declaring its sovereignty. Although the Russian declaration did not go as far as steps taken by the three Baltic republics, it set the stage for the transfer of many powers from central authorities to elected governments in the 15 Soviet republics. Mrs. Prunskiene and some Soviet officials have been searching for a compromise to resolve the impasse. Her popularity has been rising rapidly among Lithuanians during the crisis, compared with that of Landsbergis, who is losing favor, according to a poll released Monday. It was conducted by the Sociological Research Department of the Lithuanian Academy of Sciences and reported by Interfax, an unofficial news service of Radio Moscow. Mrs. Prunskiene had a favorable rating among 61 percent of those surveyed, followed by the deputy prime minister and leader of the breakaway Lithuanian Communist Party, Algirdas Brazauskas, with 50 percent, the report said. Landsbergis' rating has declined from 45 percent to 28 percent since the independence declaration, it said. Interfax did not report the poll's margin of error or say how many people were contacted. Despite signs of a compromise, the Lithuanian parliament has continued to pass and implement laws that seem likely to anger Soviet hard-liners. On Monday, Landsbergis and other members of parliament received new Lithuanian identity cards, which are to be distributed later this week to all young men as a first step toward avoiding compulsory service in the Soviet army, according to Tass.

DOC.HEAD: Police Release Sketch In Zodiac Gunman Case
DOC.TEXT: Police have released a sketch of a man who may be the so-called ``zodiac'' gunman. Four people who have been wounded in New York City since March are believed to be victims of the gunman. One victim, a 78-year-old man who was shot four weeks ago, died Sunday. In letters sent to police and news organizations, the writer listed the first three shootings and threatened to shoot 12 people _ one for each sign of the zodiac. The sketch released by police is that of a man who asked a drifter his date of birth. The drifter was shot a few days later. Investigators said the drifter was stalked because of his astrological sign, referred to in a note left in Central Park at the site of the shooting. Police believe the gunman is unrelated to the killer dubbed the ``zodiac,'' who claimed responsibility for as many as 40 killings in a series of notes sent to San Francisco-area newspapers from 1968 to 1987.

DOC.HEAD: European Leaders Fight Off Franco-German Efforts for Quick Soviet Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with final statement, comments by Kohl, Thatcher, call for support to Iran. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Western European leaders today signaled support for Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts to rescue his ailing Soviet economy but fended off a Franco-German push for an immediate $15 billion aid package. The leaders of the 12-nation trading bloc ended a two-day summit by asking aides to consult with the Kremlin about urgent proposals for immediate loans and longer term assistance. Prime Minister Charles Haughey, the host of the meeting, said the leaders were aware of concerns about the Soviet president's chances of success in pushing his perestroika program of economic reform. ``The community is concerned lest those difficulties on the economic front might impede, disrupt the process of perestroika ... in which we all have a very real vested interest,'' he told a news conference. The troublesome question also will be at the top of the agenda of next month's economic summit of the seven leading industrialized nations in Houston. In their final statement, the leaders praised reform efforts in South Africa but made no move to ease the economic sanctions imposed against the white-led government in 1986. They renewed their willingness to consider a gradual relaxation of the prohibitions ``when there is clear evidence that the process of change already initiated continues.'' Britain's Margaret Thatcher, who has pushed for a lifting of prohibitions, hailed their statement urging an end to violence in South Africa. She said it was directed at black leader Nelson Mandela's African National Congress and its support for an armed struggle, which ``ought to be abandoned.'' In a separate statement, the leaders expressed their ``deep revulsion'' at recent signs of anti-Semitism in Europe. Since May 10, there have been numerous incidents of vandalism at Jewish cemeteries, although non-Jewish cemeteries have also been targets. They also expressed their ``profound sympathy'' to Iran after an earthquake in the northwestern part of the country killed tens of thousands. They promised to provide ``all possible assistance'' to disaster victims. On the question of Soviet aid, a senior West German official, demanding anonymity, said he expected an aid package to be decided by year's end. ``I think there is a majority for providing help to the Soviet Union,'' the official said. But he acknowledged that ``no figure will be cited'' at the end of the summit. In taking a cautious approach on the Soviet Union, the officials, led by Mrs. Thatcher, rejected an appeal by France and West Germany for an immediate $15 billion aid package. ``I favor support for economic reform but there has to be reform to be supported,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. Spain's prime minister, Felipe Gonzalez, said, ``It wouldn't be responsible for the community to fix a budget (aid package) without knowing the needs.'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who made a stong pitch for immediate help for the Soviet Union, said he was satisfied with the results of the summit. He emphasized that aid for Moscow is a ``long-term investment from which we all can benefit.'' ``It only makes sense if the Soviets understand that this is help to help themselves,'' he said. West German banks have already agreed to pump $3.1 billion worth of loans into the Soviet economy. In exchange for the help, Kohl has said he would urge the Kremlin ``to adopt a constructive approach'' toward membership of a united Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Gorbachev has opposed immediate and full membership for the new German state in the Western military alliance. West Germany now belongs to NATO, its eastern neighbor to the crumbling, Soviet-led Warsaw Pact.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent Killed After Happening Upon Bank Robbery; Man Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd gaf to CORRECT `they' to `then', add attribution.
DOC.TEXT: A veteran FBI agent who happened upon a bank robbery was shot and killed as he tried to arrest the robber. A 27-year-old man was arrested several hours later on a murder warrant. The robbery was in progress at a Security Pacific Bank branch several blocks east of the Las Vegas Strip on Monday when agent John Bailey, 47, arrived to serve a subpoena, police said. The agent drew his gun and ordered the robber to halt, said Metropolitan Police Deputy Chief John Sullivan. When the man displayed a gun, Bailey fired a shot, but it missed. The man then knocked Bailey against a wall and shot him several times, he said. Carlos Gurry was arrested several hours after the shooting. Sullivan said a tip led to Gurry, and that questioning him led police to get a search warrant and then to book Gurry on a murder warrant. He remained in jail today pending a hearing before a magistrate. Bailey died in surgery at University Medical Center about three hours after the shooting. He had been shot twice in the chest, once in the back and several times in the arm, said hospital spokesman Dale Pugh. No others were reported injured. Bailey, a former Marine captain who was decorated for valor during the Vietnam War, had been with the FBI for 21 years. He was the 29th FBI agent killed in the line of duty in the United States, said Las Vegas agent-in-charge Jim Weller.

DOC.HEAD: GMAC Shooting Survivors Back to Work in New Office
DOC.TEXT: Survivors of last week's massacre at the local General Motors Acceptance Corp. office are back at work in new quarters. Seven workers and one customer were killed and five workers were wounded June 18 by James Edward Pough, who shot people at random in GMAC's Baymeadows office before killing himself. GMAC opened new offices Monday in the Southpoint office complex about two miles north of its previous office. Company officials said there was no thought to returning to the old office. ``Not for what these people have been through _ we couldn't do it,'' said Jerry Robbins, a General Motors spokesman. Robbins said employees are trying to put the tragedy behind them. A uniformed, off-duty police office stood guard Monday afternoon in front of GMAC's new office, but to keep away curiosity seekers and to provide employees with ``a certain sense of security,'' Robbins said. People bought baskets of plants and flowers to the new office in memory of the slain workers. Each desk in the office was decorated with a single red rose _ courtesy of a local moving company. Robbins said GMAC plans to stay in its temporary location for several months before deciding where to locate permanently. The five wounded by Pough in the shooting spree at GMAC remain hospitalized, but are expected to survive. GMAC said it has discovered that it mailed two letters to Pough seeking $6,394 he still owed the company after it repossessed his 1988 Grand Am. Pough turned the car in January and was notifed in March that the company had sold the car and the proceeds had been applied against his loan. But it said he still owed $6,394. On April 6, a computer-generated letter also was mailed to Pough. But he was not contacted after that and the company had concluded the debt was uncollectable, said Joseph D. Taylor Jr., GMAC regional manager from Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Two Soviets Arrested in Alleged Plot to Smuggle Guns to Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Two Soviet emigres were arrested in an alleged plot to smuggle assault weapons to Moscow for sale on the black market, federal officials said. Alexandre Mikouline, 51, was arrested Monday at Tampa International Airport where he was waiting to board a flight to Washington, D.C., and Moscow. An hour later, Georgy Kuparadze, 50, was arrested at a St. Petersburg Beach condominium. Both faced preliminary felony charges of conspiring to provide false information to a gun dealer. who heads the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms branch in Tampa, said his office expects Jim Sudberry, to get a search warrant today to inspect Mikouline's baggage. Sudberry said agents expect to find seven shotguns they believe were bought at a Tampa area gun shop. He said the government's case would be spelled out in a federal complaint today, and that the charges would carry possible 10-year sentences. Mikouline, a resident alien of St. Petersburg Beach, is a Soviet citizen who was in the United States on a visa, Sudberry said. Kuparadze was born in the Soviet Union, emigrated to Canada and has been living in New York on a Canadian passport. Both men were held overnight at the Hillsborough County Jail. They were to appear before a federal magistrate this afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: China Executes 14 Drug Traffickers, Burns 2,200 Pounds of Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Police burned 2,200 pounds of heroin and opium at a rally in southern China, then announced death sentences for 14 drug traffickers, the official Xinhua news agency said. The traffickers were later executed. The ceremony took place in southern Tunnan province, considered China's drug trafficking center. The nationally televised evening news showed a stadium in the provincial capital of Kunming filled with spectators, who applauded as police officers lit a row of pyres piled high with heroin and opium. Xinhua reported that police burned 1,144 pounds of heroin and 1,056 pounds of opium that had been confiscated in the past few years. Also at the rally, Qiu Chuangjiao, president of the provincial Higher People's Court, announced the death sentences of 14 drug traffickers, Xinhua said. It said they then were executed. Neither report gave any details about the condemned people or the executions. China's drug problem is most serious in the southwestern province of Yunnan, which adjoins the ``Golden Triangle'' region of northern Laos, Thailand and Burma, which produces most of the world's heroin. Drug trafficking and use were virtually eliminated after the Communists came to power in 1949. However, in recent years drug use has increased, particularly in the south. Last year, health workers found 146 AIDS-infected drug addicts in Yunnan _ a discovery that shocked the country. Earlier this month, provincial authorities launched an anti-drug campaign, asking each village to form its own anti-drug team.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Say Government Troops Killing Civilians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with details of rebel and government casualties, EDITS to conform; pickup 14th graf pvs, `The current...'
DOC.TEXT: Air force planes bombed and strafed residential areas and killed an unknown number of civilians in a battle for a strategic fort in the northern city of Jaffna, Tamil Tiger rebels said today. At least 196 people were killed as rebels and government forces fought for control of Tamil-dominated areas in the north and east, military officials and residents said. The charred bodies of at least 100 Tamil Tiger rebels were found in an eastern town, and 50 policemen were massacred by the rebels in the north, the officials and residents said. In addition, the military said it had killed 41 rebels and lost five soldiers in a mine explosion. The Tigers, in a statement to an Indian news organization, said five air force bombers and one helicopter gunship dropped incendiary devices and 120-pound bombs on residential areas in Jaffna on Monday. At one point, bombers and helicopters attacked the area continuously for three hours, and hundreds of buildings near the Jaffna Fort were set on fire, the rebels said. Military officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Sri Lankan air force planes were again bombing and strafing rebel positions today. The government said the 270 security forces who had been trapped in the 200-year-old fort in the heart of the city had established positions 1,000 yards outside the garrison. Military officials have said troops would try to avoid killing civilians. ``We are not hellbent on bombing and killing people,'' Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunge said. He added that helicopter gunships would try to pinpoint their targets. There was no way to independently verify either rebel or government claims because transportation and telephone services to the region have been cut off. Travelers reaching Vavuniya, just south of Jaffna, confirmed that heavy bombing and strafing operations had begun along the whole of the Jaffna peninsula. The fort is in the heart of Jaffna, a city of 120,000 that is the headquarters of the Tamil separatist movement. It is 186 miles north of Colombo. Loss of the fort would the most serious blow to the government since fighting started again June 11. At least 1,626 combatants and many civilians have died. The government won the eastern city of Batticaloa on Monday, and residents contacted by telephone said it was filled with soldiers today. The current round of fighting began June 11 near Batticaloa after a Tamil man claimed he was manhandled by police of the Indian Ocean island nation's majority Sinhalese. Tamil Tigers then overran a series of police stations. The clashes ended a tenuous 13-month cease-fire between ethnic Tamil separatists and the Sinhalese-dominated government. The Tigers apparently are digging in for a protracted guerrilla war, according to some of their military leaders, who spoke to reporters from their jungle hideouts in Batticaloa district last week. Tamil Tiger rebel mortars, rockets and gunfire have pounded the Jaffna Fort for the past two weeks. Last week, the government reported the 270 soldiers and policemen pinned down inside were running out of food, water, medicines and ammunition. ``If the rebels do not permit food and medicine to reach the soldiers and policemen in the fort, we will be taking military action to clear a path,'' Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne warned Monday. Over the weekend, air force planes dropped leaflets warning residents near the fort to leave the area. At least 12,000 people, including 1,150 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the Tamil separatist war since 1983. Indian troops withdrew from Sri Lanka in March, ending an unsuccessful, 32-month-long operation to disarm Tamil separatists. Tamils, mostly Hindu, form 18 percent of the island's 16 million people. Tamils have long accused the Sinhalese majority of discrimination. The Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population, control the government and the military.

DOC.HEAD: Small Plane Crashes; Pilot, Passenger Killed
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine plane crashed in flames about 100 yards from a retirement home today, killing the pilot and the other person on board, authorities and witnesses said. The plane, a single engine Bellanca craft, went down at about 9 a.m. across the street from the 350-bed Grace Presbyterian Village nursing home. No one was reported injured on the ground. Witnesses said they heard a sputtering sound or a boom and saw the plane go down. ``We immediately went to the plane to see if there was anything we could do,'' said a witness, Dwight Bell. ``Unfortunately, there was nothing we could do. The passenger did make an attempt to get out of the plane. It was very sad to sit there and watch it burn like that.'' Bill Anderson of the Federal Aviation Administration's regional office in Fort Worth said the pilot reported engine and landing gear problems moments before the plane struck power lines. The plane was about four miles away from Red Bird Airport, a general aviation airport in south Dallas, but Anderson said he did not know if the plane had just taken off or was preparing to land. ``It's just the Lord's blessing that it didn't crash on top of us,'' said retirement center receptionist Betty Williams. ``It's not luck. The Lord was just looking out for us.'' ``I guess (the pilot) was trying to land right here in the middle of the street.''

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Freighter Aground in Columbia River; No Spill Reported
DOC.TEXT: A 650-foot freight ship with a load of lumber went aground in the Columbia River this morning but no cargo or oil was spilled and nobody was injured, the Coast Guard said. The Pacduke, a Liberian-registered ship, went aground shortly after 6 a.m. near Cottonwood Island between Rainier and Kalama, Wash., said Lt. j.g. Sherry Bourgeault of the Coast Guard's Portland station. She said the grounding 70 miles upriver from the mouth of the Columbia apparently resulted from a steering malfunction as the ship tried to maneuver through a curve in the waterway. ``The vessel is high and dry,'' Bourgeault said. ``It grounded at a high tide and tide is on its way down now. It might be there for a while.'' She said a Coast Guard investigative team was dispatched to the ship. ``I couldn't tell you how hard it is going to be to refloat the ship,'' she said. Tugs were being sent to the site. The Coast Guard issued a notice to users of the river to exercise extreme caution and minimize wake when passing the grounded ship.

DOC.HEAD: Paris Opera Tickets Soar in Price
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT spelling to Otello, sted Othello.
DOC.TEXT: The price of tickets at the new Paris Opera, conceived to bring opera to a broad public at affordable rates, will rise sharply in September. The cheapest seats _ now $9 _ will double in price, while the most expensive ones will jump from $66 to $93. ``It's a question of bringing in money,'' Opera president Pierre Berge, was quoted as saying in an interview published in the weekend Le Figaro Magazine. Berge, the financial wizard behind the Yves Saint-Laurent fashion empire, was quoted as saying that he had always ``campaigned against the privileges of money so that tickets would be inexpensive. ``Otherwise, what's the purpose of building a popular Opera.'' The Opera-Bastille, which seats 2,700 in its main auditorium, was conceived by President Francois Mitterrand to make culture more accessible to the masses and spark urban renewal in the eastern part of Paris. Opponents contended that Paris did not need another opera house, and that existing theater, the ornate Palais Garnier, met the city's needs. While the cost of attending premieres will once again make them an elite preserve, Berge said he would not approve ``black tie affairs.'' The new facility, overlooking the historic Place de la Bastille, will put on 78 perfromances next season, including Guiseppe Verdi's ``Otello'' starring Placido Domingo and a co-production with Milan's La Scala opera house of Tchaikovsky's ``Queen of Spades.''

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: Lippman said.
DOC.TEXT: And when is a freebie golf trip considered a gift? Only when lawmakers say so. In 1988, the Pennsylvania Manufacturing Association spent a reported $20,000 entertaining seven lawmakers at a Florida golf resort. Only one reported the outing, although three others said they went but didn't consider it a gift. Lawmakers can get free movie passes in Pennsylvania, free lift tickets at ski resorts in Utah, race track tickets in Maryland, college basketball tickets in Kentucky and all sorts of freebies to professional sports. Take a ticket in Wisconsin, however, and you'll be criminally prosecuted. Wisconsin is the only state that bars lawmakers from taking anything of value _ even a cup of coffee. Four Wisconsin senators were fined for accepting free lodging from a special interest while attending a Chicago Bears-Green Bay Packers football game. In a separate case, the Tobacco Institute was fined for giving tickets to a state senator for the Los Angeles Lakers-Boston Celtics basketball game during a legislative trip to Boston. Thirteen states set limits on the value of gifts a legislator can accept from a single lobbyist, ranging from a $10 per month in California to $100 per gift in West Virginia. But there's plenty of room for ambiguity. Despite Nebraska's limit of $25 per gift, a lobbyist onced hauled a senator around with a private plane until state officials intervened. Dannie Trautwein, executive director of the state's Accountability and Disclosure Commission, said the lobbyist was lectured on the intent of the state's lobbying law. But no one was prosecuted because of the vagaries of defining a gift. ``He looked me right in the eye and said the plane was just going in the same direction as the senator and anbyody could have gotten on it,'' Trautwein said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Central Park Jogger, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0518,0743
DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Describes Central Park Jogger Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `Each of...', to UPDATE with testimony this morning. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Charged with...'.
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor described in gruesome detail the gang-rape and attempted murder of a Central Park jogger as the trial of three teen-agers accused in the attack got under way. Defense lawyers suggested their clients' statements were coerced. ``She was forced to submit to repeated sexual intercourse as each one took his turn. After the group finished raping and beating and sexually abusing her, somebody still took a pipe and struck her in the head, leaving her for dead,'' Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer told the jurors Monday. ``Every bone supporting her left eye was broken. She was in shock. She had cuts and bruises covering her body. They left her to die, naked and stripped,'' the prosecutor said. The woman, an investment banker, was making her nightly jog through the park on April 19, 1989, when she was attacked. She survived, but suffered brain damage and ``has no recollection of what happened to her that night,'' Lederer said. Photos of the victim showed that she suffered the same injuries that the defendants described inflicting, Lederer said, adding that the three would convict themselves with statements they made after they left the woman gang-raped and beaten nearly to death. ``Each of these defendants told police they participated in the attack that night,'' said Lederer. In testimony today, a police officer, Raymond Alvarez, described how he encountered a bloodied man believed to be the first victim assaulted by the gang who later attacked the woman jogger. As he and the injured man, Antonio Diaz, looked for his assailants, they came upon a bicyclist who said a group of youths tried to assault him but he managed to get away. Alvarez was the third person to testify; the first two were technical witnesses who had made maps of Central Park. Charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot are Raymond Santana and Yusef Salaam, both 16, and Antron McCray, 15. They are charged as adults, but if convicted, they would be sentenced as juveniles to up to 10 years in prison. Three other youths are due to stand trial on the same charges later this year. McCray and Santana gave written and videotaped statements to police after they were arrested. Salaam gave neither, but a police fficer took notes on comments he allegedly made and Justice Thomas Galligan has ruled the notes may be presented as evidence. Lawyers for the defendants said in brief opening remarks that the statements had been coerced by police lies, ruses and intimidation. Michael Joseph, McCray's lawyer, said his client initially denied involvement in the attack, and then the police ``added facts'' because he was not telling them what they wanted to hear. The defense lawyers also argued that there is no scientific evidence linking the defendants to the attack, and that without the statements, the prosecution's case is weak at best. Lederer said the defendants were part of a larger group of 30 to 35 youths who entered Central Park at 110th Street around 9 p.m. the night of the attack specifically to ``rob, beat and assault people.'' The three were also charged with assaulting two male joggers the same night. Lederer said that by the time the group left the park around 10 p.m., they assaulted or tried to assault at least eight people. Police said the defendants called their action wilding. Lederer said the victims were randomly chosen. The prosecutor said McCray told police: ``We charged her. We got her on the ground and everybody was hitting her. ... Everybody was stomping and everything ... and we all took turns getting on top of her. I just kicked. There was a whole bunch of us just kicking.'' Lederer said she expects to call more than 50 witnesses and present an array of photographs and medical records during the trial, which is expected to last six to eight weeks. The victim, now 29, spent several months in a New York Hospital before being transferred to a Connecticut facility for further rehabilitation. She recently returned to work at Salomon Brothers and was promoted to vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Police Recover Stolen Edvard Munch Lithograph
DOC.TEXT: A lithograph by Norwegian artist Edvard Munch, stolen from an Oslo art gallery in April, has been recovered, news reports said Tuesday. The print, Madonna, worth about $231,000, was among four works by Norwegian artists recovered at a house in Drammen, near Oslo, newspapers said. All the works had been stolen. Two Norwegian men were held on charges of receiving stolen property, but they were not suspected of stealing the artworks, reported the Norwegian news agency NTB. Their names were not released. The Madonna was among a number of works stolen from the Kunsthuset gallery in mid-April. Thieves broke down the door of the museum with a rail from a trolley track. Munch, who died in 1944, is considered a key inspiration in German expressionism. The painter and graphic artist's emotionally charged style often reflected such themes as fear and death.

DOC.HEAD: Basque Group Claims Three Recent Killings; Says One Was Mistake
DOC.TEXT: The Basque separatist organization ETA on Tuesday claimed responsibility for three recent killings but said one was a mistake, and it apologized for that attack. ETA seeks independence from Spain for the three-province northern Basque region. It began its violent campaign in 1968. In a statement Tuesday in the Basque daily newspaper Egin, ETA claimed responsibility for the June 13 shooting of retired Army Col. Jose Lasanta in San Sebastian. It also claimed responsibility for the deaths of former policeman Virgilio Do Nascimento on May 22 and Rafael San Sebastian on June 10. Referring to the killing of San Sebastian, a civilian, ETA expressed ``its most serious and sincere self-criticism over this irreparable mistake.'' The statement gave no explanation. Police believe ETA suspected San Sebastian of drug trafficking. In the past, ETA has killed at least five people it accused of involvement in drug trafficking in the Basque region. Also Tuesday, two suspected Basque terrorists were found dead, and police said they apparently committed suicide to avoid capture following a shootout with Civil Guards. The bodies were found in a rural area near Pamplona, which is near the Basque region. The dead man and woman suffered single bullet wounds to the head. Two pistols were found next to the bodis, along with another gun taken from a Civil Guard killed in the shootout Monday with Basque terrorists.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says Israel Will Not Block Soviet Jews From Setling In Territories
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Tuesday that Israel will not block Soviet Jewish immigrants from settling in the occupied territories. His statement was seen as a clarification of remarks made Sunday by Housing Minister Ariel Sharon. Sharon said the immigrants would not be settled ``beyond the Green Line'' _ Israel's pre-1967 borders. But Israel radio quoted Shamir as saying this was not a change from previous policy. Shamir said of Sharon's statement: ``Of course, he said that nobody will be sent by us to certain territories and to certain locations. But everybody in a democratic country has the right to settle wherever he wishes.'' The United States and Soviet Union strongly oppose settling Soviet Jewish immigrants in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, saying such settlements are obstacles to peace. Palestinians and Arab countries fear the Palestinians will be pushed out of the territories if immigrants are allowed to settle in them. Also Tuesday, Palestinian leaders from the occupied West Bank urged the United Nations to play a stronger peacemaking role in the Middle East ``in view of the failure of American diplomacy.'' They also asked the United Nations to set up a system to monitor the settlement of Soviet Jewish immigrants in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The requests were made during a meeting with U.N. envoy Jean-Claude Aime. Aime is on a weeklong fact-finding visit to Israel and the occupied territories at the behest of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Aime met Monday with Shamir, and Israeli newspapers said Tuesday he had offered U.N. mediation between Israelis and Palestinians. The Hebrew daily Haaretz said Shamir declined the offer, saying Israel still hoped for U.S. backing for its own election plan in the territories. The election would lead to limited autonomy for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the territories. Defense Minister Moshe Arens, meanwhile, met with three mayors of West Bank towns and promised to reopen two more Palestinian universities, the Abu Dis College of Science and Technology near Jerusalem and An Najah College in Nablus. Two weeks ago, the army announced that a nursing school in the West Bank town of El Bireh would be the first academic institution to reopen. The army closed universities and colleges in the occupied territories shortly after the start of the Palestinian uprising 30 months ago, contending they were hotbeds of anti-Israeli activity. Arens also promised to release an unspecified number of detained Palestinians as a gesture of good will on the upcoming Moslem holidary of Eid el-Adha. The Palestinian plea for U.N. help came in a petition by the West Bank leaders, who included five university professors and one physician. Saeb Erekat, a political science lecturer in Nablus, read the 12-point petition to reporters. ``In view of the failure of American diplomacy to start a peace process and as a result of the decision taken by the United States to suspend its dialogue with the PLO, the Palestinian people request from the U.N. secretary-general to intensify his efforts in this field,'' the petition said. President Bush last week announced the suspension of the 18-month U.S. dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. He did so after PLO chief Yasser Arafat failed to condemn an attempted raid on Israel's coast by Palestinian guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Government Urges Jurors to ``Use Common Sense'' to Find Guilty Verdict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with closing argument from Marcos attorney. Trims. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos' lawyer today mocked prosecutors for trying to convict her of fraud with ``must-have-beens'' instead of solid evidence. Attorney Gerry Spence said the case against the former Philippine first lady was: ``She spent a lot of money; it must have been dirty money. She must have known, of course she must, and everybody lied.'' ``That argument is a presumption of guilt,'' he said in his closing statement today. Spence depicted Mrs. Marcos as a loyal wife and mother for 35 years who had been unfairly accused of stealing and excoriated in the press for her personal habits. She is the widow of former Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos. As for the spending sprees that the government alleges were financed with money stolen from the Philippine treasury, he said, ``She could have bought every piece of jewelry on the face of this earth and not be guilty of anything.'' He reminded jurors that the prosecution was obligated to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. ``That burden never changes, and that doesn't mean there are a lot of must-have-beens,'' Spence said. In a daylong closing statement Monday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella said ``powerful circumstantial evidence'' had shown that Mrs. Marcos helped steal millions from her country's treasury and defrauded U.S. banks in buying four New York office buildings, artworks and jewelry. LaBella said her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, had agreed to help Mrs. Marcos and her husband circumvent a 1986 federal court order freezing their U.S. assets _ ``not as a favor, but for a fee.'' Khashoggi's attorneys were to follow Spence, with the case expected to go to the jury Thursday. LaBella repeatedly urged the jury to ``use your common sense'' in sorting out the complicated case, which involved testimony by 95 witnesses and thousands of documents over three months. ``You can be sure that when taken all together, the evidence will show Imelda Marcos and Adnan Khashoggi actively participated in the crimes charged in this indictment,'' he said. LaBella also urged the jury not to be swayed by the fact that Mrs. Marcos fell ill three times during the trial. ``As hard as it may be for you, it's your responsibility to make a decision solely on the facts,'' he said. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan said he planned to sequester the jury during deliberations. Mrs. Marcos, 60, could draw a sentence of up to 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine if convicted on charges of racketeering, conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Khashoggi, 54, faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted of mail fraud and obstructing justice. In his closing statement, LaBella said that both Mrs. Marcos and Khashoggi had used trusted aides to conduct their financial dealings but that both were fully aware of what was going on. The Marcoses were ousted from power in February 1986 and moved to exile in Hawaii. Marcos, originally charged along with his wife, died last September.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility In Conservative Club Bombing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with IRA claiming responsibility; Picks up 4th graf, `Tory leaders ...'; Edits thereafter to trim and conform.
DOC.TEXT: The IRA claimed responsibility today for bombing an elegant social club frequented by Conservative Party leaders and warned that no government policy-makers would be safe until Britain withdraws from Ireland. A porter was badly injured and eight other people were hurt in Monday night's explosion at the Carlton Club in London's fashionable Mayfair district. In a statement issued in Dublin, the Irish Republican Army said an active service unit had ``struck at the heart of Tory rule.'' It described the club as ``the rest and recreation center for the British government who legislate for a military occupation of the North of Ireland.'' The IRA bombed the Grand Hotel in Brighton during a governing Conservative Party conference in 1984, killing five people and narrowly missing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``Like Brighton in 1984,'' the statement said, ``the IRA has brought the war directly to those who keep the British army on the streets and in the fields of Ireland. ``While such occupation continues, and the nationalist people face daily oppression, the policy makers and their military arm will not be safe,'' it said. Scotland Yard examined security camera videotapes today for clues to the bombers. Mrs. Thatcher, the club's only female member, called Monday night's bombing ``one more outrage in a catalog of terrorist inhumanity.'' Tory leaders said they were determined to rebuild the club, as it was after being hit by German bombs in World War II. Commander George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad, told a news conference ``there's not much doubt'' that it was the work of the IRA, which killed five people in a bomb attack on a Conservative Party conference in 1984. The bomb, which exploded at 8:40 p.m., was placed inside a porchway but outside locked security doors, Churchill-Coleman said. ``There was a video camera outside the building and we're examining that tape now,'' he said. The most serious injuries were suffered by Charles Henry, 76, a porter at the club, and Lord Kaberry, 82, a former vice-chairman of the Conservative Party who is a member of the House of Lords. Henry suffered serious head injuries and was recovering from surgery today in the intensive care unit, said Westminster Hospital duty manager Kim Hodgon. Lord Kaberry was suffering from shock, minor cuts and bruises, and would be kept in the hospital for observation, Hodgson said. Hospital spokeswoman Margaret McDagh said two police constables treated for smoke inhalation would probably be discharged today. Police said five others were slightly injured: two other employees at the club, another man and two American tourists, Jane Kahan, 49, and Jacob Boal-Tefhuva, 61, both of New York. They were in the street at the time of the explosion and were treated for cuts from flying glass, a spokesman for St. Thomas' Hospital said. The IRA, whose armed campaign is intended to undermine British resolve in Northern Ireland, has renewed its offensive in Britain and continental Europe. The IRA, which draws its support almost entirely from Roman Catholics, wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. The Carlton, nestled among the establishment watering holes known collectively as Clubland, is a favorite haunt of Conservative Party Cabinet ministers and lawmakers. The blocks around the club were bustling with thousands of tourists heading to restaurants and West End theaters in the neighborhood when the bomb went off. The Fire Brigade rescued 23 people from the three-story building, and dozens of others escaped on their own. ``I hope the timing of this attack, coming during the European summit, will bring home to the international community just what depraved and evil crimnals we face,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in Dublin today at the conclusion of meeting of European Community leaders.

Here is the text of Nelson Mandela's address Tuesday to the joint meeting of Congress: Speaker Thomas S. Foley: Members of the Congress, it is my great privilege and I deem it a high honor and personal pleasure to present to you Mr. Nelson Mandela, Deputy President of the African National Congress. Mr. Mandela: Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, esteemed Members of the United States Congress, Your Excellencies, Ambassadors, and members of the diplomatic corps, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen, it is a fact of the human condition that it shall, like a meteor, a mere brief passing moment in time and space, fleet across the human stage and pass out of existence. Even the golden lads and lasses, as much as the chimney sweepers, come, and tomorrow are no more. After them all they leave the people enduring, multiplying, permanent, except to the extent that the same humanity might abuse its own genius to emulate life itself. And so we have come to Washington, in the District of Columbia, and into these hallowed chambers of the United States Congress, not as pretenders to greatness, but as a particle of a people whom we know to be noble and heroic, enduring, multiplying, permanent, rejoicing in the expectation and knowledge that their humanity will be reaffirmed and enlarged by open and unfettered communion with the nations of the world. We have come here to tell you, and through you, your own people, who are equally noble and heroic, of the troubles and trials, the fond hopes and aspirations of the people from whom we originate. We believe that we know it as a fact that your kind and moving invitation to ask us to speak here derived from your own desire to convey a message to our people. And according to your humane purposes, to give them an opportunity to say what they want of you, and what they want to make of their relationship with you. Our people demand democracy. Our country, which continues to bleed and suffer pain, needs democracy. It cries out for the situation where the law will decree that freedom to speak of freedom constitutes the very essence of legality, and the very thing that makes for the legitimacy of the constitutional order. It stands for the situation where those who are entitled by law to carry arms as the forces of national security and law and order, will not turn their weapons against the citizens simply because the citizens assert that equality, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness are fundamental human rights which are not only inalienable, but must if necessary be defended with the weapons of war. We fight for and visualize a future in which all shall without regard to race, color, creed or sex have their right to vote and to be voted into all elective organs of state. We are engaged in struggle to ensure that the rights of every individual are guaranteed and protected through a democratic constitution, the rule of law, an entrenched bill of rights, which shall be enforced by an independent judiciary as well as a multiparty political system. Mr. Speaker, we are acutely conscious of the fact that we are addressing an historic institution for whose creation and integrity many men and women lost their lives in the war of independence, the civil war, and the war against Naziism and fascism. That very history demands that we address you with respect and candor, and without any attempt to dissemble. What we have said concerning the political arrangements we seek for our country is seriously meant. It is an outcome for which many of us went to prison, for which many have died in police cells, on the gallows, in our towns and villages, and in the countries of southern Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Irked Over Name Change Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit involving two women's singing groups has struck a sour chord with a magistrate, who says courts have more important matters. ``My, my, my, we do live in a litigious society,'' U.S. Magistrate Leo Wagner said after Monday's hearing. The case involves last year's decision by the 30,000-member Sweet Adelines to change its name to Harmony International. Harmony Inc., which split from Sweet Adelines in 1959, sued, claiming the name change infringed on its rights. Wagner said he would issue an order soon and refer the case for a settlement conference. He also made it clear he wasn't happy about the case. ``There are 1,800 cases pending in the U.S. District Court here,'' he said. ``Judges are attempting to preside over cases with grave concerns. ... We have widows and orphans whose breadwinners have been killed and are within the grasp of destitution. This is a busy court.'' Still, he acknowledged, ``In this country, everyone has free access to courts _ the right for darn near anybody to come into court and sue over darn near anything.''

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Face Shortages in Last Hectic Days of Socialism
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Merchants shut stores and cleared shelves this week to make room for a deluge of Western goods, forcing East Germans to forage for food and other necessities during the nation's hectic last days as a socialist state. Officials disagreed over who was to blame for widespread shortages. ``There's no soap here, no meat,'' said Ines Kroll, a 25-year-old mother of two as she pushed her shopping cart past depleted shelves in the only store in Blankenburg, a small town north of Berlin. Many stores selling household goods closed to clear space for the Western products that will pour into the country after Sunday, when the Germanys merge their economies. Some merchants said they also wanted to avoid taking in large amounts of East German marks in the days before the nearly worthless currency is replaced by the valuable West German mark. Experts say many East German companies are keeping their products off the market until next week, when they can sell them for West German marks. Grocery stores have been canceling their orders with East German suppliers and letting their stocks run out. ``Next week, we'll get the West products and the customers will have West German marks,'' said Liane Fischer, a clerk at the Blankenburg store. Lines of up to 1,000 people snaked down sidewalks as people converged on banks to fill out paperwork necessary for converting savings accounts to West German marks. The government, in an attempt to protect its ailing industries from the first rush of Western competition, announced Tuesday a series of tariffs on Western goods beginning Sunday. An 11 percent tariff is to be imposed through the end of the year, replaced the following quarter by a 6 percent tariff. Food will not be affected. East Germany's huge farm collectives are expected to be battered by Western agricultural producers. However, it is uncertain if the tariffs will remain if the current pace of unification continues and the nations are fully unified in December. Many stores are already stocking West German goods under agreements made in March that allowed a limited entry of some products into the country. But many staples still were in short supply. Mrs. Kroll said she could find no detergent and rejected the skimpy selection of meat. She also had mixed feelings about the end of the East German mark. ``My husband mints East German coins for a living,'' she said. Some experts say 1 million to 4 million workers will lose their jobs in the first two years of economic unification. Many of the heavy industries that were once the backbone of the former, centrally planned economy are expected to fail as they face leaner, more efficient Western concerns. The small businesses that will suddenly become independent are expected to have a much better chance of survival than the large, inefficient factories that churn out outmoded cars, electronics and other products. Dietmar Mueller, a spkesman for the East German Economics Ministry, said retailers can make more money by selling West German goods, which have profit margins sometimes three times as high as East German goods. ``Merchants have not ordered enough from (East German) producers because merchants think people won't buy them,'' he said. The result, he said, is that consumers ``have to bite the bullet and buy the much more expensive West German goods.'' But Werner Schwartz, spokesman for the Commerce Ministry, which represents small businesses, said East German goods have merely sold out. The government last month ordered massive price cuts to clear textiles, electronics and other goods that customers were refusing to buy. Some televisions, for example, were cut by 90 percent. Cord Schwartau, an expert on East German industry for the German Institute for Economic Research in West Berlin, said both officials are correct. He said the ``amazingly low prices'' of unattractive goods helped move them off shelves, but that merchants also have been refusing to order new East German goods because they fear consumers won't want them. He said many East German manufacturers themselves are keeping their goods off the market so they can take advantage of higher prices that are expected after Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Rivals Clash In Beirut Slums
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with four wounded, fighting stopped. Pick up 3rd pvs, `Syrian troops...' SUBS last graf pvs, `By police...' to UPDATE total figures.
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias fought street battles in the slums of south Beirut today close to where Western hostages are believed to be held. Police said at least four people were wounded in the three-hour clash between the Syrian-backed Amal militia and the fundamentalist Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said the clashes with automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenades broke out in the Ghobeiri district of south Beirut, a Shiite stronghold. It tapered off three hours later. Syrian troops in charge of security in west Beirut and parts of the southern slums were trying to halt the fighting, the spokesman said. He said the fighting blocked traffic along part of the highway running to Beirut international airport on the city's southern edge. The airport remained open, however, and travelers had to use narrow side streets to get around the gun fights. Ghobeiri is two blocks west of Hezbollah's strongholds in the Bir el-Abed and Hay Madi districts, where most of the 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon are believed to be held. The Western captives are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. It was not known what triggered the gun battles. But Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting on and off for three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. By police count, 1,044 people have been killed and 3,141 wounded in the power struggle.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... southern Africa.
DOC.TEXT: Indeed, we have even had our political representatives killed in countries as far away from South Africa as France. Unhappily, our people continue to die to this day, victims of armed agents of the state who are still determined to turn their guns against the very idea of a non-racial democracy. But this is the perspective which we will trust Congress will feel happy to support and encourage, using the enormous weight of its prestige and authority as an eminent representative of democratic practice. To deny any person their human rights is to challenge their very humanity. To impose on them a wretched life of hunger and deprivation is to dehumanize them, but such has been the terrible fate of all black persons in our country under the system of apartheid. The extent of the deprivation of millions of people has to be seen to be believed. The injury is made that more intolerable by the opulence of our white compatriots and the deliberate distortion of the economy to feed that opulence. The process of the reconstruction of South African society must and will also entail the transformation of its economy. We need a strong and growing economy. We require an economy that is able to address the needs of all the people of our country, that can provide food, houses, education, health services, social security, and everything that makes human life human, that makes life joyful and not a protracted encounter with hopelessness and despair. We believe that the fact of the apartheid structure of the South African economy and the enormous and pressing needs of the people make it inevitable that the democratic government will intervene in this economy. Acting through the elected parliament, we have put the matter to the business community of our country that the need for a public sector is one of the elements in a many sided strategy of economic development and restructuring. That has to be considered by us all, including the private sector. The ANC holds no ideological positions which dictate that it must adopt a policy of nationalization. But, the ANC also holds the view that there is no self-regulating mechanism within the South African economy which will, on its own, insure growth with equity. At the same time, we take it as a given _ as given _ that the private sector is an engine of growth and development which is critical to the success of the mixed economy we hope to see in future _ in the future South Africa. We are accordingly committed to the creation of the situation in which business people, both South African and foreign, have confidence in the security of their investments, are assured of a fair rate of return on their capital, and do business in conditions of stability and peace. We must also make the point, very firmly, that the political settlement and democracy itself cannot survive unless the material needs of the people, the bread and butter issue, are addressed as part of the process of change and as a matter of urgency. It should never be that the anger of the poor should be the finger of accusation pointed at all of us because we failed to respond to the crisis. of the people for food _ to the cries of the people for food, for shelter, for the dignity of the individual. We shall need your support to achieve the post-apartheid economic objectives, which are an intrinsic part of the process of the restoration of the human rights of the people of South Africa. We would like to approach the issue of our economic cooperation not as a relationship between donor and recipient, between a dependent and a benefactor. We would like to believe that there is a way in which we could structure this relationship so that we do indeed benefit from your enormous resources in terms of your capital, technology, all-around expertise, your enterprising spirit and your markets. This relationship should, however, be one from which your people should also derive benefit so that we who are fighting to liberate the very spirit of our entire people from the bondage of the arrogance of the ideology and practice of white supremacy do not build a relationship of subservient dependency and foreign ingratitude. One of the benefits that should accrue to both our peoples and to the rest of the world should surely be that this complex South African society, which has known nothing but racism for three centuries, should be transformed into an oasis of good race relations where the black shall to the white be sister and brother, a fellow South African, an equal human being, both citizens of the world.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Jury Hears Tapes of Mayor's Grand Jury Testimony
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry told a grand jury last year his visits to the hotel room of a convicted drug dealer in 1988 were not ``unusual or criminal,'' according to a tape-recording of his testimony played today at the mayor's cocaine possession and perjury trial. His assertion contradicted the testimony last week of the convicted drug dealer, Charles Lewis, who said he and the mayor smoked crack cocaine on each of four visits Barry allegedly made to Lewis' hotel room. Barry is accused of three felony counts of perjury stemming from his testimony before the grand jury. His taped testimony contradicted Lewis on several other points. Barry told the grand jury he thought his first visit to Lewis' hotel room in Washington, D.C., took place on Dec. 17, 1988. Lewis testified it was Dec. 16. Barry said his Dec. 19 visit with Lewis lasted an hour or less. Lewis testified it lasted well into Dec. 20 and long past the end of the Monday Night Football game. ``Was there anything unusual about the visit'' Dec. 17? assistant U.S. attorney Judith Retchin asked Barry during one of the mayor's two grand jury appearances in January 1989. ``Not that was unusual or criminal,'' replied the mayor.
