In his grand jury testimony, it was the mayor who first brought up the subject of drugs. Barry told the grand jury that Lewis mentioned the term ``working 50'' in casual conversation and that the mayor thought the words had something to do with ``hot clothes ... prostitution or drugs.'' ``It just popped out'' of Lewis' mouth, ``I didn't pursue it,'' the mayor told the grand jury. Lewis testified last week that a ``working 50'' is a bundle of crack cocaine that retails on the streets of Washington, D.C., for $50. Barry is accused of lying when he told the grand jury that he had seen nothing to indicate that Lewis was involved with drugs and that he and Lewis hadn't ever given each other cocaine. On Monday, witnesses testified that Barry coerced a woman into having sex with him and made repeated advances toward others during a string of drug parties in the Virgin Islands. Witnesses testified about the mayor's 1986 and 1988 visits to the Virgin Islands. They described drug use, drinking and the alleged sexual encounter with one of them, Linda Creque Maynard. In an interview later with Washington station WJLA-TV, Barry insisted that the jury in his case should be allowed ``to decide on the credibility of each government witness.'' He has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about involvement with drugs by himself and a friend, Charles Lewis. Maynard, a Virgin Islands resident, testified that she was forced into having sex when she visited Barry in his Virgin Islands hotel room in March 1988. The incident allegedly occurred when Lewis left the two together for about 10 minutes after Maynard and Lewis had smoked crack cocaine together in front of the mayor, Maynard testified. She said Barry, dressed only in a robe, had been ``after me'' from the moment she entered the hotel room. Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin asked her whether Barry had ``limit(ed) himself sexually with you at all.'' ``No, he didn't,'' Maynard replied. ``Did you have sexual relations in the hotel room?'' Retchin asked. ``Yes,'' Maynard said softly. Throughout this section of testimony, Barry sat expressionless at the defense table, staring at the witness. Defense attorney Robert Mance then asked Maynard whether she had fought Barry ``all over the room'' in order to avoid the incident. ``No,'' Maynard replied, ``he already had me down on the bed.'' Maynard, who said earlier that she had considered it ``an honor to meet the mayor of Washington D.C.,'' testified that she did not report the incident to Lewis or local authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Dreska Appointed Director of New Defense Agency
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon on Tuesday announced the selection of Army Maj. Gen. John Paul Dreska, commander of the Defense Construction Supply Center in Columbus, Ohio, as director of the new Defense Commissary Agency. Colin McMillan, assistant secretary of defense for production and logistics, said Dreska will be responsible for consolidating individual service commissary functions into a single Defense Department organization. ``The Army, Navy, Marine and Air Force commissary systems, taken together, are one of the largest grocery store operations in the United States and it is the department's intention to achieve the kind of effficiencies that are available through a commercial grocery store chain,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... the world.
DOC.TEXT: To destroy racism in the world, we together must expunge apartheid racism in South Africa. Justice and liberty must be our tools, prosperity and happiness our weapon. Mr. Speaker, distinguished Representatives of the American people, you know this more than we do, that peace is its own reward. Our own fate, borne by a succession of generations that reach backwards into centuries, has been nothing but tension, conflict, and death. In a sense, we do not know the meaning of peace, except in the imagination. But because we have not known true peace in its real meaning, because for centuries, generations have had to bury the victims of state violence, we have fought for the right to experience peace. On the initiative of the ANC, a process towards the conclusion of a peaceful settlement has started. According to a logic dictated by our situation, we are engaged in an effort which includes the removal of obstacles to negotiations. This will be followed by a negotiated determination of the mechanism which will draw up the new constitution. This should lead to the formation of this constitution-making institution, and therefore the elaboration and adoption of a democratic constitution. Elections would then be held on the basis of this constitution, and for the first time South Africa would have a body of lawmakers which would, like yourselves, be mandated by the whole people. Despite the admitted commitment of President de Klerk to walk this road with us, and despite our acceptance of his integrity and honesty of his purposes. We would be fools to believe that the road ahead of us is without major hurdles. Too many among our white compatriots are steeped in the ideology of racism to admit easily that change must come. Tragedy may yet sully the future we pray and work for if these slaves of the past take up arms in a desperate effort to resist the process which must lead to the democratic transformation of our country. For those who care to worry about violence in our country, as we do, it is at these forces that they should focus their attention, a process in which we are engaged. We must contend still with the reality that South Africa is a country in the grip of the apartheid crime against humanity. The consequences of this continue to be felt, not only within our borders, but throughout Southern Africa, which continues to harvest the bitter fruits of conflict and war, especially in Mozambique and Angola. Peace will not come to our country and region until the apartheid system is ended. Therefore, we say we still have a struggle on our hands. Our common and noble efforts to abolish the system of white minority domination must continue. We are encouraged and strengthened by the fact of the agreement between ourselves, this Congress, as well as President Bush and his administration, that sanctions should remain in place. Sanctions should remain in place because the purpose for which they were imposed has not yet been achieved. We have yet to arrive at the point when we can say that South Africa is set on an irreversible course leading to its transformation into a united democratic and nonracial country. We plead that you cede the prerogative to the people of South Africa to determine the moment when it will be said that profound changes have occurred and an irreversible process achieved, enabling you and the rest of the international community to lift sanctions. We would like to take this opportunity to thank you all for the principled struggle you waged which resulted in the adoption of the historic comprehensive Anti-apartheid Act, which made such a decisive contribution to the process of moving our country forward towards negotiations. We request that you go further and assist us with the material resources which will enable us to promote the peace process and meet other needs which arise from the changing situation you have helped to bring about.
DOC.NOTE: MORE:

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... bring about.
DOC.TEXT: The stand you took established the understanding among the millions of our people that here we have friends, here we have fighters. against racism who feel hurt because we are hurt, who seek our success because they too seek the victory of democracy over tyranny. And here I speak not only about you, members of the United States Congress, but also of the millions of people throughout this great land who stood up and engaged the apartheid system in struggle _ the masses who have given us such strength and joy by the manner in which they have received us since we arrived in this country. Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, Senators and Representatives, we went to jail because it was impossible to sit still while the obscenity of the apartheid system was being imposed on our people. It would have been immoral to keep quiet while a racist tyranny sought to reduce an entire people into a status worse than that of the beasts of the forest. It would have been an act of treason against the people and against our conscience to allow fear and the drive towards self-preservation to dominate our behavior, obliging us to absent ourselves from the struggle for democracy and human rights not only in our country, but throughout the world. We could not have made an acquaintance through literature with human giants such as George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and Thomas Jefferson, and not been moved to act as they were moved to act. We could not have had heard of and admired John Brown, Sojourner Truth, Frederick Douglass, W.E.B. DuBois, Marcus Garvey, Martin Luther King, Jr., and others, we could not have heard of these and not be moved to act as they were moved to act. We could not have known of your Declaration of Independence and not elected to join in the struggle to guarantee the people's life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. We are grateful to you all that you persisted in your resolve to have us and other political prisoners released from jail. You have given us the gift and privilege to rejoin our people, yourselves, and the rest of the international community in the common effort to transform South Africa into a united, a democratic, and nonracial country. You have given us the power to join hands with all people of conscience to fight for the victory of democracy and human rights throughout the world. We are glad that you merged with our own people to make it possible for us to emerge from the darkness of the prison cell and join the contemporary process of the renewal of the world. We thank you most sincerely for all you have done, and count on you to persist in your noble endeavors to free the rest of our political prisoners and to emancipate our people from the life of prison that is apartheid South Africa. The day may not be far when we will borrow the words of Thomas Jefferson and speak of the will of the South African nation. ``In the exercise of that will, by this united nation of black and white people, it must surely be that there will be born a country on the Southern tip if Africa which you will be proud to call a friend and an ally because of its contribution to the universal striving towards liberty, human rights, prosperity, and peace among the peoples.'' Let that day come now. Let us keep our arms locked together so that we form a solid phalanx against racism, to ensure that day comes now. By our common actions, let us ensure that justice triumphs without delay. When that has come to pass, then shall we all be entitled to acknowledge the salute when others say of us, ``Blessed are the peacemakers.'' Thank you for your kind invitation to speak here today, and thank you for your welcome and the attention you have accorded our simple message. Thank you.
DOC.HEAD: End Text
Yeltsin Says Struggle Under Way on Whether to Delay Party Congress
DOC.TEXT: A battle is developing in the Communist Party leadership about whether to go ahead with a crucial congress that many say will decide the party's future, reformer Boris N. Yeltsin said today. Yeltsin spoke in response to news reports that a member of the party's Politburo contacted party officials in the Baltic republic of Estonia to ask their opinion about delaying the congress. Increasingly vocal reformers and traditional Soviet Communists have promised a battle for control of the party at its 28th Congress, which is scheduled to open July 2 in Moscow. A large group of party reformers already has indicated it will leave if the party is not completely overhauled. Some top party members want to hold the congress quickly after the conservative-minded meeting of 2,700 Communists from the Russian republic last week, said Yeltsin, president of the Soviet Union's largest republic. ``Others, in order to somehow stabilize the political situation that has emerged now, are for delaying for a time, perhaps until fall,'' Yeltsin said. Yeltsin said he favored postponement to prepare it more thoroughly. Any decision to postpone the congress would contrast with previous similar sessions, which were planned months in advance. A decision to delay the congress would have to be made by a plenary meeting of the party's Central Committee, expected within the next few days. ``The plenum will be very difficult,'' Yeltsin said. ``There will be a real struggle at the plenum.'' He criticized Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for not preparing more carefully for the conference of Russian communists last week. It elected a conservative first secretary, Ivan Polozkov, who had opposed Yeltsin unsuccessfully last month for the presidency of the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic. Gorbachev's spokesman, Arkady A. Maslennikov, told reporters after Yeltsin's news conference that Gorbachev's position on a possible delay in the plenum would not be disclosed until the Central Committee meeting. It was not clear exactly when the Central Committee would meet. A news service of the Baltic republic Estonia today quoted a spokesman for the republic's Communist Party as saying that Politburo member Vadim A. Medvedev had contacted officials about the possibility of delaying the congress. A spokesman for Medvedev, Alexander Vladimirov, and Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said they could not confirm the reports.

DOC.HEAD: Dr. Karl Menninger Diagnosed as Having Abdominal Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Karl A. Menninger, one of the founders of modern psychiatry, is being treated for abdominal cancer. Menninger, whose 97th birthday is July 22, was in fair condition Tuesday at Stormont-Vail Regional Medical Center. A statement issued Monday by the Menninger psychiatric center, which he co-founded with his father and brother in 1925, said the cancer diagnosis was made last weekend. A course of treatment has not been determined, the statement added. Menninger was hospitalized June 12 after complaining of abdominal pain and loss of appetite. He had been going to his office on the Menninger campus almost daily until then. Menninger, who is chairman of the board of trustees of The Menninger Foundation, often has been called the dean or father of American psychiatry. With his father, Dr. C.F. Menninger, and his brother, Dr. William C. Menninger, both now deceased, Menninger founded the clinic in an old farm home on the northwest edge of Topeka 65 years ago. It later became The Menninger Foundation and is now known simply as Menninger.

DOC.HEAD: George Washington to be Tried For Treason at Mock Trial
DOC.TEXT: Two centuries after he took the helm of a new nation, George Washington is being charged with treason, sedition, high crimes and misdemeanors. Not to worry _ the reputation of the Father of His Country is probably intact. The charges are merely a bit of light-hearted litigation prompted by a British nobleman's tongue-in-cheek challenge to U.S. jurists. Still, several Chicago lawyers who plan to defend Washington when the case comes to trial in October aren't letting the British get the upper hand in this battle. ``There is absolutely no question that George Washington, the father of our country, is not guilty of any crime,'' said Michael W. Coffield, one of the defense attorneys. It all began at a luncheon this month in Washington, D.C., during the national meeting of the American Inns of the Court. The association comprises legal groups inspired by four inns that operate as law schools, eateries and fraternal organizations for British jurists. Lord Goff of Chievely, a British lawyer and nobleman, launched the battle at the luncheon when he called Washington a traitor. He challenged his American colleagues to prove otherwise. ``We dumped over a few tables and were the first to accept that challenge,'' said Jim Figliulo, secretary-treasurer of the Chicago Inn of the Court and a defense team member. Queen Elizabeth II's chief prosecutor was sitting at a nearby table and agreed to represent Britain in the challenge. The Chicago defenders say the trial likely will be held in the Old Bailey, London's criminal courthouse, and actors may be hired to portray Washington and other revolutionary-era heroes. Depending on the outcome, Figliulo said, ``We might invite them back for a trial of King George.''

DOC.HEAD: 14 States Have Limits on Gifts for Lawmakers; 1 Bars Them
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Kansas limit to per year sted per gift. Also moved for PMs
DOC.HEAD: With AM-The Persuaders II
DOC.TEXT: Wisconsin is the only state that bars legislators from accepting gifts, and only 14 other states put limits on the value of gifts that lawmakers may accept. Here are those states and the limits: _ Alaska: 50 per gift. _ California: $10 per month. _ Iowa: $50 per gift. _ Kansas: $100 per year. _ Kentucky: $200 over three years. _ Louisiana: no gifts allowed except tickets to sports events, which limited to $50 per event and $300 per year. _ Maryland: only ``nominal'' gifts allowed. _ Massachusetts: $50 per gift. _ Michigan: $35 per month. _ Nebraska: $25 per gift. _ Nevada: $100 per year. _ New York: $75 per gift. _ Oregon: $100 per year. _ West Virginia: $100 per gift.

DOC.HEAD: National PTA Against Commercialism in Classroom
DOC.TEXT: The National PTA Convention voted today to support legislation that would prohibit businesses from forcing students to view advertising as a condition of receiving donations. The resolution did not deal specifically with Channel One, a controversial 12-minute daily news program that includes two one-minute commercials. However, the program was mentioned in debate. To obtain Channel One, schools sign a contract that loans them free color televisions, a satellite dish and two videocassette recorders for the life of a contract as long as the program is aired in its entirety, including commercials. The resolution adopted today says that donations of the equipment should not be offered on the condition that students view advertising. It urged state and federal legislation to bar the practice. Some delegates argued that newspapers have advertising and are viewed in the schools, but others argued that no one was forcing students to read those ads or watch commercials on other television stations. ``The operation, by selection of program content, could wield a great deal of influence on the minds of youngsters who don't have the option of turning to an alternative channel or turning the set off,'' said Sharon Voliva, a delegate from Dolton, Ill. ``The commercialism is much more damaging than the commercials.'' The convention also approved a resolution urging Congress to further study pesticide residues and children. The pesticide resolution said preschool children have greater exposure to pesticide residues because they eat more food relative to their weight and consume larger quantities of fruit, which can have a higher likelihood of pesticide contamination. The group asked that Congress clarify the Environmental Protection Agency's authority on pesticides and dietary exposure.

DOC.HEAD: Daughter's Foot Hits Gas Pedal as Mother Tries to See Why Car Won't Move
DOC.TEXT: A woman inspecting her car to see why it wouldn't move was killed when her daughter's foot slipped onto the accelerator, police said. The car hit and killed Julia Truly, 51, then rammed a house, injuring 69-year-old Emily Walker, who was inside, police said. Police said Mrs. Truly's car got stuck on a curb Monday in a parking lot, and she stepped out to see why the car wouldn't move. Her 32-year-old daughter, Diane Barber, stayed in the car. When Ms. Truly got in front, Ms. Barber's foot accidentally slipped from the brake to the gas pedal, authorities said. Ms. Walker was pinned beneath furniture and debris from the brick wall of her house. She was released from a hospital after treatment for leg injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Refugees Uncertain Whether to Start New Life or Hope For Return
DOC.TEXT: Morris Karlea escaped with 10 of his 18 children, three of his four wives and the clothes on his back when he fled Liberia after civil war erupted six months ago. Karlea, 43, spoke of the soldiers serving President Samuel Doe, who fought a rebel army that invaded Liberia from the Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. ``When Doe's soldiers arrived we were all scared,'' says Karlea, a coffee farmer from the village of Garplay. ``When they got into town, they were just shooting and shooting. They burned my car. They broke down our home, taking all our things.'' There are about 570 Liberian refugees in Banneu, a town of 3,700 people a couple of miles from the Nyon River that forms Liberia's border with Ivory Coast. Most of the residents live in thatched mud huts and grow coffee, corn and the potato-like cassava. Mussa Jabateh, 34, Karlea's half-brother and also a farmer, fled with his five children before government troops reached Garplay. Life in Banneu suits him. ``We eat here every day, we live a free life,'' he says. ``The people are too good to us.'' Villagers and refugees eat meals mostly of rice and both the leaves and roots of cassava. Once a month the Red Cross delivers a load of frozen fish. The National Patriotic Front's rebel army, commanded by ex-Doe aide Charles Taylor, now claims to control 90 percent of Liberia. An estimated 300,000 of the country's 2.5 million people fled after the fighting began. It is not just a battle to overthrow Doe _ in many cases the fighting has pitted ethnic Gios and Manos against Krahns and Mandingos. Doe is a Krahn. Terrified Liberians tell of government soldiers slaughtering citizens because they were Gios and Manos. There are also allegations of rebel massacres of Krahns and Mandingos. Karlea's mother is a Gio, his father a Mandingo. He had to get somewhere fast. ``I brought nothing, just my trousers and my shirt,'' he says, gesturing to his filthy, torn clothes and ragged sandals. War and life in a jungle village have taken a toll on Marthe Lawehy, who is 29 but looks much older. She came to Banneu in January. Her husband, who works as a power saw operator in Gbelay, near the Ivorian border, stayed behind. She brought four children with her, leaving three more in Liberia with her mother-in-law. ``When Doe's soldiers came, they burned down my house and killed three people in town. Me and my children slept three days in the bushes,'' she recalls. ``Charles Taylor's soldiers saved us. They brought us to the waterside and came here,'' she says. ``For that reason I love the man.'' Banneu village chief Thoma Mabea has thrown his village open to the refugees. ``These are my brothers and I welcome them. I've turned over my own room to them to stay in.'' Karlea, the father of 18, is now trying to build a hut for his family and wants to start a farm here. ``It's war in the country, so I can't go back,'' he says. ``But I want to. Home is sweet.''

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Staffers Withdrawn From Rural Areas After Threats
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0609 to remove garble.
DOC.TEXT: Peace Corps staffers have been pulled out of rural areas and brought to the capital following intelligence reports that Communist rebels planned to kill volunteers, officials announced Tuesday. The move was the latest in a series of measures taken in the wake of threats against Americans by the Communist New People's Army. It has been fighting 21 years to establish a Marxist government in the Philippines. Last week, the Philippine military said rebels in Manila plan to target Americans and other foreigners for assassination and kidnapping over the next six months. U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said Ambassador Nicholas Platt ordered the recall of Peace Corps staffers last weekend but delayed the public announcement for security reasons. He said no decision had been made on when the 261 volunteers would be allowed to return to their posts, mostly in remote, rural areas where security is poor. Schrager said the embassy had received a report that Peace Corps volunteers had been added to the target list of the New People's Army, which is believed to have killed eight Americans here since April 1989. He refused to identify the source of the report but said the embassy took it seriously. In Washington, Peace Corps director Paul Coverdell said he was taking the step as a ``precautionary measure'' and that all volunteers are safe. Communist rebels claimed responsibility for killing two American airmen last month near the U.S.-run Clark Air Base. They threatened to kill more until all U.S. troops leave this country. Last week, the U.S. Embassy warned Americans to take precautions against terrorism in advance of the next round of U.S.-Philippine talks on the future American military bases here. Those talks are expected in August. The lease on the bases expires in September 1991, and the rebels have demanded they be closed. At the Admiral Hotel, where many Peace Corps volunteers were temporarily housed, several said they were ordered to Manila on short notice but were not briefed on the reason beyond the embassy's official statement. ``Most of the Filipinos in my area support Cory (President Corazon Aquino), have nostalgic feelings for (the late President Ferdinand) Marcos and want nothing to do with the NPA,'' said one volunteer, who works on an agricultural project in Nueva Vizcaya province. He and the other volunteers declined to give their names. Coverdell issued a statement saying: ``I wish to assure relatives and friends of the volunteers that the volunteers are safe and emphasize that we are taking these steps only as a precautionary measure.'' He said most of the volunteers were already in Manila. The rebels have made no specific public threats against Peace Corps volunteers but have charged that U.S. and Japanese aid workers secretly assist the Philippine government in its counterinsurgency operations. Both Washington and Tokyo deny the charges. On May 29, rebels on Negros island kidnapped Fumio Mizuno, a training director for a private Japanese aid group, the Organization for Industrial, Spiritual, and Cultural Advancement. Negros authorities have appointed a team to negotiate Mizuno's release, but no talks have been held. Last week, the Philippine military said troops arrested 10 members of a rebel assassination squad and seized documents indicating the guerrillas plan to target foreigners. Military sources said the assassination list included one American, but they refused to reveal his name. Diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said one American embassy staffer was spirited out the country this month. The U.S. Embassy estimates there are up to 140,000 Americans, including 40,000 affiliated with the U.S. military, in the Philippines. Peace Corps volunteers are stationed throughout the main island, Luzon, and the central Visayas chain, including Negros. Volunteers were recalled from the southern island of Mindanao in 1985 because of lawlessness and never returned. Volunteers are involved in projects including education, environment, agriculture and community development.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Lifts Visa Requirements For Syrians
DOC.TEXT: Egypt has lifted visa requirements for Syrian citizens, Egyptian Ambassador Mustapha Abdul-Aziz Mursi announced Tuesday. The move was seen as a further step in the restoration of full, friendly relations between the two Arab nations. Syria cut ties after Egypt in 1979 signed a peace agreement with Israel. Syria restored diplomatic relations in December. ``In view of the brotherly ties and close relations between the two brotherly peoples of Syria and Egypt, the Arab Republic of Egypt has decided to exempt all Syrian brothers who wish to visit Egypt from visa requirements,'' Mursi said. Syria was among Egypt's bitterest enemies after the late President Anwar Sadat signed the U.S.-brokered peace treaty with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Addresses Congress; Asks for Support
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with details, color; combines pvs; should stand for PMs
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela appealed to Congress today to support the struggle for a multiracial democracy in South Africa and said his country ``continues to bleed and suffocate'' under the repression of white-minority rule. ``Our people continue to die to this day, victims of armed agents of the state who are still determined to turn their guns against the very idea of a racial democracy,'' the South African black leader told a rapt audience of lawmakers, diplomats and Cabinet officers in the House of Representatives chamber. Mandela was interrupted by standing applause several times, once when he said the U.S. economic sanctions against South Africa should not be lifted now. ``The purpose for which they were imposed has not been achieved.'' Mandela did not specifically address his support of violence as a last-resort alternative in the struggle for freedom, but he reminded his audience of the many Americans who died for freedom in the Revolutionary War, the Civil War and two world wars. Mandela was greeted with prolonged applause as he made his way into the chamber. He beamed a wide smile as he mounted the podium. Despite the public show of support for Mandela, some members did not attend as a show of protest over Mandela's support for Cuba, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization and his backing of armed struggle. Conservative Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., said he boycotted the speech as a ``matter of principle.'' Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., also stayed away. Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., said he was disappointed Mandela continued to advocate armed struggle. ``Who is the real Nelson Mandela?'' he asked. But other praised the speech. ``It's an extraordinary day,'' said Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif. He said lawmakers heard ``a magnificent black man ... speak powerfully and eloquently as a man of peace.'' In his speech, Mandela said, ``We would be fools to believe that the road ahead of us is without major hurdles. Too many among our white compatriots are slaves in the ideology of racism to admit easily that change must come.'' He added, pointedly: ``For those who care to worry about violence in our country as we do, it is at these forces that they should focus their attention.'' He credited the economic sanctions in place against South Africa for contributing to his release from prison after 27 years. And said they should remain in place until a new constitution is passed and democratic elections held. And he clearly preferred to talk of his vision of a peaceful future: ``Let us keep our arms locked together so that we form a solid phalanx against racism to ensure that that day comes now. By our common actions, let us ensure that justice triumphs without delay.'' Envisioning a day when the white-minority government has been replaced, Mandela said the country's economy must be transformed. But, addressing administration concerns about his socialist economic views, Mandela said, ``The ANC holds no ideological positions which dictate that it must adopt a policy of nationalization.'' Mandela asked for resources for the ANC, even though U.S. officials say President Bush has been reluctant to provide direct financial support for the ANC because the group has refused to renounce violence. ``Here we have friends. Here we have fighters against racism who feel hurt because we are hurt, who seek our success because we, too, seek the victory of democracy over tyranny.'' In their struggle for democracy, Mandela said, black South Africans are following the examples of George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson, as well as black American leaders like Martin Luther King Jr. ``Our people demand democracy. Our country, which continues to bleed and suffocate, needs democracy,'' he said. Mandela had a separate breakfast meeting with members of the Congressional Black Caucus and singer Harry Belafonte. Later, several thousand jubilant people gathered for a noontime rally to honor Mandela on Pennsylvania Avenue. Although organizers said Mandela might stop, he did not, waving instead from his limousine. Mandela, who met with Bush on Monday, was wrapping up his visit to Washington later in the day after several other public appearances, including an afternoon outdoor rally and an evening speech to a crowd that paid $10 or $25 per ticket. In between, he was meeting with congressional leaders. He was traveling to Atlanta on Wednesday, the next stop on his eight-city tour of the United States. Mandela, 71, was honored at a dinner Monday night hosted by Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, and Terry Sanford, D-N.C. Meanwhile Monday, Senate leaders decided to postpone a procedural vote on a civil rights bill, opposed by the administration, scheduled for today. Republicans complained that the vote was a ploy by Democrats to embarrass them during Mandela's visit.

DOC.HEAD: Southwestern Bell Competitors Awarded $15 Million by Federal Jury
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury awarded more than $15 million in damages to two telephone directory publishing companies who complained of unfair competition by Southwestern Bell Corp. and several subsidiaries. The jury on Monday awarded actual damages of $5 million requested by Great Western Directories Inc., and $9,400 by Canyon Directories. Under antitrust law, the damages are trebled. The jury also awarded more than $1 million in attorney fees. Great Western publishes telephone directories, including yellow pages, in nine Texas cities, including Amarillo, and the Oklahoma cities of Lawton and Enid. Canyon Directories publishes telephone directories, including yellow pages, for three towns in the Amarillo area. Great Western and Canyon Directories said Southwestern Bell exerted a double squeeze on their potential profits by increasing the fee to directory companies for Bell's listings while decreasing advertising rates 40 percent in its own white and yellow pages, which it improved. Southwestern Bell had maintained that its actions amounted to lawful competition.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Unveils Proposals To Unify By End Of Year
DOC.TEXT: West Germany unveiled proposals Tuesday to unify the two Germanys politically by mid-December and finally end the countries' 40-year split along Cold War lines. The proposals, in the form of a ``Discussion Paper'' released by the West German Interior Ministry, were made public just five days before the two countries merge their economies and social institutions. Under proposed wording for a treaty on political unification, East Germany would officially join West Germany the day after elections for a joint German parliament. West and East German politicians have proposed Dec. 9 or Dec. 16 as possible dates for the balloting. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said he expected the East German Cabinet to decide Wednesday to begin negotiations on the political treaty. He added that the pact should be ready for debate in both parliaments by early September. The parliaments of both countries last week ratified a treaty outlining the monetary, economic and social union that is to take effect Sunday. On that day, the West German mark officially replaces the nearly worthless East German mark and 40 years of rigid, socialist economic policy give way to free-market rules. The victors and vanquished from World War II are still working on the international ramifications of German unity, namely the military posture of a united Germany and the disposition of the 380,000 Soviet troops on East German soil. West Germany is a member of the Western NATO alliance, and the Allies have insisted a united Germany remain there. The Soviets have rejected that idea. East Germany has been the most strategically important member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, as the first line of defense against the West. The discussion paper notes that the so-called ``two-plus-four'' talks among the World War II victors and the Germanys are expected to be concluded by December and that the political treaty is conditional on the results of those talks. Other proposed articles of the political treaty declare that the five pre-war states that now comprise East Germany as well as the city of Berlin would be individual states under a united Germany. Proposed wording for a third article of the treaty says, ``Germans in both parts of Germany will form a united nation of people.'' Bonn wants to limit the political treaty to only those laws and regulations that differ between East and West Germany and that must be changed before political unification can be achieved. Issues which initially could be left unresolved include the countries' differing abortion laws, Schaeuble told West German reporters. In West Germany, a woman must prove medical necessity or financial hardship to have an abortion. In East Germany, abortions are free on demand in the first trimester of pregnancy. Schaeuble also suggested it was not absolutely necessary for political parties in both parts of Germany to have the same minimum election requirements in a joint election. In West Germany, political parties must receive at least 5 percent of the total vote for representation in parliament. There is no such limit in East Germany, and politicians there have been arguing for a limit lower than 5 percent so that their parties are not at such a disadvantage in a united German election. Schaeuble also told reporters Monday night that he wanted to have representatives of the European Economic Community observe the negotiations on a final unification treaty. In a related development, West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel, in East Berlin on Tuesday, said quick unification is important because of the unstable situation in the Soviet Union. Waigel, in an apparent reference to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's uncertain grip on events in his turbulent nation, said ``we need to go through the door to unification because it can close shut again.''

DOC.HEAD: Motorist Unaware That Horse Trailer Rolled Away
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Wert found his runaway horse without a hitch. Wert, of Elizabethtown, telephoned state police early Tuesday to report he had lost his horse and trailer while driving west on the Pennsylvania Turnpike. Wert said he did not realize the animal was missing until he got off the highway in this south-central Pennsylvania town. Troopers found the trailer and the unharmed horse almost seven miles back along the side of the road. The trailer had coasted to a stop along the shoulder of the westbound lane. A truck driver who saw the unhitching caught up to Wert at the exit and told him what happened.

DOC.HEAD: Concerns Raised Over Medicine Sent to Iranian Quake Victims
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Experts say some of the drugs sent to Soviet Armenia for victims of the 1988 earthquake were useless or even dangerous, and they say there could be similar problems with emergency supplies now being sent to Iran. Supplies sent to Armenia included pharmaceuticals that came from stocks of expired drugs and others of a type no longer sold, according to an article in The Lancet, a respected British medical journal. ``The quantities of expired and useless drugs are especially worrying,'' the June 9 issue said. ``The supply of massive amounts of drugs for the purpose of humanitarian aid still represents a good way of disposing of stocks of expired drugs or of those that are normally no longer marketable.'' The article was wriiten Dr. Philippe Autier, an epidemiologist and researcher in public health for the European Association for Health and Development. Also contributing to the article were members of Doctors Without Borders, a French humanitarian group, and the Soviet Armenian Ministry of Health. ``We know exactly the same problems are happening now in Iran,'' Autier said in a telephone interview Monday. Adam Kellett-Long, a spokesman for the British Red Cross, said his organization was sending its first shipment of drugs to Iran on Tuesday after receiving a list of needed medication and supplies. His organization only has sent drugs that are requested bu Iran. Iranian officials said more than 130 planes had arrived since Sunday carrying supplies and medicines. Unlike Armenia, Iran ``is much more controlled. The Iranian Red Crescent has been very strict on what it will accept. But of course there are a lot of other groups and countries involved which may not be taking the same care,'' said Kellet-Long. After the Armenian earthquake on Dec. 7, 1988, which killed 25,000 people, international relief agencies and governments rushed in 5,000 tons of drugs, consumable medical supplies and other equipment, the report said. Medical workers needed injectable painkillers like morphine, antibiotics, anesthetics, intravenous fluids, syringes and needles _ the same supplies now needed in Iran. A major quake killed in Iran on Thursday killed at least 50,000 people, according to officials. Drugs worth about $55 million were sent to Armenia, but only about 30 percent of them were available when they were most needed because they arrived unsorted and were impossible to identify, the Lancet report said. None of the boxes was labeled in Armenian and few in Russian, it said. In 24 warehouses in the Armenian capital of Yerevan, 238 kinds of antibiotics were labeled in 21 languages, it said. ``In Spitak, the most badly affected area, pharmacists wasted about two-thirds of their time merely looking for and identifying useful drugs among the relief parcels,'' the report said. Autier said experts know that only 30 to 40 types of medicines are commonly needed in most earthquake relief efforts. About 11 percent of the drugs were useless, including nasal spray and drugs for treating tropical diseases such as malaria, it said. Eight percent of the drugs had expired by the time they arrived, the report said. Some of these drugs, such as tetracycline, were potentially dangerous. For a year following the catastrophe, the Armenian ministry worked with Doctors Without Borders making an inventory of the drugs. By the end of their work, about 21 percent of the drugs were set to expire or already had expired.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia to Open Borders to Volunteers
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia will become the third newly democratic European country to accept U.S. Peace Corps volunteers, U.S. officials said Tuesday. Twenty-two specialists in English teacher training and English as a foreign language will leave for the Central European country later this year as the result of an agreement signed Monday in Prague by Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and Peace Corps Director Paul D. Coverdell, the agency said in a statement. Another 40 volunteers are expected to be sent by mid-1991, the statement said. Teams of English language-teaching specialists left earlier this month to start Peace Corps programs in Poland and Hungary, the first established in former communist-ruled countries. Other governments in the region have made contact about having Peace Corps units in their countries, said corps spokeswoman Paula Kuzmich. More than 6,100 Americans serve as Peace Corps volunteers in 72 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Source Says Trump Out of Woods For Now With $20 Million Loan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs, `The source...', to add no-comment from Trump spokesman. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Some 65...'.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's bankers have approved a 30-day, $20 million loan after agreeing in principle to a bigger long-term financial rescue for the cash-strapped developer, a source said today. An immediate $20 million cash infusion will enable Trump to make necessary bond payments while finishing touches are placed on a complex $65 million bailout, a participant in the negotiations said. The source, who spoke on condition that his name not be used, said it could take anywhere from 30 to 60 days to draw up the final documents on the financial package intended to shore up Trump's empire. A spokesman for Trump, Dan Klores, refused to comment on the report of a deal but said he hoped to have a statement later in the day. Some 65 to 70 banks and their attorneys are involved in the process. All but one bank agreed in principle to the deal. The German bank Dresdner Bank AG continued to balk but attorneys decided that Dresdner's endorsement wasn't essential. Dresdner, whose $15 million loan to Trump is secured by the first lien on the Trump Tower Fifth Avenue residential and commercial skyscraper, has been opposed to placing a second lien on the building. ``It was decided last night that Dresdner's holdout wouldn't prevent the deal from going forward,'' the source said. Trump faces a midnight deadline to cover principal and interest payments due on bonds sold to finance the Trump Castle hotel and casino in Atlantic City, N.J. The process of making those payments began today after seven key banks extended the $20 million bridge loan to Trump. Trump had missed a June 15 deadline for the casino bond payment but a 10-day grace period extended the time to tonight. A declaration of default could allow creditors to seize various Trump properties used as collateral to back the bonds and other loans, and could affect his licenses to run casinos in Atlantic City. Trump also is overdue on a $30 million bank loan payment to a group led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust. In spite of the German bank's continued reluctance to accept the bailout, it was considered possible that Dresdner might eventually agree to go in on the deal during the time it takes to complete the paperwork, the source said. The long-term $65 million bailout and debt restructuring package contains numerous stipulations, including a requirement that Trump sell assets to raise cash. The source involved in the negotiations said the agreement didn't specify which properties Trump must sell. Under the plan, the banks reportedly would extend Trump $65 million to meet any payments due and would suspend some payments on his $2 billion in bank loans in exchange for equity in some of his properties. The new loan package reportedly would contain tough restrictions on how much the freespending Trump could spend on charitable contributions and personal and household expenses. Some published reports earlier in the week had said that the tentative agreement limited his spending to $450,000 per month in the first year, less in subsequent years. The loan package also reportedly requires Trump to stick to a business plan, hire a chief financial officer, adopt a system of accounting controls and change accounting firms.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Drives On By Rally Held In His Honor
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela drove by his biggest open rally in the nation's capital Tuesday without stopping. The African National Congress leader had not been scheduled to address the several thousand people who gathered in downtown Washington, but rally organizers had hoped he would halt his motorcade when he saw the jubilant crowd and hundreds of balloons. ``I thought there was going to be a little more,'' said one young woman who waited in the hot sun to catch a glimpse of Mandela on his way from the U.S. Capitol. ``The man's tired,'' said another woman who had waited through several speeches by local politicians. The hastily arranged rally caused a rift between Mandela aides who saw the Washington stop as an important working visit and local activists who wanted to celebrate his presence in a city that is watching its mayor stand trial on drug charges. But Mandela's car and two-block motorcade pressed on down the same route taken by presidential inaugural motorcades and Mandela only waved from behind a closed window. Two white South African tourists, Ian and Karin Wood, joined the crowd on Pennsylvania Avenue. ``We're really anxious to see him. We've heard so much about him and he has such an aura,'' said Ian Wood. ``This brings us together,'' said Councilwoman Nadine Winter, who had pushed for the noontime celebration. ``It's something positive, something we can feel good about.'' Police had no immediate estimate on how many people had gathered at Freedom Plaza across from city hall or how many were lining the motorcade route, but there appeared to be several thousand along the streets who watched the brief parade. ``It was just a nice motorcade, not really a parade,'' said D.C. Police Lieutenant Reginald Smith. Winter organized the event after all 19,000 seats for in a tickets-only rally Tuesday night were sold.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats Close to Agreement on Fund to Save Ozone Layer
DOC.TEXT: Shut away in a small room on the banks of the Thames, a group of diplomats haggled Tuesday over an international accord to save the ozone layer. They met through the weekend and until late Tuesday, preparing for a meeting in November of environment ministers and other officials from nearly 100 countries. That meeting may for the first time impose an international ban on a group of chemicals that threatens the planet. The three-day ministerial conference also will consider a proposal to create an international fund to help developing countries pay the high price for technology that could help the ozone layer. Conference sources said the diplomats were close to agreement on such a fund, which the United States opposed until two weeks ago. In small working groups, they have been banging heads over how decisions will be made for the fund and over who will pay the estimated $2 billion to $7 billion bill to eliminate ozone-depleting chemicals. The fund would be a milestone in ``green diplomacy'' and could serve as a model for future accounts that will be needed to pay for solving other environmental problems, such as global warming. World leaders are set to debate global warming, a result of the so-called greenhouse effect, at a November conference in Geneva. ``Everyone is very tired,'' said one diplomat, speaking privately between meetings in a room at the International Maritime Organization. ``But what we are doing has never been done before, establishing an environmental agreement with money to back it up.'' The ministers' work, if successful, will extend and strengthen the Montreal Protocol of 1987, already considered an environmental watershed. Acting with unusual speed, 56 nations agreed in September 1987 to cut the use of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, in half by 1996. Last year, in the face of overwhelming scientific evidence on the effect of CFCs on the ozone layer, 81 nations decided in principle to ban them by the year 2000. In London, the ministers will debate whether to move up the ban to 1997 and at what speed to phase out the chemicals. The 12-nation European Community, along with Scandinavia, Australia and New Zealand, wants to move up the ban. The United States and Japan are opposed. The signatories to the Montreal Protocol also hope to persuade more developing nations to sign it _ especially India and China, which account for 40 percent of the world population and could be major CFC users. Both say they won't sign unless the rich nations help pay for the more expensive chemicals to replace CFCs. CFCs, used in aerosol sprays, refrigerators, foams and cleaning solvents, destroy ozone. Ozone is a gas thinly sprinkled through the stratosphere that filters out harmful ultraviolet rays. Scientists say that without ozone, life on Earth would die. Higher ultraviolet radiation damages the human immune system, causes skin cancer and cataracts, harms crops and disrupts sea life. The ministers are likely to agree to ban halons and carbon tetrachloride, in addition to CFCs, by the year 2000. Both are used in firefighting. Scientific studies overwhelmingly show the ozone layer will not be fully restored unless all the severely damaging chemicals are banned worldwide and some of the less harmful substitutes are strictly controlled. Environmentalists and conference observers say the stakes extend beyond the meeting. They say negotiations on ozone, which are backed by a strong international consensus, are a trial run for tougher battles looming over global warming.

DOC.HEAD: Just Don't Say No: Vatican Moves to Silence Open Dissent by Theologians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD that the document is expected to be criticized by liberal Catholics, INSERT graf after 3rd pvs, `To succumb...' Pickup 4th pvs, `The document...'
DOC.HEAD: By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican on Tuesday ruled out public dissent by theologians, striking at those challenging papal authority and the church's ban on birth control. Saying the church has suffered ``serious harm'' from open criticism, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith ordered theologians to uphold its moral teaching or keep quiet. ``To succumb to the temptation of dissent ... is to allow the leaven of infidelity to the Holy Spirit to start to work,'' the commission said in a 28-page document approved by Pope John Paul II. The document was expected to draw sharp criticism from liberal Catholics, who have charged that the Vatican is quietly extending the scope of church teachings treated as infallible, and displaying an authoritarian attitude. The document defended punishments meted out to dissidents in recent years and declared that adherence to church doctrine is not a matter of free speech. It also affirmed the right of the church to speak out on issues of sexual morality, rejecting the idea that its voice should be limited to economic and social issues. West German Cardinal Josef Ratzinger, the head of the congregation and the pope's main guardian of orthodoxy, told a news conference the document was a response to a ``climate of conflict'' fomented by dissident theologians. These include a group of 170 German-speaking theology professors from four countries who publicly criticized the pope last year. Their statement, known as the Cologne Declaration, attacked John Paul for his opposition to artificial birth control and his use of authority, particularly his choice of conservative bishops. Ratzinger said preparation of his ``Instruction on The Ecclesial Vocation of The Theologian'' began before the Cologne Declaration. But he said the German protest was an expression of the same tensions that prompted the writing of his document. Ratzinger rejected dissent as a legitimate form of expression, describing it instead as a political ploy for power in the church. During the pope's 11{-year papacy, several theologians have een punished for straying from church positions. They include the Rev. Hans Kung of Switzerland, who was stripped of his right to teach theology in 1979, and the Rev. Charles E. Curran, barred from teaching at Catholic University in Washington D.C. in 1987. The Vatican document acknowledged theologians might in some cases question ``the timeliness, the form, or even the contents'' of some church teaching. In that event, they should try to resolve the differences in dialogue with bishops, it said. ``In cases like these, the theologian should avoid turning to the mass media ... for it is not by seeking to exert the pressure of public opinion that one contributes to the clarification of doctrinal issues and renders service to the truth.'' If the theologian still cannot accept the teaching, he should keep his objections to himself, the document said. ``Such a situation can certainly prove a difficult trial,'' it said. ``It can be a call to suffer for the truth, in silence and prayer, but with the certainty, that if the truth really is at stake, it will ultimately prevail.'' Asked whether theologians could publish books or articles espousing dissident views, Ratzinger said they should take their case to the ``competent forum'' in the church. Stressing the collaboration between theology and official church teaching, the document noted theologians take an oath of fidelity binding them to present doctrine ``in its integrity and with full accuracy.'' ``The theologian who is not disposed to think with the church contradicts the commitment he freely and knowingly accepted to teach in the name of the church,'' it said. The document stressed theologians must adhere not only to infallible pronouncements or documents. Infallibility means freedom from error in matters of faith and morals and is rarely applied. It paraphrased from Humanae Vitae, Pope Paul VI's 1968 encyclical reaffirming the church ban on contraception, saying church doctrine ``also extends to that which concerns the natural law.'' Ratzinger's report said the church cannot be run like a democracy, a position voiced by the pope on several occasions. ``Standards of conduct, appropriate to civil society or the workings of a democracy, cannot be purely and simply applied to the church,'' it said. In the news conference, Ratzinger rejected the idea the church is ``a last bastion of an outdated authoritarianism.''

DOC.HEAD: CBS to Launch Search for Lucy and Desi Lookalikes
DOC.TEXT: Luci and Desi wannabees here's your chance. CBS says it's beginning a national search for an actor and actress to play the late comedians in a TV movie about the stars of ``I Love Lucy.'' The movie will be called ``Lucy & Desi: Before the Laughter.'' It will dramatize the relationship of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz from the time they met in 1940 until just after the premiere of their series on CBS in 1951. CBS said Tuesday it would hold open auditions for the title roles on July 16 in Los Angeles, in Miami on July 18, and in New York on July 20. ``In addition to a possible reading, prospective actors should be prepared to perform a favorite Luci or Desi routine from `I Love Lucy,' no longer than one minute in length, for the auditions,'' CBS said. Ball, who outlived Arnaz, died last year at age 77.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Announces Plans for Saving Spotted Owl
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with announcemnt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today announced partial plans for protecting the rare northern spotted owl at the cost of at least 1,000 logging jobs in the Northwest. But for the second time in less than a week, officials delayed issuing a complete blueprint designed to save the bird without devastating the region's timber industry. ``The admininstration is deeply concerned both about endangered speies and the livelihood of families in the Pacific Northwest who depend on timber production,'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. Yeutter and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. appeared at a news conference to discuss their plans to save the estimated 6,000 owls, which were declared a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act last week. MORE

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Laurance S. Rockefeller has given Princeton University $21 million to create a center for the study and teaching of human values, the university announced Tuesday. The new Center for Human Values is expected to offer undergraduate courses and graduate seminars in areas such as religion, culture and morality; ethics and international politics; moral education and development; and philosophy and public affairs. The 80-year-old philanthropist and conservationist is a 1932 Princeton graduate. Rockefeller's undergraduate thesis was ``The Concept of Value _ and its relation to Ethics.'' The grant will fund six new faculty positions, visiting professorships, research, public conferences, fellowships, the development of courses and a $1 million addition to the building housing the program, said university spokeswoman Jackie Savani.

Paul Mellon, a member of one of the families that founded Carnegie Mellon University, has given $5 million to the school, officials said Tuesday. Mellon's gift will be used toward the construction of a campus performing arts center. The center is expected to cost $10 million. ``A vibrant performing arts center will enhance Carnegie Mellon's strength in arts education and the university's role as one of Pittsburgh's great cultural resources,'' Mellon said in a statement. Mellon made his donation as part of a five-year campaign he started in 1986 with a $10 million gift. The campaign exceeded its $200 million goal by $4 million with Mellon's latest gift, officials said. Mellon, who was raised in Pittsburgh but now lives in Virginia, is an honorary trustee of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. He retired as chairman and trustee of the National Gallery in 1985.

Actor James Caan will marry a woman raised in the same New York City neighborhood where he grew up two decades earlier, his publicist said. Caan, 49, and Ingrid Hajek, 29, announced their engagement Tuesday and said they plan to marry later this year, said spokesman Paul Bloch. ``They grew up a few blocks apart in Sunnyside, New York, and went to the same public school, P.S. 150,'' said Bloch. ``However, they only met two years ago when they were introduced by mutual friends.'' It will be Miss Hajek's second marriage and Caan's third, Bloch said. Caan, who was nominated for an Academy Award for his role in ``The Godfather'' and an Emmy for ``Brian's Song,'' has two children, Scott, 13, who lives with the actor in Los Angeles, and daughter Tara. Caan just completed filming the movie ``Misery,'' based on a Steven King novel. Bloch said he didn't know Miss Hajek's occupation.

Screenplay writer Joe Eszterhas commanded a record $3 million price for his latest film script. Carolco Pictures outbid at least 10 studios to buy ``Basic Instinct,'' a steamy thriller about a policeman and a writer-psychologist. The $3 million is a record for a ``spec'' screenplay, which is written before going up for bids by the studios, rather than written under contract. ``I've always felt that the script was at the heart of the movie,'' Eszterhas said. ``If you're going to pay actors and directors, there's nothing wrong with paying the writer, too.'' Eszterhas, who wrote the screenplays for ``Jagged Edge,'' ``Betrayed'' and ``The Music Box,'' generally commands more than $1 million for a movie script. ``We bought a great project,'' Thomas Levine, Carolco vice president for corporate development, said Monday.

Stormie Jones, who made medical history in 1984 when she became the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, was in fair condition Tuesday at a hospital where she is undergoing tests. Doctors at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh have been evaluating the girl for several days. Stormie flew to Pittsburgh from the Fort Worth suburb of White Settlement, Texas, on Saturday night. Doctors were concerned she might be rejecting a second liver she received earlier this year. The 13-year-old reportedly has been experiencing fatigue and a change in her liver enzyme levels. She suffered a mild episode of liver rejection last month and went to Pittsburgh for tests. Doctors adjusted her anti-rejection medication.

Ze'ev Chafets, a former Israeli government spokesman and native of Michigan, has written a book about Detroit that depicts it as the nation's first Third World city. ``Devil's Night and Other True Tales of Detroit,'' to be published by Random House this fall, says Detroit has a black leadership that sees itself engaged in a struggle with a white-dominated world. Chafets, 43, was born in nearby Pontiac. After emigrating to Israel in 1969, he spent five years in the Israeli army and became a government spokesman under then-Prime Minister Menachem Begin. The idea for the book came when he watched Devil's Night arson during a return visit to the Detroit area, Chafets said. Chafets, author of three other books, describes the racial polarization in metropolitan Detroit between the majority black central city of 1 million people and the suburbs, whose 3.2 million residents are overwhelmingly white. ``The city and suburbs are separated by a cultural and emotional gap as wide as any that divides hostile nations,'' he writes.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Tells Group to Stop Using Anti-NEA Pamphlet
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge says the Rev. Donald Wildmon must stop using a pamphlet to support his group's anti-pornography campaign because it misrepresents the artist's work and may harm the artist's reputation. The judge, however, said Wildmon's Tupelo, Miss.-based American Family Association could use the pamphlets if it makes it clear the pictures being used were only fragments and not the artist's entire work. The case was brought to U.S. District Court in Manhattan after East Village artist David Wojnarowicz learned the organization was distributing pamphlets with pieces of his work taken from much larger collages. One picture, taken from a multilayered work, shows Christ with a hypodermic needle in his arm. Wildmon's group mailed out about 6,000 pamphlets to members of Congress, clergy and media outlets to bolster its view that the National Endowment for the Arts supports pornography. The NEA gave the Illinois State University galleries a $15,000 grant, which they used to hold a Wojnarowicz retrospective last winter and publish a catalogue containing his work. After viewing Wojnarowicz's work, Wildmon said, ``I kind of got sick to my stomach.'' He testified at a one-day trial that he was ``angry and upset because tax dollars went to help pay for some of this.'' Wojnarowicz claimed the pamphlet was a gross distortion of his work and filed a $1 million damage lawsuit, charging the pamphlet violated copyright laws. Judge William C. Conner on Monday agreed in part with Wojnarowicz and issued a temporary injunction saying the AFA could not use the pamphlet as it was. ``The pamphlet could be construed by reasonable persons as misrepresenting the work of the artist, with bringing harm to the artist's reputation and to the value of his works,'' the judge said. Wildmon's attorney, Benjamin W. Bull, objected to the ruling. He said the pamphlet was protected by the First Amendment's freedom of speech. The judge said the pamphlet could be used if it contained a clarifying statement. Conner said he would rule next month on the monetary and copyright infringement complaints. Wildmon and his group have for years led the conservative campaigns against films, music, television shows, magazines and art that they deem obscene. ``I consider this to be a vindication of sorts,'' the artist said after the judge issued Monday's ruling. ``I didn't know Mr. Wojnarowicz personally and had no knowledge of him,'' Wildmon said outside court. ``The whole thing we have done is try to address the issue of government support of this kind of art. I had no malice toward Mr. Wojnarowicz.''

DOC.HEAD: Train Derails, Injuring 15
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with 30 wounded. Pick up 4th pvs, `Orbetello is...'
DOC.TEXT: A train derailed in central Italy on Tuesday near a posh seaside resort, and 30 passengers were reported injured, police said. The train was heading from Alessandria in northern Italy to Rome when the accident occurred Tuesday afternoon. The train derailed as it entered the Orbetello station. Thirty people were taken to a hospital in Orbetello with minor injuries, police said. Orbetello is 90 miles north of Rome and near the Argentario peninsula, which is dotted with elegant villas and beaches. The train track was closed for several hours following the accident. Police said they were investigating the cause.

DOC.HEAD: Minorities Mark Milestone in NYC Resident Labor Force
DOC.TEXT: Minorities for the first time make up more than half the city's resident labor force, a milestone that raises stark challenges for New York's social and economic future, researchers said Tuesday. ``It's a historic moment in the life of the city: Minorities have become the majority of New Yorkers in the labor market,'' said Samuel Ehrenhalt, regional chief of the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Ehrenhalt, who reported the trend, said it will increase pressure on the city to better educate black and Hispanic youths. Other researchers said it will gradually force employers to open management jobs to minorities. ``It's a signpost on a difficult path of necessary change,'' said John Mollenkopf, a political scientist at the Graduate Center of City University. ``It points to a future that we all have to recognize and embrace.'' The labor bureau reached its conclusion after analyzing its monthly employment surveys for 1989. It found that non-Hispanic whites made up 49.7 percent of the resident labor force, under half for the first time. Out-of-town residents who work in the city _ mainly whites _ were not included in the analysis. Demographers say the city's population has been less than half white since the early or mid-1980s; it now is estimated at about 47 percent. But never before has the labor force _ residents ages 16 or older who are working or looking for work _ reached that point. Ehrenhalt said the arrival of black, Hispanic and Asian immigrants is the prime reason for the trend. The white population is about stable, and the number of native-born blacks and Hispanics has grown only slowly. ``Immigrants are playing a bigger role in New York City than they have at any time in the past three-quarters of a century,'' Ehrenhalt said. He said the trend will continue as the white population ages and leaves the workforce. ``That underscores the need to encourage a more rapid and purposeful move of minorities into the educational and occupational mainstream,'' Ehrenhalt said. ``The city economy will need them as never before.'' Lack of a high-school education is higher among minorities than among white residents, Ehrenhalt noted. And minority unemployment remains far higher _ 9.6 percent in 1989, compared with 4.1 percent for whites. Education is not the only issue. Mollenkopf said the trend increases the demands on employers to open fuller job opportunities to minority workers. Now minorities often hold lower-paying clerical jobs while senior management is virtually all white, he said. The labor bureau's figures supported the point: While 36 percent of working whites held managerial, professional and technical jobs, that fell to 24 percent of blacks and 15 percent of Hispanics. And Hispanic workers were concentrated in the declining manufacturing sector, largely in semiskilled and unskilled jobs. The city's strength is in service jobs, said Mollenkopf, ``and the higher echelons of these service firms are still basically all white. They have to come to grips with the fact that the city's labor force is multiracial. They put themselves at a disadvantage if they resist that.''

DOC.HEAD: NOW Panel Aimed at Giving Women, Minorities, Young More Political Clout
DOC.TEXT: The National Organization for Women said Tuesday the U.S. political process is unresponsive to women, minorities and young people, and named a panel of prominent Americans to help improve it. ``We have many, many obstacles to overcome,'' said NOW President Molly Yard. ``There are many groups that agree ... that it's time to take another look at our democracy.'' Yard said there were too few women, minority or young officeholders, and politicians now in power aren't addressing the concerns of those groups. The Commission for Responsive Democracy stems from a resolution adopted last year at the National NOW Conference. It created a stir because it was interpreted as a call for a third political party. Yard said Tuesday that a third party was only one option to be considered at six regional hearings by the commission, which includes two past third-party presidential candidates. ``We intend to be open-minded,'' she said. ``Our conclusions will depend upon what we hear. The whole history of third parties has clearly been important in the development of American political life.'' She said the Republican Party descended from a third party; George Wallace's third-party presidential bid forced both major parties to the right; and the National Woman's Party at the beginning of the century is cited by some as the reason women won the right to vote. Asked about the reaction of the Democratic and Republican parties to the commission, Yard said she hoped they would testify and welcome whatever recommendations the panel develops. ``Surely no political leader in this country believes we have a perfect system,'' she said. ``If they do, they're like Rip van Winkle and haven't waked up from their sleep yet.'' Yard cited the difficulty of raising money and defeating incumbents as two major problems for women and minorities. She said low voter turnout was a sign that people are unhappy with political leadership on issues ranging form defense and the environment to social welfare programs and the savings and loan bailout. In addition to the third-party option, the NOW commission is expected to examine proposals such as setting up a shadow cabinet; eliminating political action committees; public financing of elections; reforms in the use of television during campaigns; and mail and same-day registration of voters. The commission is scheduled to report its recommendations at NOW's 1991 convention next summer. Among the panel members are: Rose Bird, former chief justice of the California Supreme Court; former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark; former New Mexico Gov. Toney Anaya; former presidential candidates John Anderson and Barry Commoner; essayist Barbara Ehrenreich and poet Robin Morgan; and retired Rear Adm. Gene La Rocque, director of the Center for Defense Information.

DOC.HEAD: Checking Fees Up 28 Percent in Seven Years, Consumer Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Checking fees have jumped 28 percent in seven years, with the typical holder of a regular account paying $108 a year, according to a consumer group survey released Tuesday. The Consumer Federation of America said fees on regular, non-interest checking accounts averaged $107.96, while fees on interest-paying NOW accounts averaged $111.39. Compared with a similar survey in 1988, regular checking account fees are up 6.7 percent, while NOW account fees rose 6.4 percent. Compared with the group's first survey in 1983, regular fees are 28 percent higher and NOW fees 62.3 percent greater. The consumer group collected information in March from 170 banks and savings institutions in 16 states and the District of Columbia. Comparisons between 1990 and 1988, however, are based only on the 111 institutions included in both surveys. The non-profit group, representing 240 consumer organizations around the country, is using the survey results in its push for legislation requiring banks to cash government checks for non-customers and to provide low-fee accounts to the poor and the elderly. Sen. Henry Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, is trying to attach a provision requiring check-cashing to housing legislation pending on the Senate floor. The House and Senate banking committees are considering truth-in-savings bills that would require financial institutions to disclose fee and interest rate information in a uniform manner. Bankers are fighting government-imposed low-fee accounts, arguing that there is more than enough competition among banks to keep fees reasonable. ``Banks are businesses, not public utilities, and their prices reflect their costs of doing business with a margin for profit,'' the American Bankers Association said in a statement. The bankers' group said 59 percent of 856 banks surveyed last year offered special low-fee accounts for basic checking service. Ken McEldowney, executive director of Consumer Action, a San Francisco group, said banks are competing for wealthier customers by offering high interest rates on certificates of deposit. To offset the high rates, banks are raising fees on smaller accounts, he said. ``In a sense, low- and middle-income consumers are a captive audience,'' McEldowney said. According to the survey, a typical NOW account customer needed an average balance of $1,180 or a minimum balance of $600 to avoid fees. In calculating average fees, the consumer group assumed that the typical account had an average balance of $400, falling to $200 once a month. It assumed 10 checks, four withdrawals from automatic teller machines and two deposits a month, as well as two bounced checks and one returned deposit per year. Monthly fees averaged $5.11 for regular checking accounts and $5.96 for NOW accounts. Per-check fees averaged 27 cents for regular accounts and 26 cents for NOW accounts. Bounced check fees averaged $15 and returned deposits $4.85. The average interest paid on NOW accounts was 4.97 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth-graders Save Frogs, Win Award
DOC.TEXT: The plight of frogs wounded in a debris-clogged creek prompted a group of fourth-graders to spring into action, cleaning the stream and performing first aid on the amphibians. Then they wrote a 36-page report on the incident, earning a presidential ``Award for Excellence'' certificate and qualifying for a national competition run by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. ``They were very excited. They really felt that they made some mark,'' said Thomas J. Kennedy, science teacher to the six boys who wrote ``Let the Frogs Leap Again,'' chronicling their clean up. Ten-year-old Daniel Doerpholz, one of the first to get involved, said he and a friend from Mosier Elementary School had played in the creek behind their house for some time when they noticed last fall that the frogs were dying. ``They were getting cut up on everything. They were dying from all the pollution,'' he said Tuesday. The boys tried some first aid on frogs cut by rusted pipes and broken glass and put tags around the rescued frogs to keep track of them. Daniel and his friend, Phillip Bernier, began hauling trash out of the creek and then learned from Kennedy that they could turn their after-school hobby into an entry for the EPA competition. ``In relation to cleaning up they did that on their Saturdays and after school. They stayed after school with me sometimes for two hours and they sat there and we brainstormed,'' Kennedy said. The two boys called on four other friends and they came up with some solutions to the problem of trash in the stream. One solution was to wrap a plastic grid over a pipe, allowing water to flow through while trapping trash. Some untested ideas detailed in the report included using hamsters to power a water wheel to stir up the water, lifting trash to the top, and rigging a pulley system to lift the trash away off the surface. Their efforts were rewarded with the award certificates and entry into the national competition, the Presidential Youth Environment Awards, which will be judged later this year, said Evelyn Sullivan of the EPA's Boston office. ``If (projects) are worthwhile, then I encourage them to enter the national competition (and) that's pretty much what I did,'' she said. Daniel's mother, Sue Doerpholz, said she didn't realize how serious the children were until she saw the report this spring. ``I knew that he and his buddy Phillip would go down there and I thought they were just goofing off. Then he came home one day with all this paperwork,'' she said. Kennedy said he's proud of his students. ``I have three college degrees but the brightest people I've ever seen in relation to new ideas is 9- and 10-year-olds who really have some great ideas,'' Kennedy said.

DOC.HEAD: Relief Operation Bogs Down in Political Dispute
LaserPhotos TOK4,XTEH1
DOC.TEXT: Iran's fractious leaders turned a relief operation for victims of a catastrophic earthquake into a political dispute Tuesday, with Parliament insisting the West cannot buy forgiveness with humanitarian aid. In northwestern provinces, weary rescuers dug through the remnants of 342 cities, towns and villages demolished in Thursday's temblor.
