Another quake measuring 4.9 on the Richter scale shook southeastern Iran on Tuesday but caused no casualties or damage, Tehran University's Geophysics Center reported. Officials have said 50,000 people were killed, 200,000 were injured and 500,000 others lost their homes on Thursday, when a quake measure 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale hit Iran. Many of the reported 360 aftershocks have hampered rescue operations. Interior Minister Abdullah Nouri, who supervised relief operations, told a news conference that an accurate casualty count was not yet possible. He said 99 percent of the bodies have been recovered in round-the-clock operations by local rescuers, backed by foreign relief teams and sniffer dogs. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said 171 planeloads of relief supplies had arrived by Tuesday from more than 26 countries, including some of Iran's bitterest foes. Nouri, a middle-ranking cleric in President Hashemi Rafsanjani's political camp, thanked all those who sent relief teams and aid and said: ``If new relief teams are willing to come to Iran on humanitarian grounds, they are welcome.'' Nouri, like Rafsanjani, is considered a pragmatist who favors improved ties with the West. But in Parliament, hard-line deputies said the aid will not buy closer relations with the West or nullify positions taken by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Those stands include the February 1989 death threat to British author Salman Rushdie for offending some Moslems in his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' One deputy, Ayatollah Saddegh Khalkhali, said quake aid from the United States, Iraq and Saudi Arabia was appreciated but Iran ``could not forget our martyrs.'' ``We cannot forgive the killing of 300 people on the Airbus or the 400 at Mecca,'' the high-ranking cleric said. He was referring to the U.S. downing in July 1989 of an Iranian jetliner that killed all 290 aboard. The Navy said the jetliner was mistaken for a warplane. More than 400 Moslem pilgrims, most of them Iranians, died when Saudi troops opened fire on a demonstration in Mecca in July 1987. House Speaker Hojatoleslam Mahdi Karrubi told Parliament: ``The dispute between the Islamic Republic and Saudi Arabia is a rooted and fundamental quarrel between American-style Islam and the genuine Islam of prophet Mohammed. ``There is no compromise in this dispute.'' His deputy, Hossein Hashemia said: ``We hate having relations with those countries because what those countries did to our nation was worse than the earthquake.'' The Parliament, known for its fierce opposition to ties with the West, is struggling with Rafsanjani's pragmatists, who advocate closer ties to help Iran recover from its eight-year war with Iraq. Western diplomats said the aid gives Rafsanjani's faction a means of pushing the opening with the West. If opponents argued too loudly, they would seem to be opposing the policy of getting as much aid as possible to the victims, one Western diplomat said. In earthquake-devastated Gilan province, provincial police chief Gholamreza Gohari said the people were satisfied with the aid and it would improve Iran's links to the West. But one customs inspector, examining a pen offered by a visiting America, growled: ``We don't need a pen. Just give us back our assets,'' referring to billions held in U.S. banks since the 1979 seizure of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. Editorials in Iran's leading newspapers this week on the aid highlighted the split in attitudes. Jomhuri Islami, the main publication of the radicals, on Sunday wrote: ``Our people, even under the rubble, chant `Death to America' and demand the almighty God to curtail the U.S. plans...even those hands stretched to help.'' Another paper noted Sunday that the $1 million or $2 million in U.S. aid was far lower than the salary paid to actor Sylvestor Stallone for the movie ``Rambo.'' But the English-language Kayhan International on Tuesday called it ``very selfish of a newspaper man to sit in his air-conditioned office in Tehran with his family intact to ask quake survivors to say, `Down with America.''' Also Tuesday, the Agriculture Ministry announced that it would take over the harvest of the area's rice and tea crop, threatened because so many farmers died in the quake.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Admits Problem Paying Bills; Seeks Western Credits
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is having trouble paying $2 billion in foreign bills and needs more Western credits to help make the transition to a market economy, a government spokesman said Tuesday. ``If we have credits, it will be easier for us to have economic reform,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov told reporters. ``We're experiencing come commercial difficulties now,'' Gerasimov said. ``Our perfectly immaculate record on the external market of always paying our debts is now under question.'' He quoted the Soviet State Bank president, Viktor Gerashchenko, as saying the Soviet Union has a current accounts deficit _ the difference between cash on hand and outstanding bills _ of $2 billion. This is due to several factors, including the disruption involved in the transition from central planning to a market economy, he said. European Community leaders meeting in Dublin this week agreed to have the community's executive commission undertake a study of Moscow's needs, but they refused to grant immediate aid to the Soviets. Gerasimov said the Soviet Union needs more Western economic credits like the $3.1 billion West German bank credit backed by West Germany at the Dublin meeting. The Soviet Union's economic potential should be sufficient collateral to guarantee repayment of large-scale economic credits, he said. ``It's not aid, it's credit,'' he said. ``This credit must be returned, must be paid back with interest.'' ``To pay them back with interest, we must work harder, so it's just a kind of input to our perestroika,'' he said, referring to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of economic reform. There are no detailed plans to implement large infusions of foreign credits, Gerasimov said. The lack of such a plan ``is a little bit of danger,'' but it is premature to worry about it now, he said. According to the Soviet business weekly Commersant, deliveries from foreign firms worth up to $500 million have gone unpaid since October 1989. Similar debts have been run up before, but they were always taken care of by credits from the Foreign Economic Bank, it said. Many foreign companies have been giving their Soviet partners more time to make good on their debts. A Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Soviet current account debt has been steadily growing as imports continue to surpass exports. A $2 billion debt is not surprisingly large to economists familiar with the Soviet economy, he said. The total Soviet foreign debt is thought to be about $3 billion. Some estimates have run as high as $8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Government Imposes Curfew To Stop Rioting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT that 15 people have died in two days of rioting sted 11; pickup 5th graf pvs, `University students...'
DOC.TEXT: The government put the capital under curfew Tuesday in an effort to stop looting and anti-government rioting that doctors said had killed 15 people and injured 149. President Kenneth Kaunda cut short a 10-day vacation at his private lodge at Mfuwe, 375 miles east of Lusaka, and met most of the day with Defense and Security Minister Alex Shapi and political colleagues. The rioting began Monday one week after the government more than doubled the price of corn meal, Zambia's staple food. The increase was recommended by financial agencies and donor nations as part of a plan to salvage the economy of Zambia, one of Africa's poorest nations. Police opened fire on hundreds of stone-throwing protesters Monday. Doctors at the main University Teaching Hospital said four people died Monday and 11 Tuesday after suffering gunshot wounds and other unspecified injuries. University students who led the demonstrations said up to 30 students had been detained. The state-run Zambia Daily Mail reported that more than 100 people were being held at police stations in Lusaka. Early Tuesday, army helicopters flew low over the Zambia University campus and key trouble spots nearby. Student leaders meeting at the campus said they would continue to protest. The students jeered police and chanted ``Kaunda must go!'' ``Castrate Kaunda!'' and ``Long live multiparty!'' Students said police opened fire to scatter protesters, injuring at least one person. State radio announced the 6 p.m.-to-6 a.m. curfew late Tuesday and said anyone who ignored it would be arrested. Sporadic gunfire was heard in Lusaka most of the day as police and troops battled to stop the protests and widespread looting in the city of more than 800,000. The U.S. Embassy was closed and British officials and U.N. agencies advised their nationals and employees to stay home. Three suburban police stations were reportedly attacked and set afire by rioters who also looted food stores and a post office east of the city center. Store owners in upper-income suburbs said goods worth millions of dollars were stolen when impoverished workers joined rampaging protesters. Troops sealed off the city center and most suburban shops, and gas stations were closed. Children who arrived at schools were immediately sent home. But rioters hurled stones at police and civilian vehicles, and Lusaka residents said gunfire could be heard in several districts throughout the day. In the first official comment on the unrest, hospital authorities said three civilians, including a 3-year-old girl, died from gunshot wounds Monday and that 41 people were injured. One policeman, identified only as Constable Siwanza, also died Monday after being stoned by angry mobs during a police search of homes in the eastern suburb of Kalingalinga, police spokeman Andrew Kaitisha said. He gave no details of other police casualties. In Monday's rioting, students burned flags, denounced the corn meal price increases, from 2.79 per 55-pound bag to $6.56 a bag, and demanded an end to nearly two decades of one-party rule headed by Kaunda. Earlier this year, Kaunda promised to hold a referendum on the future of Zambia's one-party system but no date has been set for the vote. Price increases in 1986 also led to violent clashes between troops and rioters that left 15 people dead.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Announces Plans for Saving Spotted Owl
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 10-11: ``That panel,'' further production estimates
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today announced partial plans for protecting the rare northern spotted owl at the cost of at least 1,000 logging jobs in the Northwest. But for the second time in less than a week, officials delayed issuing a complete blueprint designed to save the bird without devastating the region's timber industry. ``The admininstration is deeply concerned both about endangered speies and the livelihood of families in the Pacific Northwest who depend on timber production,'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. Yeutter and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. appeared at a news conference to discuss their plans to save the estimated 6,000 owls, which were declared a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act last week. Lujan and Yeutter said the Bureau of Land Management will implement a plan that will result in the loss of 1,000 jobs due to reduce timber harvests on BLM lands in Oregon and northern California. But they called for formation of a government committee to come up with a specific plan to protect the owl on Forest Service land. ``Today we have set into motion a process to balance our responsibility in preserving the owl and forests while protecting the economic lives of American men and women who live and work in the region,'' he said. An earlier proposal by government scientists would have resulted in the loss of 7,600 jobs as a result of reductions in BLM harvests and the loss of another 20,000 jobs by the end of the decade as a result of reductions in Forest Service harvests. Lujan said the BLM proposal will protect 125 more pairs of owls than would the proposal offered by the government scientists, led by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas. That panel would have taken about 3 million acres out of production, some 2.5 million of that from the Forest Service. Lujan and Yeutter had no acreage estimates today. Lujan said annual BLM harvests in the region would drop from 950 million board feet to about 750 million compared with the 500 million envisioned under the recommendations of the scientific panel. The Forest Service will operate under existing forest plans until the new timber task force can come up with an interim conservation proposal for the owl. Under the earlier recommendations of the government scientists, harvests in the region would have been cut back to between 2.3 billion and 2.5 billion board feet. The Fish and Wildlife Service last Friday announced its decision to classify the owl as a threatened species entitled to protection under the Endangered Species Act, the same law that has protected the grizzly bear and bald eagle. Members of Congress expressed fears that environmentalists would go to court to halt logging if they were dissatisfied with the administration's recommendations. Other lawmakers said Congress ultimately would try to write its own protection plan, possibly embracing greater environmental protection and less concern for the timber industry. Biologists say each nesting pair of owls needs a large tract of undisturbed old-growth forest. Estimates of the owl population range from 3,000 to 5,000 pairs. A government scientific panel proposed in April to give the owl protection throughout its range of Oregon, Washington and northern California. Its recommendations would take more than 3 million acres of previously unprotected national forests out of production, cut federal harvests in the Northwest nearly in half and result in the estimated loss of more than 28,000 jobs by the end of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Won't Stop Jailing of Reporter Over Sources
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Tuesday refused to block the jailing of a television reporter who refused to disclose his sources in a murder story. KMOL-TV reporter Brian Karem said he would probably surrender Wednesday afternoon to begin serving a six-month contempt of court sentence. State District Judge Pat Priest issued the sentence in February when Karem refused to surrender notes containing the names of confidential sources. The sources had arranged a jailhouse telephone interview with two murder defendants for him. Priest also fined him $500. Karem appealed in U.S. District Court, and last week Judge H.F. Garcia ruled against him and ordered him to give the notes to defense and prosecution lawyers. Garcia also refused to delay the jail sentence while Karem appealed. An arrest warrant was issued Monday. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Tuesday also refused to delay the sentence while an appeal is pending. ``It bothers me very deeply,'' Karem said Tuesday. ``Just the way the First Amendment has been trampled on ... really bothers me.'' The sources named in the notes, Karem said, helped him obtain a jailhouse interview with Henry David Hernandez, 25, who is accused with his brother, Julian, of killing San Antonio Police officer Gary Lee Williams. In the interview, Hernandez said he shot the officer last March in self-defense. Lawyers say they must have the identity of Karem's sources in order to give the brothers a fair trial. They are scheduled to stand trial in November.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter's Notebook: Building Shells Stand in Testiment to Iran's Disaster
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many buildings stand roofless, and some roofs hang with little beneath. The three-story community health center in this earthquake-stricken city was reduced to a steel frame _ the brick between the steel crumbled with each jolt. A ceiling fan, still suspended from a fragment of the former structure, circles crazily in the open air, driven by the wind. Electricity has been cut off. At another home, a single wall fell, revealing an interior and furniture like a doll house. A house with blue-framed windows was rocked back on its foundations so that its second-floor balcony faces the sky. Some homes just have huge cracks on the walls and glass broken out of windows. Others have huge holes in the walls where bricks fell out. People inside their homes were in the greatest danger of being buried, but people outside ran the risk of being hurt or killed by stone from falling buildings or landslides cascading down steep mountains above some of the towns. Earthquakes travel as waves through the soil and rock, and buildings unable to move with the ground crumble as the tremors become intense. Most of the Iranian buildings destroyed on Thursday were one- or two-story homes built of brick or unreinforced concrete. The nearby town of Manjil is virtually a field of rubble. Bricks and stones that were houses scattered in all directions. In Rudbar, on the banks of the Sefid River, most buildings were destroyed and those that survived were seriously damaged. Step three feet up from the curb that used to be in front of People's Store, and you will find yourself on its tar roof.

Life in this mountain city 180 miles northwest of Tehran has moved onto the street, since houses are no longer safe. Large military tents have been set up. Some people sleep in smaller tents or under plastic sheeting tied to trees or iron fences. Even some buses parked near the river are being used for temporary shelter. Along with the electricity, water has been cut off. The only supply of running water is a three-inch pipe bent over a basin next to a bridge. A woman in a black chador washes a white bowl and pan with a bar of pink soap. Most people, exhausted from days of digging for missing relatives and from the loss of loved ones, sit, stand or wander aimlessly. Some pick through piles of relief clothing and blankets piled in a storefront.

An empty makeshift hospital run by the Iranian Red Crescent Society remains under a grove of trees on the riverbank. The seriously injured patients have been flown to hospitals in Tehran and Rasht. People with minor injuries are treated in full view of passers-by at impromptu clinics set up on Rudabr's main street. At one clinic, a doctor cleans a scalp wound of an old man who has been given only the token privacy of a white bed sheet tied chest-high to two green posts. Nearby, two paramedics stitch up the hand of a man as he lies on a tree-shaded bench beside the destroyed public clinic.

Abu Talab Musavi, a 30-year-old lawyer, won't be able to get back into his office. The building is a crumpled mess. He has climbed up rubble to the second floor and is reaching through a hole in the wall to throw what he can reach _ a couple of cushions and some cloth _ to his brother below. As he moves, rubble and broken plaster slide down, revealing the edge of a beautiful red Persian carpet.

DOC.HEAD: Administration May Send A Second Relief Plane
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is willing to send a second plane load of relief supplies to earthquake victims in Iran and is waiting to hear what is needed, U.S. officials said Tuesday. Meanwhile, a private group of Iranian expatriates plans to fly to Tehran on Saturday. Among them are doctors, nurses and engineers. The first load of U.S. supplies was airlifted from Pisa, Italy, to Iran last Sunday. The plane, chartered for $66,000 by the Red Cross under a U.S. grant, carried $225,000 worth of blankets, tents, water jugs and search-and-rescue equipment. The plane picked up the equipment at Leghorn, Italy, one of five major relief depots maintained by the United States around the world. The U.S. relief operation is being conducted under rules specified by Iran. While accepting help, it insists the aid be channeled through the Red Cross or other private relief organizations. While authorities said they would not accept aid form Israel or South Africa, Kamal Kharrazi, the Iranian ambassador to the United Nations, said Monday that ``the Iranian people do not have any problem with the American people.'' In fact, he said, the U.S. help might create a better atmosphere for relations between the United States and Iran. Iranian authorities have previously referred to the United States as ``the Great Satan.'' But the Iranian Foreign Ministry has said the nation welcomed international help due to the magnitude of the earthquake, in which at least 50,000 people are said to have died, with 200,000 injured and a half-million homeless. The group of expatriates, known as the Society for Iranian Professionals, has been in negotiations with Iran to provide the kind of professional help the country has declined to accept from foreign governments. U.S. officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity said the doctors, nurses, engineers and other professionals will leave Washington on Saturday. The officials said a second plane load of U.S. supplies would be dispatched once Iran makes clear through Switzerland and other intermediaries what kind of assistance it requires. ``As soon as we hear from them, we will help,'' an official said. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said that the United States ``is interested in helping in a very tragic situation. ... Politics don't enter into it.'' The United States broke relations with Iran in 1980 after the seizure of the U.S. Embassy and the taking of American hostages in November 1979. Six Americans are now being held hostage in Lebanon by militants believed to be under Iranian influence.

DOC.HEAD: Senate, Administration Agree on Key Elements of Housing Bill
DOC.TEXT: Democratic and Republican senators reached agreement with the Bush administration Tuesday on key elements of a major housing bill that had been stalled in the Senate since last week, Senate and administration sources said. The agreement came in a meeting with Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp and senators, including Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the principal sponsor of the housing bill. The agreement, to be detailed at a news conference Wednesday, clears the way for the Senate to resume debate on the nearly $18 billion bill, probably on Wednesday. The Senate debated the bill for five days last week before it was shoved aside, with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell saying he would await the outcome of negotiations with the administration before pressing for a vote. A key stumbling block to an agreement had been the Bush administration's proposals for increasing down payment requirements as part of a package of reforms aimed at halting massive losses that threaten the Federal Housing Administration program. The Bush administration proposed increasing premiums and upfront cash requirements so that FHA borrowers would have to pay two-thirds of closing costs at the time of purchase. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., proposed going further by requiring a 5 percent down payment on loans over $5,000, adding a premium over the life of the loan and requiring that all closing costs be paid at the beginning of the loan without being financed. Cranston had proposed another plan that he said would shore up the FHA program without increasing down payment requirements. The agreement included provisions for merging the administration's plan for helping public housing tenants to purchase their homes with Senate Democrats' proposal for a $2 billion program to encourage local governments to rehabilitate or build new low-income housing. Senate sources, speaking on the condition they not be identified, said the compromise bill emphasizes the rehabilitation of existing housing units. And it would continue to authorize nearly $4 billion more in federal spending on housing than President Bush has proposed.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Votes To Get Hungary Out of the Warsaw Pact
DOC.TEXT: Parliament voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to immediately suspend Hungary's activities in the Warsaw Pact and eventually withdraw from the East bloc military alliance. The 232-0 vote _ with four abstentions _ again puts Hungary in conflict with the Soviet Union, which wants to maintain the organization as a political union. A similar declaration in 1956 prompted Soviet tanks to invade Hungary and crush a popular uprising led by former Premier Imre Nagy. The Warsaw Pact has admitted that invasion was a mistake, and Tuesday's Hungarian vote came the same day Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze criticized the Warsaw Pact for failing ``to keep pace with the times.'' ``It is high time we understood that neither socialism nor friendship nor good-neighborly relations nor respect can be maintained with bayonets, tanks and bloodshed,'' Shevardnadze was quoted as saying in the Communist Party daily Pravda. The Parliament resolution called on the government to begin negotiations with the Warsaw Pact's six other members to prepare for the planned withdrawal. ``We seek to come to agreement with all member countries on Hungary ending membership,'' the state MTI news agency quoted the resolution as saying. As a first step, the resolution called on the government to suspend Hungary's participation in the military organization. ``The armed forces should not take part in joint Warsaw Pact military exercises and Warsaw Pact troops should not hold exercises in Hungary,'' MTI quoted the resolution as saying. Parliament also asked the government to open talks with fellow member nations to review existing treaties to ``delete all references which would allow for military intervention or which would impinge upon Hungary's sovereignty in any way.'' The decision followed Prime Minister Jozsef Antall's announcement June 9 that Hungary wants to ``restore full sovereignty over the Hungarian armed forces'' and ``revamp its forces into a defensive organization.'' Neither Antall nor the resolution gave a timetable for Hungary's planned withdrawal or specified how soon officials would like to see a complete pullout from the Warsaw Pact. Early this month, however, Defense Minister Lajos Fuer was quoted by MTI as saying Hungary wanted to cancel its Warsaw Pact membership by late next year. Antall told reporters at the Warsaw Pact meeting in Moscow on June 9 that Hungarian leaders felt ``the military aspect of the Pact should be dissolved by the end of 1991.'' In an interview published June 9 in the West Berlin newspaper Morgenpost, East Germany's defense minister, Rainer Eppelmann, predicted the breakup of the Warsaw Pact's military structures this year. The other Warsaw Pact members are Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Poland, Romania and the Soviet Union. The alliance, founded in 1955, has been a counterbalance to the West's North Atlantic Treaty Organization. In 1956, Soviet forces suppressed a popular uprising led by Nagy, who had called for a Hungary independent of the Warsaw Pact. Nagy and several aides were executed in 1958 following a show trial. Hungarians remained bitter at the Soviets and Budapest's Communist leaders. Following popular uprisings in Eastern Europe that toppled ruling Communists, Hungary held free elections in March that relegated the reform Communists to a minor role. The new non-Communist government is led by Antell and President Arpad Goencz, who was sentenced to life in prison for his role in the 1956 uprising. Warsaw Pact leaders in June admitted the 1956 invasion of Hungary and a 1968 advance into Czechoslovakia were grave errors. In Moscow, Shevardnadze followed the same theme in an article published in Pravda. ``Our organization turned out to be not very perceptive of changes, failed to keep pace with the times, didn't modernize itself, didn't perfect its military and political structures,'' Shevardnadze said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Soviet Soldier After Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: Police killed a Soviet army sergeant in a shootout after he kidnapped a family in an attempt to return home, officials said Tuesday. The couple and their two children were freed unharmed but a police officer with an East German anti-terrorist unit was injured by flying glass, according to the government news agency ADN. The soldier was armed with a submachine gun and more than 800 rounds of ammunition when he fled a Soviet weapons garrison Monday night in Magdeburg, about 50 miles west of Berlin. The soldier took the family hostage later at a campground in nearby Burg, Magdeburg Police Chief Hans-Joachim Stephan told ADN. Police spotted the soldier at the campground but took no immediate action because of the number of people in the area, he said. The soldier fled in a car with the hostages and was later stopped by a police roadblock, where he was killed in an exchange of gunfire, Stephan said. The soldier apparently wanted to return to the Soviet Union because of family problems at home, ADN said. The family taken hostage was being treated for shock, it said. The Soviet defense ministry, in a report carried by the official Soviet news agency Tass, confirmed the incident and identified the soldier as S. Suvorov, ADN said.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility for Conservative Party Club Blast
LaserPhoto LON7
DOC.TEXT: The IRA claimed responsibility Tuesday for a bombing at fashionable club that is a bastion of the Conservative Party, and it said no government member will be safe until Britain pulls out of Northern Ireland. The bomb at the Carlton Club, which injured nine people, was the first directed at the party since the IRA bombed the Grand Hotel in Brighton during the 1984 Conservative conference. That attack killed five people and narrowly missed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Scotland Yard said it was examining videotapes taken by a security camera outside the club for clues to the bombers. Mrs. Thatcher toured the bombed-out building and visited two of those injured in Monday night's attack. ``It was dreadful, inhuman, depraved'' she said. ``They are trying to undermine democracy. In Northern Ireland everyone has a vote, and they voted to stay with the United Kingdom.'' In a statement issued in Dublin, the Irish Republican Army said an active service unit ``struck at the heart of Tory rule.'' The Carlton Club is ``the rest and recreation center for the British government who legislate for a military occupation of the North of Ireland,'' the statement said. ``Like Brighton in 1984, the IRA has brought the war directly to those who keep the British army on the streets and in the fields of Ireland,'' it said. ``While such occupation continues, and the nationalist people face daily oppression, the policy-makers and their military arm will not be safe.'' Police have not said whether any bomb fragments have been found. A spokeswoman, who by custom was not identified, said the extensive damage and instability of the 158-year-old building made it difficult to search for evidence. Mrs. Thatcher said she believed the IRA bombed the club to gain publicity during a summit in Dublin of European Community prime ministers. Home Secretary David Waddington, who is responsible for law and order, said the bombing and another on June 12 at the former home of the Conservative treasurer, Lord McAlpine, signaled a change in IRA tactics. ``Whether they strike at military or civilian targets, barracks or private homes, they are attacking democracy itself and they do not care who is killed or injured in the process,'' he told the House of Commons. Two of the injured, Charles Henry, 76, a porter at the club, and Lord Kaberry, 82, a former vice-chairman of the Conservative Party who is a member of the House of Lords, were hospitalized in stable condition Tuesday, a Westminster Hospital spokesman said. Two uniformed police officers treated for smoke inhalation were released Tuesday, the spokesman said. The others, including two American tourists, were treated and released. The Americans were Jane Kahan, 49, and Jacob Boal-Tefhuva, 61, both of New York. Churchill-Coleman said the device was left in a bag or parcel against a wall near steps inside the club's front door, probably within an hour of the blast. The IRA, which draws its support almost entirely from Roman Catholics, has stepped up its offensive in Britain and continental Europe. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Conservative Party leaders said they were determined the club would be rebuilt, as it was after being hit by German bombs in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Policies Ignore Tobacco Health Threat, Doctors Say
DOC.TEXT: A dramatic increase in smoking worldwide has been fostered by U.S. trade policies that ignore the health problems associated with tobacco, according to a report. ``Globally, increasing tobacco use is responsible for almost 2.5 million excessive or premature deaths per year _ almost 5 percent of all deaths,'' said the report in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. U.S. trade policy is perpetuating the problem by trying to develop overseas _ especially in Asia _ a market that is drying up at home, said the report by the AMA's Council on Scientific Affairs. The report's recommendations included urging the nation's largest group of physicians to lobby the U.S. government to alter tobacco trade policies, and imposing foreign-language health warning labels on cigarette packages for export. A bill in Congress and supported by the AMA would require such labeling. The U.S. Cigarette Export Association, which represents manufacturers responsible for 98 percent of cigarette exports, contends the United States has no business imposing its restrictions on other countries. Andrew Copenhaver, counsel to the cigarette export association, said the United States is not resposible for the popularity of smoking overseas. ``There's no evidence that consumption trends (overseas) are being affected by whether or not the U.S. product is there,'' Copenhaver said. The AMA report _ adopted as AMA policy in June 1989 _ said worldwide tobacco use has increased nearly 75 percent in the past 20 years. In 1988 alone, U.S. cigarette exports to Asia increased 75 percent, the report said. ``The tobacco industry, ignoring long-term costs of medical care, loss of productivity from tobacco-attributable morbidity and mortality ... continues to promote tobacco as an excellent cash crop,'' the report said. Last month, at a World Conference on Lung Health meeting, former U.S. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said smoking dropped 5 percent in the United States last year, while American tobacco exports rose 20 percent. ``Export of tobacco products is a moral outrage,'' Koop said. Koop said foreign advertising aimed at women and young people, combined with a lack of warning labels, cause many non-smokers to take up the habit. Dr. Harvey Estes Jr., an AMA council member, said the government wrongfully views tobacco exports as a trade issue rather than a health issue. ``It seems irrational to advocate that we export a product that we know is going to cause death and disability to another segment of the world,'' he said in a telephone interview Monday. But U.S. trade officials believe tobacco is a legal commodity and therefore should not be unfairly restricted, said Timothy O'Leary, spokesman for the office of the U.S. trade representative. ``It's probably ... suitable for any given country in the world to decide if it wants to permit smoking. But as long as smoking is legal, then that country ought not to discriminate'' against U.S. tobacco, he said by telephone Tuesday from Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Report Links German, Dutch Firms to 2nd Poison Gas Plant in Libya
DOC.TEXT: BADEN-BADEN, West Germany (AP) _ A West German television report on Tuesday said Libya is planning to build a second poison gas plant with the help of three companies _ two in West Germany and one in the Netherlands. West German industrialist Juergen Hippenstiel-Immhausen, who has admitted furnishing plans and helping build the Rabta chemical plant south of Tripoli, is on trial in West Germany on charges of violating export laws and tax evasion. On Tuesday, the ARD television network in Baden-Baden said Libya intended to build a second plant using the plans furnished by Hippenstiel-Immhausen for the first plant. It cited U.S. and West German intelligence sources for the information. Libya has said the plant at Rabta was for producing pharmaceuticals. Hippenstiel admitted at his trial last week that he had helped build the chemical plant, which U.S. authorities say was capable of producing poison gas. The television report said two West German companies, Rose and Abacus, were suspected of having ties to the project. In addition, the report said a company it identified as KWINT-techniek, based in the Dutch town of Culembourg, was suspected of involvement with the second plant. According to the report, the Stuttgart prosecutor's office is investigating the allegations against the companies in West Germany. Repeated attempts to contact the two West German companies and the Stuttgart prosecutor's office for comment on the report late Tuesday were unsuccessful.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Blast at Bus Stop Injures Two
LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at a Jerusalem bus stop Tuesday and two women were slightly injured in the attack, the third in less than a week, authorities said. The explosion, described as small, shattered the glass-enclosed bus shelter, said city police spokesman Uzi Sandor. He said the women were taken to the hospital with minor leg injuries. Police set up roadblocks and searched the area. Sandori said about 30 Arab suspects were rounded up. The explosion was on the road that leads to Bethlehem, which is in the occupied West Bank. Jerusalem Police Commander Arieh Bibi urged people to watch for unattended packages and other suspicious objects. ``Let me just tell the residents of the capital to be more aware,'' Bibi said on Israel army radio. ``The more eyes, the better.'' On Saturday, a pipe bomb placed in a trash can on a beach exploded, injuring four people. On Sunday, another pipe bomb went off near gas tanks in the central Israeli city of Ramle. There were no injuries or damage. Two other bombs were safely dismantled by police this week, one in Ramle and one in Jerusalem. Palestinians and Israelis have predicted an escalation in violence because of the U.S. decision to suspend dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Washington cut off the dialogue last week because PLO chief Yasser Arafat failed to condemn an attempted raid by Palestinian guerrillas on Israel. Also Tuesday, a 60-year-old Palestinian, Mohammed Abu Saba, was shot and wounded by masked activists in the West Bank village of Silat et Harithiya, Israel radio said. The attackers, who accused the man of collaborating with Israel, fled after he returned fire, the radio said. Some Palestinians assisting Israeli authorities are issued weapons by the army. At least 225 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs as suspected collaborators with Israel during the 30-month-old revolt against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Some 721 Palestinians have died of Israeli gunfire in the uprising and 45 Israelis have been slain. Meanwhile, the army was investigating allegations that soldiers walked around naked on a rooftop observation post in the occupied West Bank and angered Arab residents, officials said. The rooftop post in the town of Abu Dis was set up early in June and removed 10 days ago, the military said. Residents complained that troops stationed at the lookout walked around naked, cursed women and children and used drinking water tanks on the roof to take showers.

DOC.HEAD: Government Bombs Strategic Fort
DOC.TEXT: Air force planes and helicopters firebombed and strafed residential areas near Jaffna Fort, a strategic military garrison, and hundreds of buildings were ablaze, Tamil rebels said Tuesday. Authorities and witnesses reported the deaths of 196 people nationwide, bringing the death toll in two weeks of fighting to 1,626 combatants. Many civilians have also been killed. In the northern city of Jaffna, the rebel stronghold, the government used bombers and a helicopter gunship to pound residential areas around Jaffna Fort, in which 270 soldiers and policemen have been besieged since the fighting began. Five air force bombers and a helicopter gunship used 120-pound bombs and 66-pound incendiary devices in the attack, said a rebel statement telexed to newspaper and news agency offices in Colombo. It described attacks on Monday and said hundreds of buildings near Jaffna Fort were set on fire. ``The whole area is ablaze,'' it said. Military officials said Tuesday that air force planes continued to bomb and strafe rebel positions and were trying to avoid civilian targets in the city, 186 miles north of Colombo. ``We are not hellbent on bombing and killing people,'' Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunge said. There was no way to independently verify rebel or government claims because transportation and telephone services to the region were cut off. But travelers reaching Vavuniya, just south of Jaffna, confirmed that the Jaffna was being heavily bombed. Over the weekend, air force planes dropped leaflets warning the city's 120,000 residents to evacuate. The rebel statement claimed the military was using ``napalm'' bombs but then said the bombs were made of coal tar, rubber shavings and explosives. There was no indication that napalm, a powerful defoliant, was used by the military. The government considers Jaffna Fort one of its main bases in the area and it would be a serious military blow if it lost the area to the rebels. The Tamils started a war for separatism in 1983 but there had been a 13-month halt to hostilities during a cease-fire between the rebels and the Sinhalese-dominated government. The latest fighting broke out on June 11, after a Tamil man claimed he was manhandled by Sinhalese police. Tamil Tigers then overran a series of police stations. Tamils form 18 percent of the island's 16 million people. They have long accused the Sinhalese majority of discrimination.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Estimate that $10 Million Taken in Armored Car Robbery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series; subs grafs 2-4, bgng, `Monroe County ..., to CORRECT that sheriff says he did not confirm amount, but does not deny it; pick up 5th graf, `The theft ...
DOC.TEXT: More than $10 million was stolen by gunmen Tuesday morning during an armored car robbery, authorities said. Monroe County Sheriff Andrew P. Meloni said the robbery occurred at about 7:20 a.m. in suburban Henrietta. ``It certainly was planned _ no question about that _ and was obviously rather successful,'' Meloni said. The amount stolen was $10.8 million, according to other law enforcement sources contacted by the Rochester Times-Union. Meloni said he could not confirm the amount. The theft could be the second largest of its kind in U.S. history. The FBI's public affairs office in Washington, D.C., said its records indicate the largest theft from an armored car in United States history was $11 million taken in 1982 from a Sentry Armored Car Courier Co. office in the New York City. In 1983, $7 million was stolen from a Wells Fargo armored car office in Hartford, Conn. Sheriff's department spokesman Tom Ryan said the armored car robbed Tuesday was owned by Armored Motor Service of America Inc., of Chili. The car's male driver and a female employee had stopped at a delicatessen to get coffee and sandwiches, Ryan said. While the woman went into the deli, the driver was confronted by a gunman who managed to get into the truck and take control of the vehicle, the employees told police. When the woman returned, the gunman ordered the two to drive to a more rural location about a half mile away, Ryan said. The money was then transferred from the armored truck to another vehicle, believed to be a gray van, Ryan said. The armored car company workers were taped-up and had their wrists bound. At least one of the gunmen wore a mask. After the robbers fled the scene in the second vehicle, the employees said they took about 15 minutes to free themselves, authorities said. They returned to the armored car company offices and notified the sheriff's office of the robbery at 7:38 a.m., Ryan said. ``We're dealing with people who had a well laid-out plan,'' said Capt. Neil Flood, commander of the sheriff's office Criminal Investigation Division. The two employees were not injured, Ryan said. Meloni said investigators were working closely with the FBI and were interviewing the driver and the assistant. The armored truck has been checked for fingerprints, he said, and examined for other clues. Investigators were looking into records and routes of the armored vehicle and were questioning other people in the area, he said. The money was to be transported to the Federal Reserve Bank in Buffalo, which serves as a source of coin and currency for banks throughout western New York. Banks, in turn, send surplus money to the Federal Reserve for storage.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves New Funds for Prosecuting S&L Fraud
DOC.TEXT: The House on Tuesday approved a $10.5 billion money bill that would give the Justice Department an additional $75 million to use in prosecuting fraud in the nation's savings and loan scandal. With public outrage growing over the debacle that is expected eventually to cost over $300 billion, lawmakers are rushing to provide money to pursue the more than 21,000 fraud cases that have so far been referred to the Justice Department. The additional money, approved in an amendment added to the bill last week, was part of a measure providing about half the money needed for the coming fiscal year for the departments of Commerce, Justice and State, and for the federal judiciary. The measure now goes to the Senate. The bill was approved on a vote of 368 to 55. The rest of the needed funds for those agencies will have to be added later, after authorizing legislation is enacted by the appropriate committees and the full Congress. Rep. Neal Smith, D-Iowa, who proposed adding $75 million for the Justice Department's S&L prosecutions, said even more money will be coming later. The amount was an increase over the $50 million allocated for prosecutions this year. The largest chunk of the bill, $3.2 billion, goes for State Department operations for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. It includes $788 million for U.S. dues to the United Nations and other international bodies, including a start on paying off past-due amounts withheld in previous years. Around $1.7 billion is appropriated for the Commerce Department, including $438 million for the Census Bureau and $47 million for research on global warming by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Most funding for the Justice Department, including U.S. attorneys, the FBI, the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the federal prison system, was left out of the $1.7 billion Justice section of the bill. The section does include $500 million to be used for reparations payments to Japanese-Americans interned by the U.S. government during World War II, and $400 million for anti-drug abuse grants.

DOC.HEAD: German Parliament Presidents Say Israeli Fears Unfounded
DOC.TEXT: The visiting presidents of the East and West German parliaments assured Israel Tuesday that concerns here and elsewhere about German unification are unfounded. Rita Suessmuth of West Germany and Sabine Bergmann-Pohl of East Germany also pledged that a united Germany would be a strong supporter of the Jewish state. The two presidents spoke on the second day of a three-day visit to Israel. The trip has been seen as an effort to allay concerns about German unification. ``We take the concerns seriously, but they are unfounded,'' Ms. Bergmann-Pohl said in a speech before Israel's Council on Foreign Relations, a private group that regularly discusses foreign affairs. ``It will be an important task of German foreign policy to deal with these fears and to take into consideration the legitimate security concerns'' of its neighbors, she added. Ms. Suessmuth rejected predictions that a united Germany would dominate Europe, saying that instead it would pave the way for European unity. ``Without ending Germany's division, there cannot be a unified Europe. Without German unity, the policy of confrontation between the Eastern and Western blocs will not end,'' she said. She also took a gentle swipe at those expressing concern. ``We are being watched intensively, sometimes too intensively. If we make mistakes they are weighed more heavily than those of others,'' said Ms. Suessmuth. Many Israelis remain skeptical of German unification, including Shevach Weiss, a deputy speaker of Parliament who as a child spent two years hiding from the Nazis in a basement in the Ukraine. ``I know we can't change historical processes. But we have the right and maybe the obligation to be afraid and alarmed by the enormous power (of a united Germany),'' said Weiss. The two German officials toured the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial in Jerusalem, an exhibit that tells the story of the genocide in which 6 million Jews were slain by the Nazis. In Yad Vashem's Hall of Remembrance, a darkened room with an eternal flame and the names of Nazi death camps inscribed on the floor, Ms. Bergmann-Pohl and Ms. Suessmuth each laid a wreath with red and yellow flowers and stood silently for a moment. Ms. Bergmann-Pohl, who had remained silent while viewing pictures of executions, gas chambers and bodies piled in mass graves, cried when she later addressed her hosts. ``I wanted to make a promise here that I will work hard that such injustice will never happen again, and I will work especially hard for this in a united Germany,'' she said outside the hilltop memorial overlooking Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Groups Disappointed After Meeting De Klerk
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Extreme right-wing groups expressed disappointment Tuesday after meeting President F.W. de Klerk and accused him of capitulating to the United States, Britain and local Communists. Several pro-apartheid groups met de Klerk in Pretoria and demanded guarantees that whites would maintain political sovereignty and that there would never be a Communist government in South Africa. Jaap Marais, leader of the Reconstituted National Party, said de Klerk refused to make such pledges. Marais said the president should stop ``capitulating to the demands of the U.S.A., United Kingdom and the Communists.'' Marais and other right-wing leaders consider Nelson Mandela and his African National Congress a Communist-inspired terrorist group. The ANC, the country's largest black opposition movement, is closely allied with the South African Communist Party, but it says Communist beliefs do not guide ANC policy. De Klerk's government seeks to negotiate with the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups to establish a new constitution that would give blacks some share of power in the government. ``He (de Klerk) has become entrapped in a web in which only people of the left have entrance to him,'' Marais said. ``He realized today that there are people of different views.'' Right-wing groups believe de Klerk has instituted his reforms to persuade Western governments to lift economic sanctions against South Africa. The limited sanctions were imposed in recent years to protest the apartheid system that allows the white minority to maintain political and economic control over the country. The European Community on Tuesday refused to lessen sanctions until there is ``further clear evidence'' of political change in South Africa. In Washington, President Bush told Mandela on Monday that the United States would maintain sanctions for the time being. Mandela addressed a joint session of the U.S. Congress on Tuesday and told the legislators his country ``continues to bleed and suffocate'' under the repression of white-minority rule. Both de Klerk and Mandela have warned that heavily armed right-wing extremists could undermine efforts to launch black-white political negotiations. One of the groups that met de Klerk, the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, has established commando units and threatened to take up arms if the government lessens white privileges. None of the organizations holds seats in the white chamber of Parliament, but together the groups claim tens of thousands of followers. Their support comes mostly from working-class and rural Afrikaners, the country's Dutch-descended settlers who account for about 3 million of the 5 million whites. The right-wing groups seek to carve up South Africa into separate homelands for whites and the 28 million blacks. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party, which was not present at Tuesday's talks in the capital of Pretoria, captured 31 percent of the white vote in elections last September. Most political analysts believe support for the Conservatives has increased in response to De Klerk's reforms. Right-wingers have been threatening the government for months. Last week provided the strongest indications yet that such groups are ready to act. Piet Rudolph, a leader of the Boer State Party, declared war on the government in a videotape sent to a local newspaper. Rudolph has been in hiding since he allegedly stole arms and ammunition from air force headquarters in April. Also, two offices belonging to de Klerk's National Party were bombed Friday night, causing damage but no injuries. No one claimed responsibility, but government officials say they suspect right-wingers. A local newspaper reported Friday that white extremists were planning to assassinate Mandela and de Klerk. Police arrested 11 whites for questioning, but all were released and no charges have been filed.

DOC.HEAD: Last U.S. Dirigible Found Off California Coast
DOC.TEXT: After 55 years at the bottom of the sea, the last U.S. dirigible and two rare Sparrowhawk scout planes were located in 1,500 feet of chilly water by a tiny Navy submarine. The 785-foot-long Macon was returning to Moffett Field, about 45 miles south of San Francisco, when it was damaged in a storm on Feb. 12, 1935, and settled into the sea. It was carrying a crew of 83 and four Sparrowhawks. Lifeboats saved 81 of the crew, but the Macon slid beneath the surface about 100 miles south of San Francisco and disappeared. It was spotted on Sunday by the three-man crew of the titanium-hulled Seacliff, which had been commissioned to find the wreck. ``It's a delightful surprise!'' said squadron leader Henry Miller, now 87, the only Macon crewman still alive. ``I'm simply thrilled!,'' Miller said in a telephone interview from his home in Shawnee Mission, Kan. The dirigible, which was about four times as long as the popular Goodyear blimps, went down after a tail fin snapped in heavy wind and rain, puncturing three helium cells, according to John Sanders, a spokesman at the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey. Recalling the accident, Miller said it was ``obvious the ship was a goner'' after it began losing altitude. As the deflated tail section dragged the airship downward, the captain sent several men to the nose to try to balance the ship. When the Macon went into the ocean about 15 miles offshore, Miller was one of the men on the nose. ``It was just like a big old hen settling down on a nest,'' he said of the ``crash.'' Sanders said searchers have always looked south of the lighthouse for the wreckage, but apparently the Macon was dragged north by the California Undercurrent. A clue discovered in the late 1970s helped solve the puzzle. A piece of the Macon was pulled from the water by fisherman Dave Canepa, and it eventually wound up hanging on the wall of a restaurant. Chris Grech of the Monterey Bay Aquarium, one of a small group of people looking for the wreck, heard about the junk hanging on the dining room wall and traced it back to Canepa. Canepa, who says he ``never threw any of my (fishing) records away,'' told Grech where he found the debris. Grech passed it on to the Navy. The discovery is a ``tremendous find for aviation museums,'' said Sanders. Only one intact Sparrowhawk exists, on display at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C. ``They were the most beautiful little planes I ever flew,'' Miller said. The Sea Cliff discovered the wreck in just 15 minutes on the first dive, pilot Lt. Pat Scanlon said. Scanlon said the airship's frame was collapsed, but the crew could see two Sparrowhawks intact. ``It was amazing,'' said observer Lt. j.g. Jerry Peterson. ``My heart skipped a beat when we saw it.'' The Macon is settled on a flat sandy bottom, Scanlon said, with two of the Sparrowhawks visible. The third and fourth planes are probably buried in the sand, he said. The planes only had a range of 100 miles, Sanders said, but the Macon could stay aloft for days or even weeks. The Sparrowhawks on the Macon were the only planes in the Navy that didn't have landing gear. They landed on ``trapezes'' suspended from the dirigible. The Macon crash followed the crash of its sibling ships, the Akron and Shenandoah, both of which were lost in storms. The three crashes doomed the Navy's plans to expand the lighter-than-air program.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Discusses Food-Labeling Rules
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan on Tuesday disclosed additional details about the food-labeling rules being drafted, but it's still undecided whether they will apply uniformly. Sullivan declined to discuss the uniformity question during a speech to a conference on food safety and nutrition, saying ``this issue is under review within the administration.'' He also declined to discuss it after his speech. Administration sources have said Sullivan's department wants the federal regulations to supersede state regulations, but that White House officials don't want to preclude the states from adding stronger regulations. California is the only state that might be directly affected. Sullivan said he believed the uniformity question would be resolved ``very soon.'' He previously said he wanted to get the proposed regulations out by the end of this month, but he declined Tuesday to be that specific. The proposal, to be issued by the Food and Drug Administration, would require nutrition labeling on most foods _ including most fresh produce and seafood. Nutrition labels would have to appear on all packaged food. For unpackaged foods such as fresh fruits, vegetables and seafood, other methods of displaying the information would be allowed, such as leaflets or posters where the foods are sold. Also, manufacturers would have to show on the label the number of calories from fat and the amount of saturated fatty acids, cholesterol and total dietary fiber. The regulations would define the terms ``cholesterol free,'' ``low cholesterol'' and ``reduced cholesterol'' to eliminate misleading claims. Restaurants, bakeries, cafeterias and some small businesses would be exempt from the regulations, Sullivan said. Also waived from the requirements would be bite-size foods and foods that have no meaningful sources of calories and nutrients, he said. Another change would update the reference values, now called the Recommended Daily Allowance or RDA, used to compare the nutrition content of foods and evaluate a food's contribution to the diet. RDA would be replaced with the term Reference Daily Intakes, or RDI, and updated values would be proposed for protein and for 12 vitamins and seven minerals that have RDAs. Vitamin K, manganese and other nutrients that don't have RDAs would be added to the list with reference values. Reference values also would be established for fat, cholesterol, sodium and fiber, but manufacturers would not be required to include that in their nutrition labels, Sullivan said. The food industry has lobbied strongly for a labeling policy that would be standard across the country. John Cady, president of the National Food Processors Association, said that if labeling rules differed from state to state, consumers would be confused and distribution logistics would increase food costs substantially. The Center for Science in the Public Interest wants the states to be able to bolster any federal food-labeling requirements. But even with that issue aside, center officials say the department's proposals ``are inadequate given the severity of the problem.'' Bruce Silverglade, legal affairs director for the center, said the organization obtained a draft copy of some portions of the proposed regulations. Because of several deficiencies in the proposal, he said, the center is urging passage of congressional legislation that is tougher. Silverglade said Sullivan's proposal was defective because it would not require manufacturers to disclose how much fat, cholesterol, sodium and fiber a food contributes to the maximum daily amounts a person should consume. It also would not require disclosure of sugar content or set a deadline for final agency action, he said. Current requirements, established 17 years ago, call for nutrition labeling only when a manufacturer adds vitamins, minerals or proteins or makes a nutritional claim about the product. About 60 percent of packaged foods list nutrients, a majority of which is labeled voluntarily.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalists Issue Death Threat Against American
DOC.TEXT: Moslem fundamentalists threatened to kill the American director of the largest private relief group working with refugees from the war in Afghanistan, officials said Tuesday. The death threat against Thomas Yates, director of the International Rescue Committee, was made in a letter delivered Sunday to the World Food Program, said the officials, who insisted they not be identified by name, nationality or agency. The letter, made available to The Associated Press, was written in English and addressed ``To Whom It May Concern.'' It said Western aid groups were being watched and that Yates would be killed to prove the claim. It accurately described the car he drives, clothes he had worn, and places he often went. ``We know your secrets and your locations,'' said the letter, signed by the shadowy International Jihad Organization. The group has been linked with Hezb-i-Islami, or Party of God, the most anti-West of the seven resistance groups based in Pakistan. Spokesmen for Hezb-i-Islami said the attacks would be justified, but they denied involvement. As Washington and Moscow move closer to a political settlement of the Afghan war, diplomatic sources say many Afghans have launched an anti-West campaign to counter what they consider a U.S. attempt to sideline the Moslem fundamentalists. The officials said Yates and his family had left Peshawar, the border city that has served as headquarters for the guerrillas who have been trying for 12 years to overthrow the Soviet-backed government of Afghanistan. The U.S.-based International Rescue Committee opened its Peshawar operations in 1980. It has sponsored educational, agricultural and health care programs in border camps, where nearly 4 million Afghans have taken refuge during the war. Attacks on private Western relief groups have increased since late April, and many agencies have threatened to close their operations unless the government guarantees their safety. In a related development, the Australian-based Shelter Now International said Tuesday it was indefinitely suspending its operation pending a final decision by the board of directors. Shelter Now, which ran programs for Afghan widows and orphans, has been the target of repeated fundamentalist attacks in both Pakistan and Afghanistan. The decision to freeze its operation was prompted by the June 16 attempted murder of its director, American Thor Armstrong. ``Although we may never know the motive behind this attack, we are convinced this was not just a coincidence but a serious sign of the escalating danger to both expatriates and Afghans,'' the release said. ``This is not an easy decision but circumstances leave us no choice,'' it said. When the Soviet Union withdrew its soldiers from Afghanistan in February 1989 after nine years of military involvement, the guerrilla government-in-exile was touted by its Western backers as likely to replace the Communist-style government left behind in Kabul. But the guerrillas have failed to achieve a significant military victory, and the government-in-exile has degenerated into a chaotic collection of bickering warlords, diplomats and analysts say.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Imelda Committed No Crime
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos was ``a world-class shopper,'' but the racketeering case against her is a prosecutor's fantasy based on rhetoric rather than evidence, her attorney said Tuesday. ``There is no crime in being wealthy or in spending money,'' defense lawyer Gerry Spence told the U.S. District Court jury in closing arguments. He said Mrs. Marcos ``committed no crime except of loving a man for 35 years, raising his children, taking his lavish gifts and being his ardent supporter.'' Spence, a flamboyant attorney from Wyoming, gave a dramatic plea for acquittal. He raised and lowered his voice, waved his arms and used his cowboy hat to illustrate a point. He said the government had wrongly concluded that the former Philippines first lady knew stolen money was used for investments in the United States. He compared the theory to a ``big leap ... like Superman would make'' and said it violated his client's right to a presumption of innocence. ``It's a hole so big you could drive a truck through it,'' Spence said. The lawyer also claimed that Philippines President Corazon Aquino had threatened to cancel the U.S.-Philippine military base agreement unless the Marcoses were brought to trial. ``Corazon Aquino used the American bases on the Philippines as leverage,'' Spence said. ``No prosecution, no bases.'' He ridiculed the government's case in a mocking tone and attacked the lead prosecutor, Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella. ``His proof is his arguments, his must-have-beens, his fantasies,'' Spence said. ``Mrs. Marcos was the most open woman in the world. There isn't any evidence in this case that she ever did anything.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of helping her late husband, former Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos, embezzle $222 million from their country's treasury to buy four New York buildings, jewelry and art works. She faces up to 50 years in prison and $1 million in fines if convicted of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with mail fraud and obstructing justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the properties after a U.S. court order froze their assets. Khashoggi's attorney, James Linn, is to present his closing arguments on Wednesday. The jury is expected to begin deliberations on Thursday. Spence said the building purchases were arranged by Mrs. Marcos' husband and constituted a three-way investment by the Philippines government, Marcos himself and their close friends, Benedicto and Gliceria Tantoco. The Tantocos, who are fugitives in the case, owned the largest department store in Manila and Benedicto Tantoco was the former Philippine ambassador to the Vatican. Spence said Marcos was not a crook but a politician who wanted to hide his partial ownership of the buildings. ``He didn't want people to know he was investing in the U.S.,'' he said. ``Don't you think he has the same right as the Japanese, the Dutch and the English?'' Spence said Marcos did not acquire his wealth by illegal means but rather through 30 years of investing in Philippine companies. In his opening statement, the attorney had attributed Marcos' wealth to a secret horde of gold hidden in the Philippines by a Japanese general during World War II. Spence again and again came back to his argument that none of the evidence directly linked Mrs. Marcos to the transactions. ``One document out of 300,000 has her signature after the date of the alleged wrongdoing and that is $700,000 from a Swiss account to her private account to pay for her jewels,'' he said. ``There is something almost fantastically silly about this case.'' Spence said the defense called no witnesses because there was ``nothing to rebut.'' Spence said at another point, ``I'll tell you she was a world-class shopper, but I'll tell you she was a world-class decent human being.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Miami Visit Splits Ethnic Groups
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's planned visit here has aggravated tensions in this racially divided community, as Cuban-Americans protest his stand on Fidel Castro while blacks rally to his support. Black radio talk shows on Tuesday called for demonstrations to rival the protests called for by Cuban-American radio programs outside the Miami Beach labor convention Mandela is to address Thursday. Mandela's visit was welcomed until a nationally televised interview last week when he defended his support for Cuban leader Fidel Castro, Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. Mandela said they had supported the African National Congress in the early years of its struggle against apartheid in South Africa. Miami, with its large Cuban-American population, immediately withdrew a planned proclamation in Mandela's honor. Five Miami-area mayors, all Cuban-Americans, criticized Mandela for being insensitive to human rights in Cuba. ``We, Cuban Americans, find it beyond reasonable comprehension that Mr. Nelson Mandela, a victim of oppression by his own government, not only fails to condemn the Cuban government for its human-rights violations, but rather praises virtues of the tyrannical Castro regime,'' their statement said. Mayors Xavier Suarez, of Miami; Julio Martinez of Hialeah, Pedro Reboredo of West Miami, Jose Rivero of Sweetwater and Gilda Oliveros of Hialeah Gardens signed the declaration. On Tuesday, Mayor Alex Daoud of Miami Beach, where Mandela is to address the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees convention, also criticized Mandela over his praise for Gadhafi and Arafat. The mayors' statements angered black leaders, and black-oriented radio stations on Tuesday called for Mandela supporters to turn out in support of the black South African leader. ``We look like a bunch of stupid clowns around this country and around the world for not knowing who it is that is coming here, and how he ought to be treated,'' said Johnnie McMillian, head of the Miami-Dade chapter of the NAACP. Callers to Cuban-oriented talk shows were almost unanimous in condemning Mandela. Callers to black-oriented stations were particularly angry with Suarez, who enjoyed widespread black voter support in his two election victories against more militant Cuban challengers. Representatives from the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and other black groups presented Suarez's office with a protest letter Tuesday afternoon, and called on blacks to rally at the Miami Beach convention center and in Miami on Thursday to greet Mandela. Local Jewish leaders, while praising the black South African leader for his struggle against apartheid, have been critical of his stand toward Gadhafi and Arafat. ``We also recognize that we have profound and fundamental difference with Mr. Mandela,'' said Howard R. Scharlin, president of the Greater Miami Jewish Federation. ``These differences are deeply troubling to us.'' Feuding between blacks and Hispanics in Miami has simmered for more than a decade, polarizing the city's politics along racial lines. The latest friction grew from the January 1989 shooting of a black motorcyclist by a Colombian-born Miami police officer, sparking three days of rioting. Officer William Lozano was convicted of manslaughter in the case, but blacks objected to his widespread support in the Hispanic community and among Latin police officers, who raised money for his defense and wore black armbands in his support following the conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Smoking Forces See EPA Report As Big Win; Tobacco Industry Disagree
DOC.TEXT: Anti-smoking forces view a new Environmental Protection Agency report as a key victory in their decades-old war against tobacco use. But tobacco industry sources say the report is simply flawed and unsupported speculation. The EPA report, which is still in draft form and has not received final agency approval, was released Monday. It contends that secondhand smoke causes about 3,800 lung cancer deaths annually among non-smokers. It also says that children of smokers suffer more respiratory problems than children of non-smokers. ``For the first time, the government has come up with a real body count on the effects of environmental tobacco smoke,'' John Banzhaf, the executive director of the anti-smoking group Action on Smoking and Health, said Tuesday. ``It's going to have a major impact.'' Nonsense, said Brennan Dawson, vice president of public affairs for the Tobacco Institute. The EPA report, she said, is filled with scientific inaccuracies and is but another example of the anti-smoking bias in some government agencies. She said a review of the study by an EPA independent science board will destroy the conclusions drawn in the draft report. A test of the report's effect will come this week when Rep. Thomas Lukin, D-Ohio, introduces legislation called the ``Equal Treatment for Cigarettes Act.'' The bill, for the first time, would require the EPA to treat cigarette smoke as a carcinogen that it can regulate, just as it now can act against some industrial chemicals. Benjamin Cohen, an aide to Lukin, said the legislation would remove from the 1976 Toxic Substance Control Act a clause exempting tobacco products from EPA control. ``The Toxic Substance Control Act is the law that permits EPA to regulate asbestos,'' said Cohen. ``The new legislation would require the EPA to also regulate cigarette smoke.'' Banzhaf said the EPA study also will strength the anti-smoking side in lawsuits across the country, including one that his group filed against the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. ``When we can point out that a sister federal agency has determined that second hand smoke is dangerous, it will strengthen our litigation against OSHA,'' he said. The suit, an attempt to force OSHA to regulate smoking in the workplace, will be heard in federal court in the District of Columbia this fall. Phil Wilbur, director of the Smoking Control Advocacy Resource Center of the Advocacy Institute, a non-profit organization that assists special-interest groups, said the EPA report ``has put a number, 3,800, on the lung cancer deaths caused by secondhand smoke. ... People will realize that the number of deaths from secondhand smoke rivals the number of deaths from cocaine.'' Banzhaf said there now are about 150 non-smokers' rights groups around the country. Many are lobbying city councils and state governments for such things as limiting cigarette advertising and enforcing laws to cut off minors' access to tobacco. Despite all this, Ms. Dawson said that the tobacco industry is not in retreat and is still defending strongly what the group believes is a fundamental right of people to smoke. ``We still do pretty well,'' said Ms. Dawson. ``The fact is that most corporations still allow people to smoke on company premises. Most legislative and others battles are won by the industry. ``You don't hear about the smoking-restriction bills that don't get passed, or the tobacco taxes that don't pass,'' she said. And, she noted, despite decades of increasing opposition to smoking, ``fifty million adult Americans still smoke.'' The war, said Ms. Dawson, is not just for the tobacco industry because ``our customers deserve a battle also'' and representation against the anti-smoking forces. She said with things like limits on advertising and enforced restrictions on certain behaviors, there are people who support the industry's efforts to fight government action. ``They may be no friends of tobacco, but they don't like this nannyism and behavior modification coming from their elected officials,'' said Ms. Dawson. In the draft report, the EPA said evidence includes what the report calls ``detectable association at environmental exposure levels'' between cancer and exposure among nonsmoking family members who live with a smoker. The report also said that although 30 percent of the adult population smokes, there are detectable levels of cotinine, a metabolic product of nicotine, detected in the blood, saliva and urine of 50 to 75 percent of nonsmokers tested.

DOC.HEAD: Plutonium-Powered Satellite to Probe Sun's Poles
DOC.TEXT: A plutonium-powered satellite that will be launched from the shuttle Discovery this fall to explore the sun's poles poses little health risk in the event of an accident, space officials said Tuesday. ``We have looked at the statistics ... and our conclusion is that we think it's definitely as safe as it can be and we're not worried about it,'' said astronaut Thomas Akers, who will be part of Discovery's five-man crew. Ulysses' scientific instruments will be powered by one radioisotope thermoelectric generator (RTG), which converts heat from decaying plutonium into electricity. Two such generators were aboard the Galileo spacecraft that was sent on a six-year journey to Jupiter from the shuttle Atlantis last October. Environmentalists had opposed Galileo's power supply. They said a Challenger-like accident could scatter the deadly plutonium over Florida. But Willis Meeks, Ulysses project manager for NASA, said at a news conference the chances of that happening were ``very small.'' In the likelihood of the worst possible disaster, in which plutonium was released into the atmosphere, Meeks said there would be an additional 300 to 400 cancer deaths over 50 years based on the world's entire population. But a U.S. Energy Department engineer at the briefing who refused to identify himself said that estimate was much too high. President Bush is expected to approve Ulysses' launch in early September. Presidential approval is necessary when RTGs are used. The approximately $750 million mission is on schedule for an Oct. 5 launch, said John Conway, director of payload management and operations for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. There is no evidence of any damage to Discovery's right payload bay door, which inadvertently was yanked upward earlier this month by an overhead bridge, he said. Ulysses will be the first spacecraft to orbit over the sun's poles, providing new insight into solar winds and magnetic fields, said Peter Wenzel, Ulysses project scientist for the European Space Agency. The European agency is splitting the cost and responsibility of the mission with NASA. Wenzel said it will be like seeing the sun in the third dimension. ``Think of some little green man from Mars who comes, lands near the equator, looks around, goes back and describes what the Earth is like. That's not the whole story. You have to look at all latitudes,'' Wenzel said. Discovery has until Oct. 23 to lift off with Ulysses because of the alignment of Earth, the sun and Jupiter, whose gravitational field will slingshot the satellite back to the sun. Otherwise, the flight must be delayed for 13 months, said Willis Meeks, Ulysses project manager for NASA.
