It will take Ulysses 16 months to reach Jupiter and 2{ more years to reach the sun's 70-degree south latitude. In mid-1995, the satellite is expected to be in the same spot on the northern side. The 814-pound satellite will not be any closer to the sun during the five-year mission than it is now on Earth _ a distance of 93 million miles. It will be twice that far, in fact, when it passes over the solar poles. Ulysses is named after the heroic adventurer in Greek mythology.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Shuttle Official: Airline Sale Not Likely
With AM-Trump, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump never wanted to sell his year-old airline shuttle and probably won't, the president of the Trump Shuttle said on Tuesday. ``Ultimately, we're going to dominate this marketplace,'' said Bruce Nobles, who added that shuttle employees and suppliers have expressed some anxiety over the New York developer's financial difficulties. But he said the airline is unaffected. Trump is $73 million overdue on loan payments, but his bankers on Tuesday approved a 30-day, $20 million loan and agreed in principle to a bigger long-term financial bailout which would force him to sell some of his properties. The shuttle, a major Trump asset, has hourly flights linking New York with Boston and Washington. Trump in April hired Merrill Lynch Co. to negotiate the possible sale of the shuttle, which he purchased last June from Eastern Airlines for $365 million. Nobles, in a speech to an aviation industry meeting, said he had spoken with Trump earlier in the day. ``He doesn't want to sell the shuttle and has never wanted to sell the shuttle,'' Nobles said, adding that a sale was unlikely in view of Pan Am's efforts to sell its competing shuttle operation. Pan Am put its shuttle up for sale a month ago. Nobles said Trump earlier indicated he would sell the airline only if he were offered ``a lot of money.'' He said there is continuing interest, but no offer has been made. ``It's probably unlikely someone will make an offer we can't refuse.'' said Nobles, who has worked for both the Pan Am and Eastern shuttles. He announced the airline was extending until Sept. 30 a program that guarantees service, seats and on-time arrival. Failure to deliver gives customers a choice of bonus frequent flier miles, restaurant coupons or a discount on a future flight. Asked if criticism of Trump and jokes about his business and marital difficulties affect the airline, Nobles said, ``I don't know of any hard feelings. I guess a lot of people are having fun bashing Donald.'' He said the shuttle is running 50 to 55 percent of capacity and has to add ``several hundred'' extra flights a month because peak-hour flights are filled up. The airline has been losing money and will continue to do so into its second year because of the need to pay off loans, Nobles said. But he said it has been earning profits over its operating costs for some time. He spoke candidly of some of the airline's failures _ a concierge service which he said cost too much to make it worthwhile and a helicopter service into Manhattan. He said it needs to find ways to attract more passengers on weekends when fares already are lower and has had to cut back to a flight every two hours on Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning. Nobles said the shuttle's high fare _ $119 one way on weekdays between New York and Washington _ is justified by the fact that passengers can walk on any hour without reservations. He said a decline of shuttle passengers from 4 million in 1988 to an expected 3.7 million this year is due to general economic decline in the Northeast and increasing competition from carriers using other airports in the New York and Washington area and from Amtrak. Nobles blamed air traffic control limitations over the busy airports it serves for any delays. ``We would be 100 percent on time if air traffic control could handle the demand,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Cools, Southwest Simmers
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures rocketed over 110 degrees in parts of the Southwest on Tuesday while Miami cooled to an unseasonable 71 degrees. A band of thunderstorms stretched across a midsection of the nation from Kansas to Michigan. The 71 degree reading in Miami tied the low temperature record for the date set in 1950. The low temperature for the nation Tuesday was 28 degrees at Truckee, Calif., in the Sierra Nevadas. In Phoenix, the low temperature for Tuesday was a sweltering 91 degrees. By early afternoon, it surpassed Monday's record-breaking 120 degrees by one degree. The previous all-time record was 118. Searing heat also baked the deserts of San Diego County, Calif. Midland-Odessa, Texas, warmed to 104 degrees by early afternoon, breaking by one degree the community's high temperature record for the date. Thunderstorms early Tuesday brought wind gusts of 60 mph to Milford Lake, Kan., and damaged large tree limbs at Topeka, Kan. Wind gusts reach 60 mph at Kansas City, Mo. The storms reached southeast Kansas, northeast Oklahoma, north and central Arkansas and southwest Missouri. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over the northeast Colorado, from central and northeast Illinois across northwest Indiana into southwest Michigan. Rainshowers and thunderstorms extended over much of the Florida peninsula, southern Georgia, North Carolina and the central Texas Gulf Coast. Heavier rainfall in the six-hour period ending at 2 p.m. EDT included almost an inch at Fayetteville, Ark., and half an inch at Springfield, Mo., and Harrison, Ark. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 54 degrees at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 118 degrees at Yuma, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Says Party Debating Whether to Postpone Congress
DOC.TEXT: Reformers are trying to postpone a major Communist Party Congress scheduled to open next week that is expected to be a showdown between party liberals and hard-liners, Boris Yeltsin said Tuesday. A delay could prevent Communist Party hard-liners from capitalizing on their successes last week at a meeting of 2,700 party members from the Russian Federation, the largest and most populous of the 15 Soviet republics. Yeltsin, newly elected president of the Russian Federation, and other reformers favor a delay as a means of preserving their influence. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's stand on the delay was not immediately known, and one Western expert said postponement was unlikely. The 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party, to be attended by 4,700 delegates from around the country, was originally planned for next year but its opening date was moved up to July 2 to boost Gorbachev's reform efforts. Now, however, the congress seems likely to result in a walkout by radical reformers that could further polarize the political situation. The final decision on whether to delay the congress will be made at a plenary meeting of the party's policy-making Central Committee, expected within days, Yeltsin told a news conference. ``There will be a real struggle at the plenum,'' Yeltsin said. Some top party members want to hold the congress while memory of last week's meeting of Russian communists is still fresh, he said. ``Others, in order to somehow stabilize the political situation that has emerged now, are for delaying (the congress) for a time, perhaps until fall,'' Yeltsin said. ``I am personally for delaying it, to prepare more thoroughly.'' Yeltsin said last week's meeting of Russian delegates ``will have a very serious influence on the 28th Congress, and this is alarming.'' That meeting was dominated by traditional Soviet communists who accused Gorbachev of weakening the party with his reforms. It elected conservative Ivan Polozkov first secretary of a newly reconstituted Communist Party of the Russian Federation. Those same delegates from the Russian federation would form a majority at the national party congress. Gorbachev's most visible conservative rival on the party's ruling Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, told the Russian gathering last week that it was impossible for the Soviet leader to effectively run the party while he also holds the job of Soviet president. In another sign of the struggle, the lead article in the government newspaper Izvestia expressed doubt about holding any large-scale gatherings such as the congress now. Izvestia writer Albert Plutnik said such meetings ``objectively, in the current situation, do not benefit the supporters of perestroika,'' Gorbachev's reform program. Gorbachev spokesman Arkady A. Maslennikov declined to comment about Gorbachev's position and said the Central Committee would decide when the congress would be held. A Western diplomat in Moscow, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he doubted the congresss would be postponed. Party congresses, normally held every five years, theoretically are the most powerful party gatherings, with the right to elect the Central Committee and party leadership, and change the party's rules and program. In the past, however, the meetings have been carefully orchestrated from the top. Gorbachev is bringing a new program and new party rules to this congress. Yeltsin, elected last month president of the Russian republic, which has 52 percent of the Soviet population and three-quarters of its territory, is a leader of the party's reform wing. Gorbachev, whose position as Soviet president would not be affected by a challenge to his party leadership, has made clear he intends to be a candidate for the top party job at the congress and has pledged to keep the party from splitting. But the main reform group within the party, Democratic Platform, has instructed its delegates to walk out of the congress if the party is not completely transformed. A majority of delegates to a Democratic Platform conference June 17 in Moscow called for forming a new political party if the Communist Party does not reform. Yeltsin, who was active in Democratic Platform before being elected Russian president, said the congress was the ``last chance for radical renewal of the party,'' and indicated he would suspend his party membership if he is dissatisfied with the results. ``If there is no such renewal ... then Yeltsin as chairman of the Supreme Soviet (of Russia) either holds up his Communist Party membership or maybe takes other steps,'' Yeltsin said. According to some reports, Politburo member Vadim Medvedev had contacted party officials in the Baltic republic of Estonia to poll them about delaying the congress.

DOC.HEAD: Disputed Van Gogh Work Withdrawn from Auction
DOC.TEXT: Sotheby's auction house pulled a painting attributed to Vincent van Gogh out of a sale Tuesday after the Amsterdam museum devoted to the artist warned it could be a fake. The small picture of a house with a red roof between trees and two figures on a path, titled ``The Steps at Auvers'' (``L'Escalier a Auvers''), had been estimated at $3.5 to $5.2 million in the Tuesday night sale of impressionist and modern art. The unidentified seller bought it in 1984 at Sotheby's for 430,000 pounds, then worth about $602,000. If it is proved to be a fake, its value would be no more than 5,000 pounds, or about $8,500, as a curiosity. As the five-year period needed for a claim has expired, the seller has no right to seek compensation from the auction house but a Sotheby's statement said: ``We do consider our moral obligations.'' There is a larger version of the disputed picture in the St. Louis Art Museum. The withdrawn work had been sold in Copenhagen in 1925 as a genuine work of the artist and scholars dated it to July 1890, shortly before van Gogh shot himself. It was exhibited as his work in Tokyo in 1985. But experts at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam recently cast doubt on its authenticity. As a result, Sotheby's said, they were withdrawing it from sale pending further research. This year is the centenary of van Gogh's death and all his work is being subjected to close scrutiny. Fakes of his art first appeared in Paris soon after the turn of the century. Van Gogh never sold a picture in his lifetime but he has become the most popular artist ever known. In 1987, his paintings of sunflowers and irises set world art auction records and on May 15, his portrait of a doctor who had treated him for mental illness received a new record price of $82.5 million in New York. The buyer was a Japanese industrialist Ryoei Saito. When the two-day Sotheby's sale of impressionist and modern art started Tuesday, Seibu, the Japanese store chain, paid $3.14 million for a set of 42 colored lithographs by Marc Chagall. The company said the price was an auction record for a set of prints. The works illustrated the pastoral romance of a goatherd and a shepherdess, ``Daphnis and Chloe,'' attributed to the third century Greek writer, Longus. The set of 42 lithographs was published in Paris in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Additional $11 Million Reallocated for WIC Food Program
DOC.TEXT: An additional $11 million has been reallocated to 46 states for a special supplemental food program for women, infants and children, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. About half the states have been running out of money for WIC, as the program is called. Higher food costs, especially for dairy and citrus products, were said to be the main factors. Officials said the department regularly reallocates unspent and carryover WIC funds to states in need. ``Many states have managed their WIC caseloads carefully enough that they aren't having any budgetary problems,'' said Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the department's Food and Nutrition Service. ``Others have had to economize ... by choosing less expensive but nutritious foods,'' she said. Nationwide, the reallocated money will allow states to provide an additional 300,000 food packages to participants over the final three months of this fiscal year, Nelsen said. The funds will be available to states July 1 and will supplement more than $2 billion allocated for WIC in the current fiscal year that began Oct. 1. More than 4.5 million women, infants and children participate.

DOC.HEAD: City Council Scales Back Generous Homeless Policy
DOC.TEXT: City council members voted Tuesday to end one of the nation's most generous municipal policies for the homeless in an effort to control a budget crisis that could leave the District of Columbia with a $95 million budget deficit. The council voted to stop immediately providing unlimited shelter to the homeless. The legislation now goes to Mayor Marion Barry for his approval. The vote scaled back an initiative that had passed with more than 70 percent of the vote in 1984. It guaranteed overnight shelter for any homeless person who requested it. The new policy authorizes the city to restrict annual spending for shelter, limit the number of nights individuals and families can stay at the shelters and require people with money to help defray the cost of finding permanent housing for themselves. The city was expected to spend $40 million on the homeless this year, or about $15 million more than originally budgeted. The cost of implementing the law has nearly tripled, from $10 million in fiscal 1985 to $27 million in fiscal 1988. Tuesday's decision angered homeless advocates, who said they planned to file suit against the city. ``I think whoever voted for this thing should be run out of town,'' advocate Mitch Snyder said. ``This is going to put thousands of people out on the streets.'' If shelter money is exhausted before the end of the budget year, the mayor could transfer money from other city accounts, but he would not be required to do so. The Barry administration is facing a budget deficit of about $95 million for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. The mayor has proposed that 26,000 city workers be furloughed for four days each, that services be cut and that new taxes be enacted.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Testify That Weedkillers May be More Harmful Than Thought
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Garry in 7th graf and Shelia in 10th graf are cq
DOC.TEXT: Farmers and homeowners frequently use weedkillers that contain a key ingredient of Agent Orange that may be more harmful than previously thought, scientists told a congressional panel Tuesday. ``It appears to me that there are other contaminants in herbicides, as well as herbicides per se, which have not been adequately evaluated for carcinogenicity in animals let alone studied for their effect ... in humans,'' Daniel Thau Teitelbaum, a Denver physician, told a House Government Operations subcommittee. Teitelbaum studied industry records as part of the class-action lawsuit by Vietnam veterans against the makers of Agent Orange. In the 20 years of controversy surrounding whether the government should pay benefits to ailing Vietnam veterans who were exposed to Agent Orange, attention has focused on dioxin contamination 2,4,5-T _ one of the herbicide's two key ingredients. The Environmental Protection Agency has labeled dioxin a ``probable human carcinogen'' and 2,4,5-T has been out of circulation for years. But scientists told the subcommittee that the other key ingredient _ 2,4-D _ causes cancers and other ailments linked to Agent Orange. Evidence shows that 2,4-D was also contaminated with harmful compounds, some related to dioxin, according to testimony on the government handling of Agent Orange research. The farm-chemical industry says ongoing research into 2,4-D is needed but that the ``weight of the evidence'' so far indicates the risk of harm is relatively small if it does indeed exist, industry spokesman Garry Hamlin said in a telephone interview from Indianapolis. A so-called phenoxy herbicide, 2,4-D is sold over the counter to kill dandelions and other lawn weeds. Farmers use it against weeds in corn, wheat, rice and sorghum. Teitelbaum, noting that use of 2,4,5-T was first discontinued because of concern about birth defects, said studies were needed on possible birth defects resulting from 2,4-D exposure. Two National Cancer Institute studies have shown an increased risk of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a rare cancer, in ``frequent users of agriculture chemicals,'' said NCI researcher Shelia Hoar Zahm. The studies of farm workers in Kansas and Nebraska found that the risk grows or drops according to skin exposure and how soon after exposure the worker changed clothes. Vietnam veterans were exposed to Agent Orange in concentrations far in excess of the normal strength, special adviser Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. has told the Veterans Affairs Department. The department said this year it would compensate veterans for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and for another rare cancer _ soft tissue sarcoma. However, the government maintains that exposure can't be documented. Zumwalt, a retired admiral, ordered Agent Orange sprayed in Vietnam to clear dense jungle. His son, who served in Vietnam, later died of cancer, which Zumwalt attributes to Agent Orange. he said 27 ailments can be linked to Agent Orange. Zumwalt, appearing before the subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations, reiterated his contention that government and industry officials ``intentionally manipulated or withheld compelling information on the adverse health effects associated with exposure to the toxic contaminants contained in Agent Orange.'' In a related matter, Rep. Ted R. Weiss, D-N.Y., said his subcommittee had forced the Air Force to release a 4-year-old draft report showing an increase of birth defects among the offspring of those who handled and sprayed Agent Orange from the air. Patti Turner, a spokeswoman for the Air Force Surgeon General's office, said the conclusions were premature.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Says Bush Did Not Tell Truth on Taxes
Retransmitting to fix cycle designator
With AM-Bush-Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, awash in budget woes, had a rueful response to President Bush's concession Tuesday that tax increases were needed to shrink the federal budget. ``I told the truth and I paid the price,'' said Dukakis. ``Mr. Bush did not and we're all now going to have to pay the price for that.'' Bush, who made ``read my lips _ no new taxes'' a hallmark of his 1988 campaign against Dukakis, released a statement Tuesday that a ``tax revenue increase'' was necessary to battle the budget deficit. Dukakis, who said during the campaign he would raise taxes as a last resort, has been fighting to raise taxes to bridge a state budget gap now estimated at more than $1 billion. ``This is going to be a long and difficult process for the president and the Congress and they're going to have to go through what, whether we like it or not, we've had to go through in the past year and a half,'' Dukakis said. Dukakis' political popularity in his own state has plunged since the presidential campaign. Massachusetts revenues have decline steadily, and the state's bond rating has fallen to the lowest in the nation, due largely to political paralysis over the issue of raising taxes. Standard & Poors last week put the state on credit watch, warning that its bond rating could fall to junk bond status if fiscal problems are not quickly resolved. Although the fiscal year ends in four days, the Massachusetts House and Senate have so fair failed to agree on either a tax plan or a budget for fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Producers Get Preview Of Opposition To Import Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Sugar producers got a taste on Tuesday of the debate that can be expected on the House floor when urban lawmakers attack what they see as an overly protective U.S. sugar policy in the 1990 farm bill. ``You have gotten away with murder, and I don't blame you for wanting to continue it,'' Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., told a gathering of the American Sugar Alliance. He and Rep. Willis Gradison, R-Ohio, want a 10 percent reduction in the government guaranteed sugar price. They say beet and cane farmers should prepare themselves for changes in world trade that will eventually lead to even greater adjustments in the program. The sugar program is bitterly opposed by manufacturers of candy, baked goods, soft drinks and other sweets because it prevents cheaper world-priced sugar from being sold in the United States. In defense of government sugar support, House Agriculture sugar subcommittee chairman Jerry Huckaby, D-La., said it keeps prices stable and predictable for sweets manufacturers. It is necessary to compete with more heavily subsidized sugar from Europe, he said. The world market is a ``dump market,'' said Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn. ranking minority member on Huckaby's subcommittee. Stangeland said sugar producing countries take what they need for themselves, sell to preferred customers at the highest rates possible and dump the rest on the world market at low prices, often subsidized by their governments. Downey and Gradison also attacked the program as bad foreign policy. It holds domestic prices at 22 cents a pound, about 9 cents more than the average world price, by controlling the amount of sugar that can be imported from sugar producing nations. Many of the countries are desperately poor but have excellent sugar-growing capacity. ``It doesn't make any sense to not allow sugar imports from countries we are paying foreign aid,'' said Downey. He said the United States should allow those countries ``to get out from us infusing them and allow them to do something productive.'' Gradison said the government's import quota program squeezes the economies of Caribbean nations, who have a better climate for sugar production than the United States. Downey and Gradison said the Bush administration has shown support for their position. Huckaby said he feared the administration saw the sugar program as something that could be traded away in exchange for concessions from other countries during international trade talks aimed at reducing subsidies worldwide. He and the other three congressmen all said it was too early to predict the outcome of the international talks, though Huckaby said ``I would be amazed if any significant agreement was reached in agriculture.'' The House and Senate are each expected to begin floor debate on the 1990 farm bill next month. Huckaby said the House and Senate sugar proposals are similar except the House would require the government to allow no less than 1.25 million tons of imported sugar in the country each year, and permit another half million tons in imports through a re-export program involving U.S. refiners. Downey and Gradison said they'll make the case on the House floor that sugar, or any agricultural product, should not be treated so differently as other goods U.S. makers sell abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Told Grand Jury He Saw Nothing `Criminal'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Barry grand jury testimony he visited Rasheeda Moore's mother, inserting 2 grafs after 18th graf, Davis Crenshaw.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry told a grand jury he had neither given nor gotten drugs from a man who later pleaded guilty to drug dealing, according to tapes played Tuesday at Barry's cocaine and perjury trial. He said he saw nothing ``unusual or criminal'' in visits to the man's hotel room. Charles Lewis testified at the trial last week that he and the mayor smoked crack cocaine on each of four Barry visits to Lewis' hotel room. The January 1989 grand jury tapes include new material as well as previously released statements _ Barry's responses to questions about whether he knew Lewis was involved with drugs, and his denials that he ever gave Lewis drugs or that Lewis gave him drugs _ that form the basis for the three felony perjury charges the mayor faces. For example, the tapes indicate that on Dec. 22, 1988, the day Barry's links to Lewis were becoming public, the mayor visited three people who law enforcement officials have said could eventually be called to testify about his alleged drug use. Barry testified before the grand jury in two appearances a few weeks after a police operation aimed at Lewis was called off when city officers learned Barry was with him at a downtown hotel. Since that episode, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin asked Barry during the grand jury proceeding, ``have you talked with anyone or has anyone come to your attention who you believe has information about Charles Lewis' connection with narcotics or drugs of any kind?'' ``No ... I had gotten the feeling, again, just an impression from having known him over the years, having seen him in the Virgin Islands, that one, Chuck Lewis was not a drug dealer and two, I didn't get the impression that he used drugs,'' Barry said. When asked by Retchin whether he had ever given Lewis ``anything of value,'' Barry responded, ``No. If you're getting at _ I've never given Mr. Lewis any cocaine or any other drugs. Announce that right up front.'' In addition to the perjury felony charges, Barry, 54, also has been charged with 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy count. He has pleaded innocent to all 14 charges. His taped testimony differed from Lewis' version on minor as well as major points. For example, Barry said his Dec. 19, 1988, visit with Lewis lasted an hour or less. Lewis testified that he and the mayor smoked crack cocaine well into Dec. 20 and long past the end of the Monday night football game they had been watching. Also, Barry told the grand jury he thought his first visit to Lewis' hotel room in Washington took place on Dec. 17, while Lewis testified it was a day earlier. ``Was there anything unusual about the (Dec. 17) visit?'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Retchin asked Barry during his grand jury testimony. ``Not that was unusual or criminal,'' replied the mayor. In a Jan. 24 1989, grand jury session, Barry also described how he attempted to handle revelations that he had paid repeated visits to Lewis' hotel room. The mayor detailed a telephone conversation with top police officials, and said he met a man _ now considered a possible witness against him _ who noted the mayor's anxiety about the situation. Barry told the grand jury he first learned of the developing revelations from one of his security guards while he was visiting the hotel room of Willie Davis, a former aide to Birmingham, Ala., Mayor Richard Arrington. Barry also said he had spent 45 minutes alone that day in the Washington hotel room of Doris Crenshaw. He testified he visited the hotel room of Davis before traveling to an official function and then to the Georgetown restaurant of Hassan Mohammadi. Mohammadi ``recognized I was very upset about this whole thing that had gone on that night,'' Barry said on the tape. Davis, Crenshaw and Mohammadi are considered potential witnesses at the trial, according to law enforcement sources who have commented only on condition they not be named. Barry also testified that on that same day he visited church organist Mary Moore. She is the mother of Rasheeda Moore, who later cooperated in the FBI sting that led to his arrest at a Washington hotel. In his grand jury testimony, Barry said he chatted for about 30 minutes with the elder Moore, then had his security guard drive her to a prayer meeting at her church while he talked with her son and waited for the car to return. The grand jury tapes also reveal that it was Barry who first brought up the subject of drugs while answering questions about his relationship with Lewis, a former city employee. Barry told the grand jury that Lewis mentioned the term ``working 50'' in casual conversation and that the mayor thought the words had something to do with ``hot clothes ... prostitution or drugs.'' ``It just popped out'' of Lewis' mouth, ``I didn't pursue it,'' the mayor told the grand jury. Lewis testified last week that a ``working 50'' is a bundle of crack cocaine that retails on the streets of Washington for $50.

DOC.HEAD: Great Plains Wind Erosion Down
DOC.TEXT: Wind erosion in the Great Plains dropped sharply this season because of improved moisture conditions in much of the region, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Wilson Scaling, chief of the department's Soil Conservation Service, said an estimated 7.8 million acres were damaged by wind in the 10 states that make up the Great Plains, down 45 percent from 14.3 million acres in 1988-89. The agency measures wind damage during a seven-month season that runs from November 1 through May 31, when winds are usually the strongest and soils the driest. The survey covers 541 counties in the 10 states. ``Most of this decrease is the result of precipitation in Colorado and Kansas, where land damaged from wind decreased from 6.5 million acres last year to 463,000 acres this year for the two states,'' Scaling said. The greatest damage was in North Dakota, in its third year of severe drought, he said. The state reported 2.9 million acres damaged this season, compared with 2.3 million last year and a record 3.5 million acres in 1987-88. North Dakota accounted for more than one-third of the total wind erosion in the 10-state region. Kansas, after setting a record with 5.1 million acres damaged last year (largely due to a one-day storm that damaged nearly 4.8 million acres), reported only 190,000 damaged this season. The least damage was in Nebraska, with 130,000 acres damaged, compared with 192,000 last year. Officials said the record for land damaged by wind in the Great Plains was 15.3 million acres in 1954-55, the year that the agency began annual records. According to the survey, the state-by-state breakdown comparing wind-damaged acres in 1989-90 with damage in 1988-89, included: _Colorado, 273,731 and 1,403,655. _Kansas, 189,600 and 5,126,250. _Montana, 1,249,665 and 1,832,025. _Nebraska, 130,115 and 191,605. _New Mexico, 248,500 and 117,950. _North Dakota, 2,932,687 and 2,297,681. _Oklahoma, 136,800 and 111,930. _South Dakota, 601,830 and 678,550. _Texas, 1,668,000 and 1,979,626. _Wyoming, 407,550 and 552,680.

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota Town Remembers King of the Bubbly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with ceremony held; picks up 3rd graf pvs, ``Little did...'' ^LaserPhoto BI1
DOC.TEXT: The farm where Lawrence Welk learned to play the accordion became center stage Tuesday for a project to create a museum honoring the king of champagne music. About 100 people gathered to hear bands play German polkas, waltzes and marches, and Gov. George Sinner planted a tree during a groundbreaking ceremony at the farm where Welk lived until he was 21. Sinner said Welk symbolizes the talent of the descendants of the Germans who came to North Dakota 100 years ago. ``They are people who work hard and play hard,'' Sinner said. ``They are people who believe that artistic ability is at its best when it is for the common people.'' The bandleader himself, now 87 and living in Los Angeles, did not attend but sent a letter of thanks. ``Little did I dream when I was growing up on the farm so many, many years ago that someday it would be restored and people would come and marvel at how life was lived in the early 1920s,'' Welk wrote. ``Looking back, I would say that life on the farm was very hard and I didn't always like it _ especially when I had to help butcher the hogs. But they were really happy days, too, because there was always love.'' The farm has been vacant since 1966. But folks in this town of 600 _ about 75 miles south of Bismarck _ decided to refurbish the farm to chronicle Welk's achievements and the history of his German-Russian ancestors. Carpenters have finished rebuilding a granary and a buggy house, a summer kitchen and the outhouse on the farm where Welk's parents came from Russia in 1893. Renovation work is under way on the 25-by 28-foot sod house built by Welk's father at the turn of the century. And a barn that was not part of the original farm is being turned into a museum of German-Russian immigration. The cost of the project is estimated at $750,000, including $500,000 for a trust to maintain the museum after it opens. Welk Heritage Inc., which is coordinating the restoration, has raised $150,000, including $80,000 from Welk's foundation in California. It hopes to collect the rest from grants and donations. Sharon Eiseman, a spokeswoman for Welk Heritage, said plenty of visitors are expected. Strasburg bills itself as the gateway to South Dakota's Black Hills. ``During the summer we have 1,000 to 1,100 cars a day going through here, down to South Dakota and back up to Canada,'' Eiseman said. One recent visitor was the Rev. John Nieuwsma of Holland, Mich., who stopped at the farm with his sisters to reminisce about growing up in the area. ``Lawrence is older than we are but we used to go to town on Saturday night and peek through the windows of the Blue Room and see him playing with the Hotsy Totsy Boys,'' Nieuwsma recalled. ``Back there in the haymow, that's where he practiced his accordion until he left,'' Nieuwsma said. ``Lawrence never wanted to be a farmer but he made a deal with his father that he'd work on the farm until he was 21, in return for a $400 accordion.'' Welk kept his part of the bargain _ and went on to one of the country's most successful bandleaders. He formed his own band in 1927 and got his start in radio at WNAX in Yankton, S.D. The band was known as ``The Honolulu Fruit Gum Orchestra'' and ``Lawrence Welk and his Hotsy Totsy Boys,'' and played at area ballrooms for several years in the late 1920s and early 1930s. ``He started out with polkas and waltzes,'' Eiseman said. ``It's just the general heritage around here. Everybody plays polkas and waltzes.'' In the late 1930s, the band traveled east to the William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh, where ``Champagne Music'' was born. Welk then made his headquarters in the Chicago area in the 1940s, and became a national television hit in the late 1950s, first as a summer replacement and then as a regularly weekly show. His syndicated television show, now in reruns, is still a favorite among North Dakotans on Saturday nights.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Carries `Message Of Peace' to White House
DOC.TEXT: Egypt sent its foreign minister to the White House on Tuesday with a ``message of peace'' and this advice: Talk to the PLO again. The U.S. reply, through spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, was that talks with Yasser Arafat's group had only been suspended _ not cut off forever more. To get the 18-month dialogue resumed, all Arafat has to do is punish the perpetrators of the attempted May 30 assault on Tel Aviv and denounce it as well, U.S. officials said. As for the message carried by Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid, the Egyptian emissary declined to provide any details, and Fitzwater and other U.S. officials were not filling in the information blanks. But Abdel-Meguid provided a couple of clues after he saw Secretary of State James A. Baker III at the State Department. He said it was up to Israel to get the stalled process going, and that Egypt was willing to resume its role of conduit to the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``If this can help, if the parties are ready,'' the foreign minister told reporters. ``I think the Palestinians are certainly part of the peace process and this has been known since the peace process started,'' Abdel-Meguid said. At the same time, he suggested it was Israel's fault there are no negotiations in the Middle East. ``It is for Israel to respond to the peace process now,'' the foreign minister said. Egypt, working with the PLO, helped arrange the formula that Baker presented to Israel in March. It provided for talks between Israel and Palestinians in Cairo. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who proposed Palestinian elections last year, resisted provisions to include Palestinians deported from the West Bank and others with homes in East Jerusalem in the negotiations. The Israeli Cabinet collapsed under the strain. This month Shamir formed a new government and Bush has written to ask the prime minister what his intentions are for dealing with Palestinians. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Tuesday that Shamir had not replied. Nor has the Bush administration invited the new Israeli foreign minister, David Levy, to Washington for talks. Fitzwater said Bush's meeting with Abdel-Meguid focused on the peace process and on Bush's decision to suspend the 18-month U.S. dialogue with the PLO. ``The president made two essential points in the discussion,'' the spokesman said. ``First, that the United States is committed to continuing the peace process and we want to work as best we can to get a dialogue going that will help resolve those issues. ``Secondly, the president reiterated that his action with regard to the PLO was a suspension of our dialogue and that we continue to look to the PLO to make those actions and statements that would allow us to resume a dialogue at some point in the future,'' Fitzwater said. In the foiled raid, two speedboats crammed with Palestinian guerrillas were spotted by radar and intercepted by the Israeli navy before they could reach the Tel Aviv beach. Four of the guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. Abul Abbas, a member of the PLO's Executive Committee, claimed responsibility for the attack. The Bush administration wants Arafat to punish him, but so far there is no sign the chairman will act against the head of the Palestine Liberation Front.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Lithuanian Leader Asks Council to Freeze Its Independence Move
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister told parliament Tuesday that breaking away from the Soviet Union would be impossible without a compromise with the Kremlin, and asked the Lithuanian Supreme Council to freeze its declaration of independence. Kazimiere Prunskiene said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed in a telephone call earlier in the day that in return for a temporary suspension of its March 11 independence declaration, he would end the nine-week-old economic embargo against the breakaway Baltic republic. Gorbachev also said he would begin negotiations that ``will discuss a different status for Lithuania, including as an independent state,'' the prime minister said. There was no confirmation from Soviet officials of Mrs. Prunskiene's claim that Gorbachev had softened his position on independence. The only statement from Moscow about Lithuania was more toughly worded. Mrs. Prunskiene argued that Lithuania will not escape the economic blockade imposed in April by the Kremlin, take control of its borders, or be free of Soviet Army soldiers without compromising. ``We need negotiations,'' she said. ``We don't have a magic wand to solve these problems.'' Mrs. Prunskiene also hinted the future of her government _ including her own possible resignation _ may depend on how the Supreme Council parliament reacts to the proposed compromise. ``Maybe a new government could find some such solution,'' she said. Lithuania, a republic of 3.8 million people, and its parliament are divided over whether to accept a compromise with Moscow over the declaration of independence. Gorbachev met with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis in Moscow on Tuesday morning, then telephoned Mrs. Prunskiene two hours later in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius to offer what the prime minister described to parliament as a softening of his position. Mrs. Prunskiene said she was optimistic a compromise would lead to Lithuanian independence in part because Gorbachev in the telephone conversation did not repeat his demand that the republic ``return to March 10'' _ once again act as a Soviet republic rather than an independent state. She argued that that amounts to willingness to negotiate with Lithuania as a sovereign state, and recognition of its declaration of independence. But the Soviet news agency Tass, quoting what it said was an official report on the meeting with Landsbergis, said the Lithuanian president was told talks can only be held ``if Lithuania declares a moratorium and suspends the act of March 11 for a period of talks. They can be held only in the context of an inter-republican dialogue on the preparation of a new union treaty and the formation of a union of sovereign socialists states.'' Landsbergis did not give the parliament a clear account of his meeting with Gorbachev, but said he came away from it with a much better idea of what was acceptable to the Soviet leader. He said he may return to Moscow on Wednesday if more discussions are necessary. Committees of the Supreme Council will meet on Wednesday to discuss 10 versions of the compromise. The full parliament is to discuss them Thursday. Landsbergis said Gorbachev reviewed eight of the 10 options during the meeting. Unlike Mrs. Prunskiene, Landsbergis made no appeal for acceptance of the compromise in his speech to parliament. The Lithuanian president said he was simply offering a draft for discussion. Top Soviet officials also reportedly were debating whether to delay the critical national Communist Party Congress, scheduled to open July 2. Gorbachev might face a challenge to his leadership from traditional Soviet communists at the meeting, and a walkout by progressives. Lithuanian officials said privately a sharp debate was going on in the republic on how their drive for independence would be affected by the congress and its effect on Gorbachev's power. The Lithuanians indicated they do not know if they should accept the compromise while Gorbachev is strong enough to offer it, or hold out for possible victory by reformers who support the republic's right to independence. The Kremlin cut off all oil, most natural gas and some other raw materials to the republic in nine weeks ago in an attempt to force it to rescind the declaration of independence. Mrs. Prunskiene said Western powers want Lithuania to negotiate and reduce the tension between East and West caused by the confrontation. A small group of foreign correspondents was allowed back into the republic for the first time in weeks on Tuesday. The Soviet Foreign Ministry has been barring correspondents from traveling to Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Bouncing Baby Bengal Meets the Press
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT that this was not tiger's first meeting with journalists. Picks up 6th graf pvs `Then, the ...'
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto WX14
DOC.TEXT: The world's first test-tube tiger cub pounced and growled during her National Zoo debut Tuesday before settling down with a big bottle of milk. The 20-pound bouncing Bengal is one of a litter of three cubs produced by in vitro fertilization in an effort to save endangered tiger species. Mary Alice, the only surviving cub, was born by Caesarean section April 27. ``This is a marvelous step forward for all those cats on the verge of extinction,'' said Michael Robinson, director of the National Zoo. ``In 20 years of our lifetime, we have lost three subspecies of tigers.'' During a meetings with journalists, Mary Alice fussed and squirmed until her keeper stuck a milk bottle in her mouth. Then, the yellow-and-black cub stood up on her hind legs, grasped the bottle with her front paws, closed her eyes and sucked aggressively until her chin was covered with milk. Mary Alice is expected to weigh about 300 pounds when she is fully grown. A second yellow-and-black cub died of pneumonia three weeks after birth, but zoo officials said the death was not related to the in vitro procedure. The third cub, a white tiger, died shortly after birth. The surrogate mother, Nicole, a 9{-year-old Siberian tiger is from the Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha, Neb. A male tiger named Chester provided the sperm that scientists used to fertilize three eggs taken from two other tigers. Mary Alice eventually will be housed at the Omaha zoo. Of the 37 species of felines, all but the domestic cat are threatened or endangered, according to the National Zoo's Center for New Opportunities in Animal Health Sciences. That means a species is either dying out or not reproducing rapidly enough to survive long-term. Since 1969, three subspecies of tigers have become extinct and the South China tiger is critically endangered, with only 50 remaining in the world. There are more tigers in the world's zoos than there are in the wild _ 31 black-footed cats; 21 sand cats; and 12 pallas cats in zoos, according to center officials. ``Sometimes people use the words `captive' and `research' as four-letter words,'' said Lee Simmons, director of the Omaha zoo. ``This animal's relatives are captive in Siberia and other countries,'' he said. ``The habitats for many animals are in isolated enclaves.'' When tigers' natural habitats are destroyed, they are limited to a small area, isolated from other tiger species in their home countries. While kept in a small area, tigers inbreed, not producing new genetic material, which causes extinction, Simmons said. National Zoo officials said in vitro fertilization helps conserve rare tiger species by allowing animals that are sexually incompatible or separated by long distances to reproduce. Mary Alice is named after the wife of Ulysses Seal, a major participant in programs to conserve tigers in zoos, Simmons said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Deny Removing Nuclear Weapons from Baltic Republics
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Tuesday denied reports it is shifting nuclear warheads out of its rebellious Baltic and southern republics and into less volatile regions. ``As they told us in the Defense Ministry press center, there is no need to remove Soviet troops with nuclear weapons around the Soviet Union, so no unscheduled movements have been made,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov told a regular briefing. U.S. officials and private specialists said last week that the Soviets were moving nuclear warheads out of the Baltics and southern republics, including Armenia and Azerbaijan. The U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the moves reflected Moscow's concerns about nationalist and ethnic tensions that could lead to attempts by rebel forces to take control of a nuclear weapons storage depot. Stephen Meyer, an authority on the Soviet military and a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said last week that Soviet government officials had told him recently they were consolidating their weapon storage sites for security reasons. ``This is a very touchy subject for them,'' Meyer said. Meyer said it seemed from his conversations with Soviet officials that the warhead removal started after a flare-up of violence in January between armed Azerbaijani and Armenian groups around Baku, a city where some nuclear warheads are believed to be stored. Moscow sent Russian airborne units to stop the fighting, but isolated attacks on military units in that area reportedly have continued. Meyer said the consolidation involves not only nuclear warheads but also conventional armaments. He likened the move to an American decision in the 1970s to reduce the number of nuclear warhead storage sites in Western Europe in response to a rise in terrorist threats against U.S. installations.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Ship Rams Drilling Platform in the North Sea, 12 Rescued
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers on Tuesday saved 12 crew members of an Italian ship that rammed a North Sea drilling platform, Dutch Television reported. The accident caused no major damage to the platform, but the Arcola supply ship sustained major damage and was in danger of sinking, according to the television report. The Dutch Coast Guard and other ships in the area helped rescue the entire crew without incident, the report said. Salvage crews were preparing to tow the wreck to port from the accident site 45 miles west of the Dutch island of Texel.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Leaders More Focused On Change Than Violence With Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights leaders who worked with Martin Luther King Jr. say they support Nelson Mandela in his effort to liberate South Africa's blacks despite his refusal to renounce violence as King did. Mandela is to visit the King Center for Nonviolent Social Change on Wednesday to lay a wreath at King's tomb. He is to meet with King's widow, Coretta Scott King, and the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the King-founded Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Civil rights leaders in Atlanta generally have said it is more important to liberate South African blacks than to insist on following King's staunch policy of non-violence. ``As an advocate of non-violence, I am very concerned about violence. But violence has a lot of ramifications,'' Lowery said in an interview after a recent trip to South Africa. ``There is state violence in South Africa, which makes it difficult for blacks to commit themselves to non-violence. The government has not renounced violence. ``We are more than anxious to be helpful,'' Lowery said. ``If our experiences in desegregation can be helpful, we will offer them.'' Mrs. King has said more attention is paid to Mandela's position on violence than is to the South African government's acts of violence against blacks. In a newspaper column, she said that as chairwoman of the Mandela visit host committee she would like to show the 71-year-old African National Congress leader ``the city of Atlanta's impressive spirit of interracial cooperation.'' ``There are some differences in every revolution, but I have to advocate non-violence. I've seen the results,'' said the Rev. Hosea Williams, King's field lieutenant during the 1960s. ``Right now, if the blacks in South Africa could overcome apartheid with violence, they would still be sitting ducks for violence against them. ``I would tell Mr. Mandela to please study and evaluate the teachings of Martin Luther King Jr. before deciding that violence is the only way to bring about needed social change,'' Williams said. As a young Baptist minister, King led bus boycotts in Montgomery, Ala., in 1955, and was successful in achieving integration of the city's public transportation system without violence. He founded the SCLC in 1957, and dedicated the group to fighting for social change through peaceful means. King advocated worldwide economic sanctions against South Africa as a means of destroying apartheid, and in a 1964 speech on the South African situation said ``we can understand how in that situation people felt so desperate that they turned to other methods, such as sabotage.'' At the time of his death, King was greatly troubled by a trend among black youth to embrace violence. Mandela helped found and launch the ANC's guerrilla campaign after the group was banned in 1960. He was arrested in 1962 and in 1964 was sentenced to life in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow South Africa's white government. While on trial, Mandela said the ANC had no choice but to wage an armed struggle because the group had been outlawed. Mandela and the organization continue to support armed struggle, saying it is necessary to keep pressure on the government. On Tuesday, speaking to a joint session of Congress, Mandela did not directly restate his position that violence is a necessary tool in battling apartheid. But he pointed to the South African government's oppression of the black majority. ``For those who care to worry about violence in our country as we do, it is at these forces that they should focus their attention,'' Mandela said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Young Men Likelier Homicide Victims Than Other Nationalities
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Young men in the United States are more than four times as likely to be homicide victims than those in 21 other industrialized countries, according to a study released Tuesday. In 1987, there were 4,223 male homicide victims aged 15 to 24 in the United States, or 21.9 for every 100,000 men in that age group, researchers said in an article in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association. The country with the next highest rate was Scotland with 22 victims, or 5.0 for every 100,000 men in the same category. Austria's 0.3 was the lowest rate. ``If the U.S. homicide rate could be reduced to the next highest rate, more than 3,000 lives would be saved'' each year, wrote Lois Fingerhut and Joel Kleinman of the federal National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md. While there is no clear reason for the wide differences, ``we have to look at the availability of firearms,'' said Fingerhut in a telephone interview from Hyattsville. The researchers found that 75 percent of the U.S. deaths were caused by guns. France was second with 54 percent. The researchers used the latest available figures for each of the 21 countries; most were for 1987 but some were for 1986 or 1985. A spokesman for the National Rifle Association in Washington, Tom Wyld, said the NRA wouldn't comment without studying the article. But James Wright, a Tulane University sociologist who specializes in criminology, noted that the Swiss own guns and have almost no history of violence. ``But they do emphasize responsible firearm ownership much more than we do,'' he said. According to the NCHS study, only one of 14 homicides in Switzerland was by firearm. ``And, if you subtract all the firearm homicides, we're still killing loads more people than any other country,'' Wright said from his office in New Orleans. Homicides in the United States in 1987 not involving firearms outnumbered annual murder totals in all 21 other countries combined by more than 3-to-1 (1,036 to 308), according to the study. ``The argument has been made that comparisons of homicide in the United States and other countries are not valid because the United States has such a heterogeneous population,'' the researchers said. But they point to Ohio, whose black and metropolitan percentages mirror the entire United States, but whose homicide rates for both blacks and whites are less than half the national average. Fingerhut said the research focused on the 15-to-24 age group because 20 percent of all U.S. homicides occurred in this age group, and because Public Health Service objectives include a sharp reduction in homicides, especially among black males. When comparisions were made for the total population, the U.S. rate, 8.7 per 100,000, was still 2.6 times higher than the next highest rate, Finland, with 3.3 per 100,000. The U.S. rate among black males 15 to 24 was 85.6 per 100,000, more than seven times this nation's rate for young white males. But the rate for white males alone, 11.2, was still more than twice the rate in Scotland, the study found. ``In the United States, homicide is the leading cause of death among black males aged 15 to 24 years and the third leading cause (after motor vehicle injuries and suicide) among white males 15 through 24 years of age,'' the researchers wrote in the Chicago-based JAMA.

DOC.SECOND: U.S. Estimates 1,000 to 2,000 Chinese Still Detained
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Tuesday estimated there still are 1,000 to 2,000 Chinese in prison after Beijing's crackdown last year on the pro-democracy movement. U.S. officials have been telling the Chinese that ``we hope the names of all those released will be made available, and that China will provide an accounting of all those who remain in detention,'' said department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``Our best guess is that probably up to 1,000, perhaps 2,000, remain in prison, but I must caution you that we do not have accurate information,'' Ms. Tutwiler told reporters. She noted the Chinese have officially declared that fewer than 400 people remain in detention, while Amnesty International, a human rights organization, estimates that 650 are still in prison. Others have reported higher numbers of prisoners. China has announced three releases of prisoners, Ms. Tutwiler said, one in January of 573 people, one in May of 211 and a third in June of 97. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon testified before a congressional panel earlier this month that at least 2,000 remained in custody out of the 15,000 arrested in last summer's violent upheaval. The number of those killed has been estimated in the hundreds or thousands.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Net $10.8 Million In Armored Car Heist
With BC-Robbery-List
LaserGraphic, LaserPhoto ROC1
DOC.TEXT: Robbers with a shotgun ambushed an armored car whose crew had stopped to buy sandwiches and stole more than $10 million cash Tuesday in one of the largest heists in U.S. history, authorities said. The Armored Motor Service of America Inc. truck was headed to the Federal Reserve Bank branch in Buffalo when the robbery occurred, the Monroe County Sheriff's Department said. The truck's driver and guard were bound and gagged but were not injured. ``We don't have an exact amount,'' Sheriff Andrew P. Meloni said. ``It's in the neighborhood of $10.8 million.'' He said authorities have no suspects. Meloni said officials have not yet determined where the money came from. The largest reported robbery from a U.S. armored car company was in 1982, when $11 million was taken from the Sentry Armored Car Courier Co. in New York City. But authorities have since said much of the missing money may have been previously embezzled. In 1985, nearly $8 million was stolen from a Wells Fargo depot in Manhattan. In 1983, robbers took gold estimated to be worth up to $11 million from a smelting firm and jewelry wholesaler in North Miami, Fla. FBI spokesman Bill Carter said armored car robberies are usually larger than bank robberies. The AMSA truck left the company's offices in the Rochester suburb of Chili about 7 a.m. Tuesday with a male driver and a female guard aboard, sheriff's department spokesman Tom Ryan said. The employees' names have not been released. They stopped at a store nearby and the guard left the truck to buy coffee and sandwiches, Ryan said. While the woman was in the store, a man stuck a shotgun in the slot of the armored car and took control of the vehicle, Meloni said. When the woman returned to the car, she also was placed under the gunman's control. Ryan said investigators believe at least one other person was involved in the robbery. The employees said they could not give a good description of the robbers because they were told not to turn around, he said. The employees were ordered to drive to a wooded area in the town of Henrietta, about half a mile from the convenience store, where they were tied up, blindfolded and gagged. The robbers transferred the money bags, weighing at least 1,600 pounds, from the armored car to another vehicle and drove off, Ryan said. The AMSA employees were able to free themselves within 15 minutes, drove back to the company headquarters and reported the robbery. It was the second multimillion-dollar heist AMSA has suffered in the past 13 months. In May 1989, $2.9 million was stolen from an AMSA truck in East Syracuse. Two men drove a one-ton truck through an overhead garage door and pistol-whipped two guards in that robbery. Two suspects are now on trial in federal court in Syracuse. One of the security guards involved pleaded guilty last year to taking part in the robbery. Meloni would not comment on whether Tuesday's robbery could have been an inside job. ``There are a lot of questions, obviously, about the manner of the heist,'' Meloni said. ``It appeared to be well-planned.'' Meloni said sheriff's officials and the FBI are looking for witnesses, reviewing the company's records and questioning the two employees. He said he could not comment on whether the employees' actions followed company policy. He said one of the robbed employees had worked at AMSA for 6 months and the other for a year. The Federal Reserve Bank branch in Buffalo supplies coin and currency to banks throughout the region. Banks in turn send surplus money to the Federal Reserve for storage. The branch manager, James Aston, said loss or theft of money headed for the Federal Reserve would be covered under an agreement between the banks and the carrier, Aston said. ``Typically, the carrier is insured,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Flag-Burning Amendment in Largely Symbolic Vote
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; SUBS 3rd graf: ``The Senate,'' with party breakdown; SUBS 5th graf: ``But the,'' with last week's House tally. FYI a roll call will move
DOC.TEXT: The Senate rejected a constitutional amendment against flag burning Tuesday with critics arguing that it was already dead and being debated largely as ammunition for use against them at election time. ``We will take a meaningless vote so that some campaign operatives can try to bludgeon senators who are willing to stand up for the Bill of Rights and vote against this amendment,'' Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, declared. The Senate voted 58-42 in favor, leaving it nine short of the required two-thirds majority needed to approve amendments. Thirty-eight Republicans voted in favor and seven voted against; among Democrats, it was 20 in favor and 35 against. President Bush has been calling for approval of the measure, which said simply that ``Congress and the states shall have power to prohibit the physical desecration of the flag of the United States.'' But the House rejected it last week, falling 34 votes short of two-thirds with a 254-177 tally in favor. Speaker Thomas Foley said lawmakers would not get a chance to reconsider this year. The Senate's action thus was largely a symbolic gesture that gave senators a chance to vent their views on an issue that has raged in the year since the Supreme Court held unconstitutional a Texas flag-burning law. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas conceded before the vote that ``we're not going to win now.'' But he said that ``we're not going to give up and we'll see what happens in the days and weeks and months ahead.'' ``In the heartland of America, some folks just can't understand what Congress is up to,'' Dole said. Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine told lawmakers they could ``support the American flag without changing the American Constitution.'' He said it would be ``a sad irony'' to see flag burners ``stampeding those who love America into taking the unwise action of changing the Bill of Rights for the first time in our history. ``I love America and the American flag and the American Bill of Rights too much to let that happen without a fight,'' Mitchell said. Conservative supporters held out hope that if the Senate approved the amendment they could somehow revive the measure in the House, while critics said the idea was to put them on record on an emotional issue that could help their challengers. ``Stirred by fears of sound-bites and 30-second spots, members of Congress who should know better are expressing a willingness to sacrifice the Bill of Rights for what they hope will be a benefit in the polls,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. But Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., said the issue was ``so important that it should be sent to the states where the American people can decide whether they want to protect the flag.'' ``If we in the Senate pass it, I have a feeling the House will pass it,'' Thurmond said. In a dramatic switch, Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va., declared he had changed his mind since last year when he backed the constitutional amendment. Robb said that after the Supreme Court decision he as a veteran felt anger toward flag burners and ``feared the visceral outrage of most Americans.'' Robb fought in Vietnam as a Marine Corps officer. ``I have concluded that our flag can better be protected by not tinkering with the First Amendment'' to the Constitution, Robb said. Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., called for approval of the amendment, saying that ``Americanism cannot survive unless it has nationalism'' and ``Americanism is bottomed on nationalism.'' ``Americanism must have sacred symbols,'' Heflin said. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., reminded the Senate that President Woodrow Wilson had advocated a maximum of free speech to make sure that those who were fools would be exposed as such by their own words. ``Those who burn the American flag are fools; let's not dignify them by changing the Bill of Rights,'' Rudman said. Before voting on the amendment itself, the Senate rejected three rival versions. The Senate rejected, 90-10, a plan offered by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that would strip the Supreme Court of its authority to decide flag-burning cases. Helms pointed to the close 5-4 vote in the Supreme Court and said his measure was the most effective way to combat ``these kooks ... these loonies who burn the American flag.'' Critics said the Helms plan would violate long-established law giving the Supreme Court jurisdiction over constitutional issues. ``It's almost as ancient as the Republic,'' said Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn. The Senate also voted 51-48 to kill a plan offered by Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., that would replace the amendment with legislation to ban burning the flag in any way that would cause a breach of the peace. Critics said approval of the measure would make it impossible to get a vote on the amendment that had been urged by the president for a year. But Bumpers said that measure was drawn so broadly that it would cover numerous harmless uses of the flag. ``You can't buy a Coke without a reproduction of the flag on the cup,'' Bumpers said. ``Pantyhouse, swizel sticks _ everything!'' By 93-7, the Senate rejected a proposal offered by Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., that would allow Congress to ban flag burning but deny that power to the states.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvians Line Up for Bread, Gasoline as Economic Crisis Deepens
DOC.TEXT: Peruvians lined up to buy bread, gasoline and other essentials Tuesday as President-elect Alberto Fujimori prepared to travel to the United States to seek aid to cope with a deepening economic crisis. In Lima, housewives stood in block-long lines to buy bottled cooking gas. Children waited hours to buy fist-sized loaves of bread. Hundreds of taxis and buses idled near the few open gas stations. Peru's currency, the Inti, lost value by the hour. On the free market the Inti has been devalued by 48 percent in one week, and by 23 percent since Monday morning. The shortages come five weeks before Fujimori is to be sworn in as Peru's next president. Fujimori, an agronomist who was a political unknown at the start of the election campaign, defeated noted novelist Mario Vargas Llosa in the June 10 presidential runoff. On Thursday, Fujimori is scheduled to travel to New York, where he plans to visit the United Nations to seek emergency economic aid to finance food imports. He will also travel to Washington to meet with officials of the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank. He hopes to reestablish ties with international lenders that were broken by his predecessor, Alan Garcia, who limited payments on the country's $20 billion foreign debt. Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, will then travel on to Tokyo for meetings with Japanese leaders. Japan has said it is willing to resume loans to Peru if the country can show a willingness to deal with its serious social and economic problems. In Lima, the shortages have only added to the problems of the capital's 7 million residents who already suffer from daily blackouts, severe water rationing and runaway inflation. The general manager of Petroperu, the state-owned oil company, blamed the fuel shortages on panic buying and excess demand. ``Petroperu is very worried by the situation,'' Pedro Touzett told a news conference Tuesday. ``People whose gas tanks are normally half empty are trying to fill them up every night. Housewives who normally store one gallon of kerosene are storing five.'' Touzett added that the shortage of electricity had increased demand for cooking gas and gasoline to power private generators. He said the power shortages also hampered fuel distribution because gas stations cannot operate their pumps and natural gas bottlers their machinery. The Bread Industry Association attributed the bread shortages to reduced wheat imports. Peru imports all but 150,000 tons of the 1.2 million tons of wheat the country consumes each year. ``Once more we beg the government to import on a bigger scale and to do so continuously,'' Gilberto Hinojosa Teves of the Bread Industry Association told reporters Monday. But economists say that many imports have been reduced because of a lack of foreign currency. The government has been selling silver and gold to raise money. The Central Bank reserves stand at $900 million, mostly gold and silver. Centrist politician Manuel Moreyra said Monday that the rapid devaluation of the Inti was due to the government's ``unusual emission of bills as well as the uncertainty before political change.'' The country's problems have been compounded by a severe drought that has cut crop production and hydroelectric power, and attacks by Maoist Shining Path guerrillas on power lines.
