DOC.HEAD: U.S. Estimates 1,000 to 2,000 Chinese Still Detained
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Tuesday estimated there still are 1,000 to 2,000 Chinese in prison after Beijing's crackdown last year on the pro-democracy movement. U.S. officials have been telling the Chinese that ``we hope the names of all those released will be made available, and that China will provide an accounting of all those who remain in detention,'' said department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``Our best guess is that probably up to 1,000, perhaps 2,000, remain in prison, but I must caution you that we do not have accurate information,'' Ms. Tutwiler told reporters. She noted the Chinese have officially declared that fewer than 400 people remain in detention, while Amnesty International, a human rights organization, estimates that 650 are still in prison. Others have reported higher numbers of prisoners. China has announced three releases of prisoners, Ms. Tutwiler said, one in January of 573 people, one in May of 211 and a third in June of 97. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon testified before a congressional panel earlier this month that at least 2,000 remained in custody out of the 15,000 arrested in last summer's violent upheaval. The number of those killed has been estimated in the hundreds or thousands.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Announces Preliminary Owl-Saving Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs congressional reaction after 7th graf, bgng: At the xxx; SUBS 16th graf pvs, bgng: Yeutter said xxx to CORRECT figure on timber harvest; DELETES final three grafs pvs to trim.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration announced preliminary plans for saving the threatened northern spotted owl Tuesday, contending it can be done with a far-less-drastic reduction in timber cutting than government scientists say. Even so, 1,000 Northwest logging jobs would be lost. For the second time in a week, officials delayed issuing a complete proposal to support their public hopes that the bird can be saved without economically devastating the region by greatly restricting timber cutting. Tuesday's outlook from Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. was in stark contrast to estimates by government scientists that timber-cutting reductions that would cost 28,000 jobs by the end of the decade would be necessary to save the owl's habitat in the Northwest's old-growth forests. Environmental groups said in advance they would likely challenge in court any action short of that. ``Today we have set into motion a process to balance our responsibility in preserving the owl and forests while protecting the economic lives of American men and women who live and work in the region,'' Yeutter said. He said he will chair a new timber task force that will present to President Bush no later than Sept. 1 a comprehensive proposal for protecting the owl while pursuing maximum timber harvests on Forest Service lands in the Pacific Northwest. At the same time, the Cabinet secretaries also called on Congress to broaden provisions of the Endangered Species Act so that an exemption committee will have more latitude to consider the economic and social impact of protecting such wildlife. Congressional members of both parties blasted administration officials for failing to outline more specific proposals, accusing them of ducking the issue. ``These proposals are a sham, they're smoke and mirrors,'' said Rep. Bob Smith, an Oregon Republican. Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., said the administration is trying to ``throw it back to us and expect us to work miracles. ``I think they have come up with something they know is impossible but will give them a chance to dump it back on Congress,'' she said. The estimated 6,000 remaining owls were declared a threatened species under the act last week. Under the act, federal agencies are prohibited from harming the owl or its critical habitat without first receiving permission from the Fish and Wildlife Service. Lujan and Yeutter said the Bureau of Land Management will put into effect a plan that will result in the eventual loss of 1,000 jobs due to reduced timber harvests on BLM lands in Oregon and northern California. An earlier proposal by government scientists would have resulted in the loss of 7,600 jobs as a result of cutting reductions on Bureau of Land Management land and the loss of an additional 20,000 jobs by the end of the decade as a result of reductions on Forest Service land. Despite the lesser reductions, Lujan said that by careful cutting the BLM land proposal would protect 125 more pairs of owls than would the proposal offered by the government scientists led by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas. Lujan said cutting on Bureau of Land Management acreage in Oregon and northern California would be reduced from 950 million board feet annually to about 750 million board feet. The Thomas proposal would have cut harvests on the lands to less than 500 million board feet. Lujan said the Bureau of Land Management is determined to have a minimal impact on owl habitat as it seeks maximum timber harvest levels. ``We're not going to just go in there and cut willy, nilly. Any contract submitted to us must meet the test of the Fish and Wildlife Service. If we don't meet the test, we don't cut,'' he said. Yeutter said the Forest Service will operate under existing forest plans until the new timber task force can come up with an interim conservation proposal for the owl, a move that should allow the service to harvest the 3.85 billion board feet of timber mandated by Congress last year. Under the earlier recommendations of the government scientists, cutting on Forest Service lands in the region would have been reduced to between 2.3 billion and 2.5 billion board feet. Yeutter also announced for the first time publicly that the administration supports a proposal to ban exports of raw logs from state lands in Oregon and Washington as a way to offset any reduction in timber supply resulting from owl protection. The Fish and Wildlife Service last Friday announced its decision to classify the owl as a threatened species entitled to protection under the same law that has protected the grizzly bear and bald eagle. Biologists say each nesting pair of owls needs a large tract of undisturbed old-growth forest.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominated Skol As Ambassador To Venezuela
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday announced he will name government Latin affairs veteran Michael Skol to be ambassador to Venezuela. Skol is the deputy assistant secretary of State for Latin American affairs, and previously was director in the department's office of Andean affairs, minister-counselor at the U.S. Embassy in Bogota, and deputy director for Latin American affairs in the State Department's Office of Policy Planning. He served in numerous other Foreign Service and department postings. The White House also announced Bush will appoint John F.W. Rogers, executive vice president of Oliver Carr development company in Washington, as chairman of the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Groups Agree to Join Forces for Next Presidential Campaign
DOC.TEXT: France's two main rightist opposition groups agreed Tuesday to join forces for the next presidential campaign and present a single candidate to challenge the Socialists' standard-bearer. The alliance between the conservative Rally for the Republic party and the center-right coalition, the Union for French Democracy, will avoid ``fratricidal battles'' in the 1995 presidential election, said former Premier Jacques Chirac, the leader of the Rally for the Republic. The two groups decided they would form a confederation, to be called the Union for France, to field a single presidential candidate. The nominee would be chosen through a series of U.S.-style primaries culminating in a national convention. Chirac and former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, head of the Union for French Democracy, said the confederation would exclude any alliances with the extreme-right National Front or the governing Socialist Party. ``Each movement will retain its personality'' within the confederation, Chirac said. The decision was made at a lengthy meeting of a coordinating committee of the two groups, presided over by Chirac and Giscard. Polls have shown voters would prefer a single rightist candidate to counter the governing Socialists. An effort in this direction was made with the recent creation of the United Force, a grouping of personalities from the two rightist groups, some of whom would like to see a single conservative party. The Union for France would be run by a 30-member political bureau. Chirac said its goal is to present a common political agenda. ``Whatever the circumstances, this confederation will back only candidates who share the same political and moral values,'' said Chirac. Francois Leotard, leader of the Republican Party in the Union for French Democracy, denounced the confederation as too timid. A member of the United Force, Leotard said the confederation would solve neither ``disciplinary ... nor electoral'' problems, nor the problem of ``relations with public opinion.'' Socialist President Francois Mitterrand is in his second seven-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Calls Off Cleanup From Norwegian Tanker _ No Evidence of Oil
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard ended its efforts to track spilled oil from the supertanker Mega Borg after crews Tuesday failed to find any sign of the oil sheen in the Gulf of Mexico. Since Sunday, Coast Guard pilots have been unable to spot the sheen, once 45 miles long, which had come within 7 miles of the Texas shoreline last week, officials said. ``We're expecting it to dissipate,'' said Coast Guard Chief Warrant Officer Howard Edmonds. ``We don't think it will come ashore.'' An estimated 3.9 million gallons of Angolan crude oil spilled from the Norwegian supertanker when it exploded June 8. Officials believe most of the oil burned, evaporated or was scooped up by 11 skimmers. Edmonds said Tuesday the Coast Guard was calling back its flight crews and beach patrols, which have been looking for tar balls from Galveston to Sabine Pass for the past 10 days. He said winds and waves are believed to have broken up the remaining oil and pushed it back out to sea. Meanwhile, salvage crews continued transfering oil from the Mega Borg to smaller cargo vessels. The transfers are expected to be completed Wednesday, Edmonds said. The 886-foot Norwegian ship exploded while crews were transferring its 38 million gallon cargo onto a smaller vessel in a process called lightering. The supertanker burned for more than a week some 57 miles offshore from Galveston. Two crew members were killed, while two others remain missing and are presumed dead. Seventeen other crewmen were injured. The ship owners have not said whether the supertanker will be repaired or scrapped.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Concedes That Tax Increases Needed to Decrease Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 15th graf:``White House,'' with White House trying to calm GOP revolt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, who won the White House with a ``read-my-lips'' pledge of no new taxes, conceded Tuesday that tax increases must be part of any plan to shrink the mushrooming budget deficit. The politically charged admission was quickly hailed by Democrats, who had demanded that Bush and his Republican allies share the heat for digging deeper into taxpayers' pockets during an election year. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. and chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, called Bush's statement ``an important step in the right direction,'' while the White House said it marked the turning point in sluggish negotiations with Congress to write a plan to reduce the deficit. ``We're going to have to do some things that are probably not going to be universally popular in dealing with the budget deficit,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. Neither the White House nor congressional Democrats would speculate on what taxes might be raised or what spending programs might be trimmed. ``We're not willing to give it any definition,'' presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said of Bush's statement. ``That's a matter for the negotiators.'' Some Republicans balked at Bush's decision and it quickly became a political target. Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., a member of the House GOP leadership, urged members of Congress to sign a letter declaring any increase in tax rates unacceptable. By the end of the day, 90 Republicans _ more than half the 176 GOP members of the House _ had put their names on the paper., Rep. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J., said the ``charade is finally over.'' ``The other shoe raised in the 1988 presidential campaign has just dropped. George Bush has announced that he's raising taxes,'' Torricelli said. Sen. John Breaux, D-La., said Bush had scotched an election-year theme for Republicans. ``It removes this so-called tax and spend issue from their arsenal of weapons,'' he said. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said the president had concluded that tax increases are necessary ``and we share the president's view.'' Foley added: ``I think someone who is complaining about taxes being raised in the budget summit will have to complain against both parties and the president.'' White House chief of staff John Sununu tried to calm the Republican revolt. House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia said Sununu had assured him that nothing had changed in Bush's position on taxes. ``The White House claims the statement doesn't mean anything new,'' Gingrich insisted. Deficit estimates have sharply increased since Bush unveiled his budget in January, and red ink may total more than $200 billion in the next fiscal year. ``We're not interested in who's first (to mention taxes) and who's last and who gets the blame for this and that,'' Fitzwater said. ``Both sides want to move in a bipartisan way to resolve this issue, and this statement is designed to reflect that feeling.'' Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, Bush's Democratic rival in the 1988 presidential election, said he told the truth about the need for higher taxes and ``paid the price'' by losing the presidency. ``Mr. Bush did not (tell the truth) and we're all now going to have to pay the price for that,'' Dukakis said in Boston. Meanwhile, Democratic Party Chairman Ron Brown said Bush's statement was candid and sober and ``gives no one comfort. It's no time for partisan gloating.'' Budget talks are scheduled to resume Wednesday, and the White House expressed hope for a final agreement by the August congressional recess. Bush issued his statement after a breakfast session with top congressional leaders and following a weekend of meetings between Democrats and White House budget negotiators. ``It is clear to me,'' Bush said, ``that both the size of the deficit problem and the need for a package that can be enacted require all of the following.'' He listed ``tax revenue increases,'' cuts in spending for federal benefits as well as reductions in other domestic and defense programs, reform of the budget process and ``growth incentives,'' a term often used to describe a cut in the capital gains tax rate. Bush, asked about his statement as he left a photo session, said the written statement ``speaks for itself'' and declined to specifically address reporters' questions about his position. ``I want to see this economy grow,'' he said. ``I want jobs. I want to see the deficit down. And this bipartisan statement speaks for itself. Now we're going on to some serious negotiation.'' He hailed congressional Democrats for the ``good faith'' spirit of the budget talks and said it was ``essential that these talks get moving.'' From the outset of the budget talks, Bush had said that everything was on the table for negotiation. Until now, however, he had refused to say explicitly that tax increases must be included in the deficit-reduction formula. The White House refused to acknowledge that Bush had scrapped his no-new-taxes pledge. ``Are you crazy?'' Fitzwater good-naturedly asked reporters. However, Fitzwater said Bush's statement amounted to ``a refinement'' of his earlier remarks. ``We've got to deal realistically with this problem,'' he said. On the other hand, Fitzwater said, ``I don't think that it (Bush's statement) is that big a change. We're still a long way from the final details of a settlement.'' There is a general consensus among budget negotiators that they need to reduce the deficit by $45 billion to $60 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and about $400 billion to $600 billion over the next five years. Technically, the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law would require far deeper cuts, based on current revenue and spending projections. By law, the government will be forced to absorb deep, across-the-board spending cuts unless the deficit is kept to $74 billion in fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mandela, Bjt
Mandela To Meet Sharansky In Los Angeles
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, who spent 27 years in jail for opposing his government, will meet this week with another famous dissident, Natan Sharansky. The meeting with the former Soviet prisoner will take place on Friday in Los Angeles, a day before Mandela winds up his 10-day U.S. tour, the Anti-Defamation League announced Tuesday. Sharansky was imprisoned in Soviet jails and labor camps for more than eight years on false charges of treason, before being exchanged in a 1986 East-West prisoner swap and allowed to go to Israel. ``It is indeed appropriate for these two giants of our generation _ heroes to blacks and Jews worldwide _ to share their experiences and to begin a dialogue exploring common grounds on a variety of issues,'' said ADL director Abraham H. Foxman. Foxman said he proposed the meeting to Mandela when he met with him in Geneva earlier this month at the head of an American Jewish delegation that wanted to protest the South African leader's warm praise for Palestinian chieftain Yasser Arafat. Mandela allayed some of the Jewish officials' concerns by advocating Israel's right to exist within secure borders. Mandela told Foxman he had read Sharansky's autobiography, ``Fear No Evil,'' the Jewish official said.

DOC.HEAD: EC Urges African National Congress to Renounce Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 22nd graf `In a' to ADD Italian prime minister's remarks about letter from Arafat distancing himself from seaborne raid on Israel. Pickup last graf, `On Monday...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON13,15
DOC.TEXT: The 12-nation European Community on Tuesday called on all South Africans to renounce violence in a declaration that Britain said was directed squarely at Nelson Mandela's African National Congress. But the leaders of the trade bloc, at the end of a two-day summit, refused to ease sanctions against South Africa's white-led government, saying they need ``further clear evidence'' that changes to end apartheid will continue. The statement came as Mandela was being lionized on a visit to the United States, where he called for sanctions to be maintained. But Mandela also caused unease in Washington by his continued refusal to renounce violence. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said it was a ``great pity'' that the EC nations were ``unable to agree publicly to make a start now on easing sanctions.'' ``What they have done is something I am very pleased about,'' she added. ``They have condemned pretty clearly anyone who advocates violence ... and that goes straight to the armed struggle in no uncertain terms, and that ought to be abandoned.'' Despite the refusal to lift sanctions, South Africa's government welcomed the EC statement. ``What the declaration says, albeit not in so many words, is that South Africa has regained international respectability,'' Foreign Minister Pik Botha said in Pretoria. ``The use of violence is rejected,'' he added. ``By implication, this means that the ANC's adherence to the armed struggle is unacceptable.'' The summit was dominated by the South African issue and by a West German and French demand for $15 billion in immediate aid to help the Soviet Union's deteriorating economy. Other leaders rejected the demand. On the issue of South African sanctions, the community said it ``affirms its willingness to consider a gradual relaxation of this pressure when there is further clear evidence that the process of change already initiated continues.'' ``The European Council calls on all parties ... to refrain from violence or advocacy of violence,'' the communiquesaid. The leaders described South African President F.W. de Klerk as a man of ``foresight and courage'' and said Mandela has ``inspired millions of South Africans opposed to apartheid.'' But in effect, the community stuck to a position adopted at a summit in Strasbourg, France, six months ago. Since then, de Klerk has begun a reform program, including releasing Mandela after 27 years in jail, legalizing the ANC and scrapping some apartheid laws. Britain, backed by Portugal, argued that de Klerk deserved a specific reward. But Ireland and Denmark were adamant that sanctions remain. Britain, Italy, Spain and Portugal have already lifted some relatively minor restrictions. But unanimous support by the EC nations is needed to end joint embargoes imposed in 1986 that banned imports of South African iron, steel and gold coins. On Soviet aid, the community ordered its executive commission to undertake with the World Bank and other international agencies a study of Moscow's needs. Most of the leaders opposed giving money to the Soviet Union with no clear idea of how it would be used. ``It wouldn't be responsible for the community to fix a budget without knowing the needs,'' said Spain's prime minister, Felipe Gonzalez. In a related development, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman acknowledged in Moscow on Tuesday that the Soviet Union was having trouble paying $2 billion in foreign bills, but he asked for more Western credits to help move toward a market economy. Officials said they expected Italy, which takes over the community's six-month rotating presidency July 1, to have Soviet aid proposals ready by fall. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl predicted that an aid package would be organized by the end of the year. But Kohl, who has pledged $3.1 billion of West German credit guarantees for the Soviet Union, complained that ``whenever there is a question of money, the question first goes to the Federal Republic of Germany.'' In a separate development, the leaders expressed ``deep revulsion at recent manifestations of anti-Semitism, racism and xenophobia'' in Western Europe, particularly a spate of desecrations of Jewish graves. Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti said he had received a letter from Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat ``distancing'' himself from the foiled May 30 seaborne attack by Palestinian guerrillas on a beach near Tel Aviv. Andreotti referred to the letter while speaking to Italian reporters, but gave no details. The United States last week suspended its 18-month dialogue with the PLO because of Arafat's failure to condemn the raid and discipline Mohammed Abbas' Palestine Liberation Front, which claimed responsibility for the attack. On Monday, pressing ahead with plans for closer union, the leaders agreed to start intergovernmental conferences in Rome in mid-December aimed at achieving an undefined form of political union, and economic and monetary union by 1993.

DOC.HEAD: For Mandela, an Honor No American Black Has Ever Received
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf: ``Kweisi Mfume,'' to CORRECT ``slash'' to ``sash''
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela stood before Congress on Tuesday where no black from America had ever stood _ not Frederick Douglass, not Booker T. Washington, not W.E.B. DuBois, not Martin Luther King Jr. His arms raised in triumph from the podium of the House of Representatives, the deputy presiden of the African National Congress became the third heroic figure from abroad to address a joint meeting in these revolutionary times. Lech Walesa, an electrician from Poland; Vaclav Havel, a president-playwright from Czechoslovakia; and now the 71-year-old Mandela, a prisoner for 27 years in South Africa. Mandela is a representative of a struggle _ he pointedly made clear _ that is not over. A dedicated revolutionary who will not renounce the use of arms, he craftily reminded his audience of American blood that has been shed in the cause of freedom, using words known to every schoolchild and every member of Congress. ``Equality, liberty and the pursuit of happiness,'' he said, ``are fundamental human rights which are not only inalienable but must, if necessary, be defended with the weapons of war.'' This was said by an erect, trim, tidy, calm man in a soft, lilting South African English that made his audience strain to hear. Before him sat Washington: the House, the Senate, the Cabinet, military men led by a black general, Colin Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff; the diplomatic corps, including one black African ambassador in a sweeping white robe. Often, when dignitaries visit, members of Congress find other demands more pressing and the seats are filled by staff. Not this time. The overflow sat in Statuary Hall, amid the granite figures, watching on four television sets. When he finished, even that audience applauded. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., stayed away. He had fought vigorously when Congress, overriding a veto by then-President Reagan, imposed sanctions on South Africa to bring pressure for an end of the rigid system of segregation known as apartheid. Helms had said in the debate that sanctions would lead to ``everlasting tyranny.'' Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., said he boycotted ``as a matter of principle.'' He said Mandela was more like the 1960s revolutionary H. Rap Brown than Martin Luther King Jr. But for the 24 black members of the House, the moment was precious. Kweisi Mfume, formerly Frizzell Gray, wore a black African sash with stripes of red and gold, over his gray business suit. He is a Democratic member of the House from Baltimore. Someone else, apparently a staff member, brought his tiny son, dressed in a suit, and led him across the House floor by the hand. Before his address, Mandela met with Congress' blacks members and a handful of their white allies. He thanked them for pushing through sanctions. ``To be there, to see him, to have him thank members of the Congressional Black Caucus, makes my lifetime in politics worthwhile,'' said Rep. Charles B. Rangel, a Democrat who represents Harlem. During the speech, a shriek _ a whoop _ went up when Mandela ticked off the names of his American heroes. ``All right!'' people called out. ``Right on!'' He named Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln, of course, but his list included names not always on such lists: John Brown, the firebrand abolitionist whose anger at slavery helped start the Civil War; Sojourner Truth, the black lady preacher who could neither read nor write but whose words stirred the North; Frederick Douglass, the runaway slave who bought his own freedom with the earnings from his speeches against slavery; Marcus Garvey, ``the black Moses''; and King, who dreamed of freedom from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. None of them, in their time, had been honored with an invitation to address Congress, the American equivalent to knighthood. Mandela became the first black who was not a head of state to whom that honor was bestowed. He said he came not as a leader but ``as a particle'' of a people ``who we know to be noble and heroic, enduring, multiplying, permanent, rejoicing in the expectation and knowledge that their humanity will be reaffirmed.''

DOC.HEAD: Killer of Robert Kennedy Denied Parole 13th Time
DOC.TEXT: Sirhan B. Sirhan, who shot Sen. Robert F. Kennedy to death 22 years ago, was denied parole Tuesday for the 13th time. After a hearing of more than five hours in Soledad Prison, Sirhan was told his next parole hearing would be in 1992. Commissioner David Brown, one of the three Board of Prison Terms members, said parole was denied ``because the prisoner committed a political assassination, which is unique in American history.'' Brown said another reason for the denial was that the ``underlying cause of the offense and the prisoner's role in the offense remain unresolved and a longer period of time is needed to resolve this issue.'' Brown did not elaborate on that comment and was not available for questions after the hearing. Sirhan, now 46, was convicted of gunning down Kennedy on June 5, 1968, in the pantry of Los Angeles' Ambassador Hotel. Kennedy, who had just won California's Democratic primary, died early the next day. Sirhan is serving a life term in prison. He was sentenced to death in 1969, but the sentence was reduced to life imprisonment in 1972 after the state Supreme Court struck down the death penalty. The parole board had been petitioned by about 40 prominent Middle East officials and citizens. They included two Arab members of Israel's Knesset, the mayor of Bethlehem, members of the Arab Women's Union and officials of Bir Zeit University. Sirhan's lawyer, Luke McKissack, said Monday the petition suggested that Sirhan's release could speed peace in the Middle East. Los Angeles Deputy District Attorney Larry Trapp said he was surprised at McKissack's move. ``It would suggest that Sirhan should have some place in making political decisions or influencing political decisions,'' Trapp said. The petition said: ``We of Israel and Palestine are concerned that inmate Sirhan Sirhan be given equal treatment under the law. It concerns us that ... he is repeatedly denied parole while other convicted murderers, many more dangerous than he, are released after serving much less time.''

DOC.HEAD: Unexpected Price Rises Forcing Cuts in WIC Program
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 20-22: ``The Agriculture,'' material from a0730 AM-WIC Money
DOC.TEXT: Sharp food price increases and rebate reductions will force nearly a quarter of a million low-income pregnant women and children from a federal supplemental nutrition program, according to a survey released Tuesday. ``Between March 1990 and September 1990, the end of the current fiscal year, our survey found that at least 240,000 participants would no longer be served by the WIC program,'' said Dennis Bach, president of the National Association of WIC directors. Bach said at least 25 states already have begun reducing their monthly participation in the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC. The program provides needy women and children with vouchers redeemable at grocery stores for food, including milk, cheese, juices and cereals. Since May 1989 the Consumer Price Index shows that milk prices have risen 10.7 percent, cheese costs have climbed 12.7 percent and fruit juices and frozen fruit prices have risen 13.8 percent. Congress has appropriated $2.1 billion for the current fiscal year. Bach said an additional $72 million was needed to prevent the reductions. The House approved a fiscal 1991 increase of $235 million, including $85 million to maintain current services and $150 million for program expansion. But Bach said the $150 million ``could be eaten up to maintain current levels.'' Only half of those currently eligible are receiving benefits, according to Bach. The Agriculture Department, meanwhile, announced it was allocating an additional $11 million to 46 states for the WIC program for the final three months of the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. ``Many states have managed their WIC caseloads carefully enough that they aren't having any budgetary problems,'' said Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the department's Food and Nutrition Service. ``Others have had to economize ... by choosing less expensive but nutritious foods,'' she said. The House Select Committee on Hunger planned a second hearing to examine program reductions on Wednesday. The estimated cutbacks are prompted by an increase in WIC foods prices that the study said are averaging 7 percent or more in one-third of the states. The Department of Agriculture's food and nutrition service, which runs the program, had estimated only a 4.5 percent food price inflation. In a recent status report the USDA said no ``high priority'' pregnant or breastfeeding women or infants were being removed from the program as of March. The government report, however, acknowledged ``some states will experience declines'' but said as many as 20 states would maintain or increase participation levels by the end of the fiscal year. The states hardest hit in the cutbacks include California, New York, Texas and Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Squirrel in Worse Shape, GAO Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 13-18: ``Sam Marler,'' reaction from administration, university
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Spotted Owl a0779
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators reported Tuesday that the fate of the endangered Mount Graham red squirrel has become precarious and raised new objections to a planned observatory on the Arizona mountaintop that is its only home. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, suggested that 1988 legislation authorizing construction of the $200 million observatory be changed to permit a delay while new studies are undertaken to weigh the impact of the installation on the squirrel's chances for survival. The forested site of the proposed observatory on Mount Graham in the Pinaleno mountains 110 miles northeast of Tucson is the squirrel's only known habitat. In testimony before four House environmental subcommittees, James Duffus III, natural resources director of the General Accounting Office, sharply questioned the validity of a 1988 study by the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service which concluded that building the observatory would not pose an unacceptable risk to the squirrel. Duffus testified that since the wildlife service's biological report was issued and the act approving the construction of the observatory was passed, ``the status of the Mount Graham red squirrel has become more precarious.'' ``Available data suggest that squirrel numbers have dropped from about 215 in 1988 to between 132 and 146 in May 1990,'' he said. Duffus said that although the exact cause of the population decline in unknown, biologists consulted by the GAO suggest that reduction of the red squirrel's source of food, mostly spruce and fir tree cones, is a major reason. ``They contend that removing trees that produce these cones in order to build the astrophysical facility is not biologically sound,'' he said. The University of Arizona initially sought to build a seven-telescope facility atop the Emerald and High peaks of the Mountain. Duffus said the eventual Fish and Wildlife report giving a green light to a compromise bid to build three telescopes was flawed because it was based on other than biological information and ignored the concerns of the service's own biologists. The wildlife service's regional director decided on his own that the university's determination to build a ``world-class'' facility outweighed the risk to the squirrel, an officially endangered species, Duffus said. ``We do not believe that it is appropriate for a Fish and Wildlife Service official to consider non-biological information in reaching an opinion that could jeopardize a species's existence,'' the GAO official said. ``We believe ... that biological decisions should be based on biological information.'' Sam Marler, director of external affairs for the service, said later, ``There is nothing only in what the field biologist does,'' and recommendations from those staff members frequently are modified by more senior biologists before the regional director makes his decision. Marler said he had heard allegations that the decision was improper, ``But I haven't seen or heard anything that would suggest it was improper.'' Allan Beigel, a vice president of the university in Washington for the hearing, said in a statement issued in Tucson the university believed the government witnesses had ``saisfactorily responded'' to the concerns raised by the GAO report. University officials will try to allay concerns of members of the Arizona delegation who believe the observatory should be reassessed, he said. A joint statement from the state's two senators and Reps. Morris Udall, a Democrat, and John Kyl, a Republican, said, ``Until the biological opinion is updated, the project should not proceed.'' Their statement noted the GAO opinion that the government ``would have difficulty'' persuading a court that it had complied with all the requirements of the Endangered Species Act. Duffus said Congress now faces a policy decision. On the one hand it can allow construction of the observatory to continue as planned, he said. But he said it can also order the wildlife service to update its opinion in light of the squirrel's precarious situation and concerns over the process used to arrive at the original opinion. ``This may require additional legislation to hold construction in abeyance until a new biological opinion is rendered,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Six Fatalities Reported from Wildfire
With AM-Heat Wave, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Six firefighters battling an erratic wildfire in intense heat died Tuesday and at least five others were hospitalized with serious burns, authorities said. Four of the injured firefighters were prison inmates who were among the 1,000 people battling a blaze on a mountain ridge about 90 miles northeast of Phoenix. Officials did not know the full circumstances of the six deaths, said Tonto National Forest spokesman Bob Celaya. The fire was sparked by lightning Monday, but the wind Tuesday began pushing the 1,900-acre fire past firelines on the Mogollon Rim, he said. The temperature Tuesday was at least 106 in Payson, 12 miles southwest of the fire. The injured inmates were part of a group of 18 or 19 prisoners and two officials the Perryville state prison assigned to help fight the fire, said Corrections Department spokesman Mike Arra. The four injured inmates and the other injured firefighter were taken to the burn unit of the Maricopa Medical Center in Phoenix. ``We are getting some in and we don't have them all yet,'' said nursing supervisor Donna Heitman. ``We are almost in the process of preparing for a disaster.''

DOC.HEAD: Record Heat Threatens Some Crops, Forces Water Use Restriction
With AM-Heat Wave, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Record heat threatened crops, forced a desert water district to issue restrictions and sent hundreds of thousands of Southern Californians fleeing to beaches Tuesday as temperatures pushed past well into the 100s. The 112-degree high at the Los Angeles Civic Center was an all-time record for downtown, beating the previous record high of 110 degrees set on Sept. 4, 1988. Other areas that reached three digits were Woodland Hills with 112, Pacoima with 114, Ontario with 112, San Bernardino with 111, San Gabriel with 111, and Santa Barbara with 103. The deserts were even hotter. Palm Springs and Thermal recorded highs of 120, while Needles had a high of 119. The second day of high heat put firefighters on alert as brush already dry after four years of drought sat on hillsides shimmering in heat that dropped humidity below 10 percent. At least one brush fire was reported in the Sunland area northeast of downtown. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory for inland orchards and vineyards in San Diego County, and growers said berry crops would be damaged immediately and some fruits could be lost if the heat continues. ``This is going to finish up the strawberries,'' said Ben Hillbrecht, a grower with about 200 acres near Escondido. ``And the boysenberries will cook right on the vine. We won't have any this year.'' He said the heat also will stop raspberry bushes from producing for about one month. Avocados have just appeared as tiny green buds, and Hillbrecht said if they don't get enough moisture, they may fall off. ``There are certainly some crops that are threatened, though at this moment we have seen no damage,'' said grower Jim Bathgate of Valley Center. He said fruits such as apricots and peaches still on the tree could be affected if the heat wave continues a few days, as the weather service has predicted. ``It won't help the water shortage, because everyone turns on their water to keep things as wet as they can,'' said Hillbrecht. In the Mojave Desert, the small Hi-Desert Water District in Yucca Valley announced use restrictions to begin Wednesday after the rural water company noticed an average six-to-seven foot drop in its wells. One well dropped 20 feet over the past six weeks. Irrigation will be limited to one day a week, and filling pools and washing cars at homes will be banned, along with water use for construction such as mixing concrete, Puffer said. The district serves about 5,200 customers. Not everybody was having a hard time with the heat wave. At Raging Waters, a 1.5-million-gallon water playground in San Dimas, Calif., business was also brisk, said spokeswoman Lynne Matallana. ``We love the hot weather. It encourages people to come out and visit us,'' she said. Hundreds of thousands of people headed to beaches, where temperatures were more than 20 degrees cooler than inland. Lifeguards reported nearly 100,000 at Santa Monica, 150,000 at Hermosa Beach and 40,000 at Zuma Beach in Los Angeles County.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Asks Congress for Aid in Anti-Apartheid Struggle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6 pvs with 9 grafs bgng: ``At an,'' with evening rally; picks up 7th graf pvs: ``Standing before,''
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela urged Congress Tuesday to supplement economic sanctions against South Africa with ``material resources'' to hasten the end of white-minority rule. ``Our people demand democracy,'' the celebrated black leader said. Mandela made an impassioned plea for justice in his historic address to a joint session of Congress, comparing the struggle of South African blacks with that of America's founding fathers. The one-time prisoner was accorded the kind of reception from Congress normally reserved for U.S. presidents. His entrance was greeted with a 2{-minute ovation and there was even longer applause from the packed House chamber when he finished. ``Our people demand democracy. Our country, which continues to bleed and suffocate, needs democracy,'' he said. At an evening rally attended by more than 19,000 people in the city's Convention Center, Mandela again called for the United States to maintain its economic sanctions against his country, but he also called for financial assistance to the nation once the apartheid system is abolished. ``New investment will play a key role in this respect,'' he told an often cheering crowd of thousands. ``We need to mobilize the country for peace,'' Mandela said. ``We need to train personnel for economic recovery. ... For all this we shall continue to rely on your firm support.'' Mandela said he had been encouraged by his trip to the United States. ``The masses of the American people are with us, both Congress (the House) and the Senate are with us; surely apartheid must go,'' he said. Mandela's tardiness of more than an hour prevented him from speaking at a private $1,000-per-person reception before the rally, and he apologized for that in his speech. He said the unspecified amount raised would be devoted to ``the struggling masses of South Africa.'' Mandela was introduced by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who apologized for U.S. complicity in his arrest by the South African government 27 years ago. ``Our CIA was a factor in your arrest,'' Jackson said. ``We are ashamed of that.'' Mandela spent most of the day in private talks with lawmakers. In his speech Congress, Mandela appealed to the senators and House members to let the ``people of South Africa'' _ not the U.S. government _ be the ones to judge when the sanctions imposed by Congress four years ago should be lifted. Standing before the assembled lawmakers, Cabinet members and foreign ambassadors, Mandela skirted the controversial issues that have arisen since he began his U.S. tour last Wednesday. He made no reference to his support for anti-American radicals, such as Libya's Moammar Gadhafi, and did not reiterate directly his view that violence is a useful tool in the anti-apartheid struggle. He was at pains, however, to praise American founding fathers, such as George Washington, who resorted to armed confrontation in the American war of independence. He compared the struggle of South African blacks to that two-century-old struggle. And he pointedly referred to Pretoria's armed tyranny of the black majority. ``We would be fools to believe that the road ahead of us is without major hurdles. Too many among our white compatriots are slaves in the ideology of racism to admit easily that change must come,'' he said. ``For those who care to worry about violence in our country as we do, it is at these forces that they should focus their attention.'' In an apparent response to concerns about Marxist influence within his African National Congress, Mandela praised private industry as an ``engine of growth and development'' and said ``the ANC holds no ideological positions which dictate that it must adopt a policy of nationalization.'' But he left open the possibility of a dominant state role in the economy when he said priority attention must be given to meeting the material needs of the people. After thanking the Congress for imposing the sanctions that have crippled South Africa's economy, Mandela said, ``We request that you go further and assist us with material resources which will enable us to promote the peace process and meet other needs which arise from the changing situation you helped bring about.'' He was not specific about the type of assistance the ANC is seeking. Congress has approved $10 million in aid for South Africa, which is to be used for promotion of democracy in that country. Officials have said the ANC would be entitled to a portion of these funds if it renounces violence. They would be channeled through the National Endowment for Democracy, which seeks to promote the consolidation of democracy worldwide. The lifting of the sanctions is expected to be an issue of heated debate, and Mandela appealed to the lawmakers to leave the decision to South Africans. ``We plead that you cede the prerogative to the people of South Africa to determine the moment when it will be said that profound changes have occurred and an irreversible process achieved, enabling you and the rest of the international community to lift sanctions,'' he said. Administration officials have said they would, consistent with legislative requirements, consult with Congress on lifting the sanctions once the State of Emergency is suspended in Natal Province and all political prisoners are released. Mandela estimates the total at 1,000. In addressing the Congress, Mandela was virtually guaranteed a friendly audience. It was the Congress, four years ago, which overrode President Reagan's veto and imposed a ban on new investments in South Africa as well as trade and travel restrictions as part of a broader sanctions program. The only other private citizens who have addressed a joint meeting were Solidarity leader Lech Walesa of Poland last year and the Marquis de Lafayette in 1824. While acknowledging that the struggle is not yet over, Mandela seemed confident of eventual victory, discussing his vision of a post-apartheid South Arica. At times, the 71-year-old leader used soaring rhetoric to make his points. He said that South African society, ``which has known nothing but racism for three centuries, should be transformed into an oasis of good race relations, where the black shall to the white be sister and brother, a fellow South African, an equal human being, both citizens of the world. ``To destory racism in the world, we, together, must expunge apartheid racism in South Arica. Justice and liberty must be our tool, prosperity and happiness our weapon.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Cautiously Applaud Bush Oil Drilling Moratorium
With AM-Offshore Oil, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists and lawmakers applauded President Bush's decision Tuesday to ban much offshore oil drilling for at least a decade, but some complained the move was politically motivated and didn't go far enough. Bush blocked new drilling off much of the West Coast, Florida and New England until at least the year 2000. He ordered further environmental studies to determine if drilling leases might be offered after that. ``We'll take a half a loaf because it's better than none,'' said Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla.. ``A 10-year moratorium is better than fighting for a moratorium every year.'' ``I view this as a major victory for environmentalists and coastal advocates. We have won time, up to 10 years,'' said California Assemblyman Tom Hayden, a Democrat. ``So I'm thankful for the actions in Washington, whatever the motives are.'' Some environmentalists said Bush acted to help Republican candidates in California and Florida concerned about possible negative voter reaction to new drilling in a year that has seen many news stories on oil spills. ``The President's decision to delay leasing and development for 10 years off most of California's coast is an important concession to the political reality, but it merely postpones the controversy instead of solving it,'' said Ann Notthoff of the Natural Resources Defense Council of San Francisco. Notthoff also warned that a provision in Bush's order that would lift the moratorium if oil supply is disrupted is ``a loophole big enough to drive a truck through.'' Bush suspended until at least the year 2000 any new leases to oil companies for drilling off the coast of nearly all of California. He permanently banned drilling in a marine sanctuary in Monterey Bay. The moratorium also applies to the waters off Washington and Oregon, 14 million acres off South Florida and 12.8 million acres of Georges Bank off Cape Cod. Bush directed Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan to begin talks with Florida officials on a federal-state buyback of 73 leases that oil companies already had bought for drilling off Florida. That rankled some Florida officials, who estimated the buyback could cost $100 million to $200 million. ``The people of Florida should not be asked to bear what is rightly a federal responsibility,'' said Gov. Bob Martinez, who otherwise called Bush's moratorium ``a major victory.'' Ann Whitfield, spokeswoman for the Florida Public Interest Research Group, also complained that Bush did not ban drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. ``We look at it as winning a battle, but not winning the war,'' she said. In Oregon, Republican Congressman Denny Smith called Bush's action a ``sound decision.'' ``I believe that drilling for oil would put Oregon's coastal wildlife habitat, rich fishing runs and growing tourism industry at risk in exchange for a few days worth of energy,'' said Smith. Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., said, ``While I would have preferred an outright ban on any leasing off our coast, a 10-year breathing space will be welcome.'' New England lawmakers have been fighting drilling on the prolific Georges Bank fishing ground since it first was proposed early in the Reagan administration. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said the Bush decision represented a ``shift _ and a welcome one'' in Reagan-Bush policy. ``Anybody who knows or cares about Georges Bank should be delighted,'' said Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass. ``He's not even going to be president by the year 2000. He's done all that he can for Georges Bank on his watch.'' Oil companies acknowledged public worry over oil drilling. ``President Bush has recognized that most Americans are not prepared at this time to develop certain environmentally sensitive offshore areas,'' Los Angeles-based ARCO said in a statemen. ``ARCO supports the president under these circumstances.'' Chevron Oil Co. said initial reports of Bush's decision indicated ``the president's actions seem to go too far.'' ``But we certainly realize there is great concern by the American public over this issue,'' the company said in a statement in San Francisco. ``We're anxious to see the various parties to the offshore development controversy work together to find long-term solutions that will satisfy both the need for a sound U.S. energy policy and for protection of the environment,'' the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Dog Recall Expands To Cover Nation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS second ``is'' to ``its'' in lede
DOC.TEXT: J.M. Schneider Inc. of Ontario, Canada, is voluntarily expanding its recall last week of 22,000 pounds of frankfurters to include grocery stores nationwide, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
DOC.HEAD: Officials said, 2nd graf
Congressional Committee Would Cut Latin American Debt to Governments
DOC.TEXT: President Bush would be authorized to cut debts to the U.S. government by Latin American countries under a provision approved Tuesday by the House Banking Committee. There was no record vote. Two Republicans, Stan Parris of Virginia and Marge Roukema of New Jersey, said they disapproved. But another Republican, Rep. Jim Leach of Iowa, joined Democrats Joseph Kennedy of Massachusetts and Esteban Edward Torres of California in sponsoring the proposal. A subcommittee last Wednesday voted to authorize the president to reduce the debts of African and East European countries. The United States and other creditor governments have already reduced some African debt. Tuesday's vote added Latin American countries to the proposal if their debt and the interest they pay on it are large enough to meet a series of requirements that show the debt to be particularly heavy. It asked the Bush administration to urge other governments also to negotiate reductions of debts owed to them. There has been particular pressure to reduce the debt of Poland, much of which is owed to West Germany and France. The Bush administration has so far opposed reductions in Europe. Leach made it plain that he does not intend the bill to apply to debts owed to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which are jointly owned by 152 governments.

DOC.HEAD: Temperatures Soar Across the Southwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to show that four of injured men were prisoners; picks up 6th graf pvs, `Spot checks...; SUBS 20th graf, `A 102-degree...' with all-time heat record in Los Angeles
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PN2, PN4
DOC.TEXT: Air conditioners whined. Swimming pools beckoned. But there was no getting around it _ it was hot here Tuesday, 122 degrees worth of hot, hot enough to ground planes. It was the hottest day on record in America's hottest big city. A heat wave that stretched from the Southern California coast to the heart of Texas reached its sweltering peak in Phoenix, which set an all-time record of 120 degrees on Monday and promptly broke it a day later. At 2:47 p.m. it was 122, and many of the airlines at Sky Harbor International Airport began canceling takeoffs, said airport spokesman Rick Martinez. The National Weather Service advised the metropolitan area's 2.1 million residents to stay indoors, carry plenty of water when driving and not leave pets or children inside parked cars. Six firefighters died and five others _ including four men from a prison workcrew _ were seriously burned fighting a 1,900-acre fire in Tonto National Forest, about 90 miles northeast of Phoenix, forest spokeswoman Joyce Hassell said. The temperature Tuesday topped 106 in Payson, 12 miles southwest of the fire area. It wasn't known immediately what role the heat might have played in the tragedy. Spot checks at Sky Harbor indicated most airlines were resuming flights later Tuesday afternoon, as temperatures dropped below 120. American Airlines canceled all its afternoon flights in an out of Phoenix, officials at the company's offices here said. It was the first time planes had been grounded because of heat in the history of Sky Harbor, the world's 20th busiest airport, Martinez said. The heat had reduced lift to the point that planes had no margin for error trying to get airborne, he said. Some landings also were rerouted to other airlines, Martinez said. ``Temperature is really critical on takeoff,'' Martinez said. ``People are staying in the gates, waiting for the temperature to go down.'' ``It is what we consider a severe weather condition, not unlike your northern California fog conditions or similar weather conditions,'' said America West Airlines spokesman Dick Shimizu. America West canceled its takeoffs at 3:30 p.m.; they resumed at 4:20 p.m., airline officials said. Airlines with Boeing aircraft have contacted the Seattle company to get information on engine specifications and takeoffs at higher temperatures, Martinez said. Phoenix natives pride themselves on their resistance to heat, but out-of-towners were shocked by the scorching weather. Emery Jones of Castledale, Utah, drove into town with his wife, Suzanne, in an air-conditioned car. When they stepped out, he said, ``it took our breath away.'' Monday's high of 120 broke the old record of 118 degrees that had been set on four occasions, the last time on July 4, 1989. Tuesday morning's low of 91 degrees also set a record for the date and was close to the 93-degree reading of July 20, 1989, which was the highest low temperature ever recorded here. Weather service meteorologist Craig Ellis said the high temperatures were caused by a strong high-pressure area in the upper atmosphere and the sun beating almost directly down on the Earth. He predicted the temperature would peak Tuesday or Wednesday before cooling off to around 113 degrees. In Tucson, which is about 1,200 feet higher, the temperature hit an all-time record of 115 degrees by 1 p.m. Tuesday. Arizona's second-largest city had a high of 113 Monday and had never gone higher than 114 degrees. The state didn't swelter alone. An all-time high of 112 was set in downtown Los Angeles, where the previous record high of 110 degrees was set Sept. 4, 1988. Borrego Springs, Calif., in the Anza-Borrego Desert had Monday's nationwide high of 122 degrees, and the weather service reported temperatures above 110 degrees in low deserts from the coastal mountains eastward to New Mexico. At Death Valley National Monument in eastern California, park Ranger Karen Rosga said she advised people to drink a lot of liquid and slow down. The temperature hit 120 degrees Monday and was expected to top out at 121 Tuesday. The weather sevice issued a heat advisory for much of north-central Texas. Lubbock in west Texas hit an all-time high of 110 degrees Sunday, according to weather service forecaster Loren Phillips. Some businesses rejoiced in the extreme heat. ``These will be record-beaking days for our stores, believe me,'' said Marilyn Novak, marketing director for Baskin-Robbins ice cream stores based in Glendale, Calif. Business also was brisk at Raging Waters, a 1{ million-gallon water playground in San Dimas, Calif. ``We love the hot weather. It encourages people to come out and visit us,'' Raging Waters spokeswoman Lynne Matallana said. Several people passed out from heat exhaustion Monday at the South Rim of the Grand Canyon, spokeswoman Maureen Oltrogge said. Although temperatures on the rim reached only 92, it was 110 degrees deeper in the canyon, she said. The Salt River Project, one of the two major utilities for the Phoenix area, appealed to the public to conserve energy by setting thermostats 2 to 3 degrees higher and to not run appliances during peak hours of the day. The Arizona Automobile Association's main office in Phoenix took at least 1,500 calls, about 500 or 600 more than usual, said Frank Kuczora, shift supervisor of the road service department. Many were from motorists whose vehicles overheated or had dead batteries, he said. Ellis, the weather service forecaster, said he believed the heat lent credence to theories of global warming. However, Robert Gall, a professor in the University of Arizona's atmospheric sciences department, attributed the extreme temperatures to the atmosphere's natural variability. ``I don't think it represents a long-term trend,'' he said. If the extreme heat is related to greenhouse warming, ``there is no way of proving it,'' he said. ``This kind of anomaly, warm temperatures, could be naturally occurring,'' Gall said. ``There is variation all the time ... I would say that if the dice were rolled, it just came up hot.''

President Bush on Tuesday blocked new oil drilling off the coasts of much of California, Florida, Washington, Oregon and New England until the year 2000. In addition, he permanently blocked any drilling in a proposed marine sanctuary in California's Monterey Bay, and ordered a moratorium on new leases until 1996 for one section off southern California where drilling already is under way. ``My desire is to achieve a balance between the need to provide energy for the American people and the need to protect unique and sensitive coastal and marine environments,'' Bush said in a written statement announcing his long-pending decision. The president called for more environmental studies to settle the question of whether leases might be offered after 2000.

The farm where Lawrence Welk learned to play the accordion became center stage Tuesday for a project to create a museum honoring the king of champagne music. Gov. George Sinner and other state officials were expected to attend the groundbreaking ceremony at the farm where Welk lived until he was 21. The bandleader himself, now 87 and living in Los Angeles, did not attend but sent a letter of thanks. ``Little did I dream when I was growing up on the farm so many, many years ago that someday it would be restored and people would come and marvel at how life was lived in the early 1920s,'' Welk wrote. ``Looking back, I would say that life on the farm was very hard and I didn't always like it _ especially when I had to help butcher the hogs. But they were really happy days, too, because there was always love.''

Air conditioners whined. Swimming pools beckoned. But there was no getting around it _ it was hot here Tuesday, 121 degrees worth of hot, the hottest day on record in America's hottest big city. A heat wave that stretched from the Southern California coast to the heart of Texas reached its sweltering peak in Phoenix, which set an all-time record of 120 degrees on Monday and promptly broke it a day later. The National Weather Service advised the metropolitan area's 2.1 million residents to stay indoors, carry plenty of water when driving and not leave pets or children inside parked cars. Phoenix natives pride themselves on their resistance to heat, but out-of-towners were shocked by the scorching weather. Emery Jones of Castledale, Utah, drove into town with his wife, Suzanne, in an air-conditioned car. When they stepped out, he said, ``it took our breath away.''

DOC.HEAD: The Best Books in English
DOC.TEXT: So many books in the world. So what shall we read? Three British bookmen and 15 collaborators have produced a list of 2,500 books they consider are the best in the English language. ``That's a lot of titles, but if you start young enough, we think you could get through it. You could read a book a week if you wanted to,'' said Brian Last, one of the three editors of ``An English Library'' from Gower Publishing Co. Their book contains 15 categories of books, from fiction to reference, and cites 11 books of the Bible in the Old Testament and seven in the New Testament. Charles Dickens' novels and William Shakespeare's plays mingle with the poems of the present poet laureate of England, Ted Hughes, and modern American novels such as Ken Kesey's ``One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest.'' The new book is based on ``An English Library'' by the late Frank Seymour Smith, a librarian whose choice ran to more than 5,000 books in 1963, none of them by a living author. ``Our changes take account of more modern tastes,'' said Last in an interview. ``We wanted to remodel Smith, put in contemporary writers and add new sections like world literature in English which takes account of important authors in Australia, Canada, India and Africa.'' Last, 39, is managing editor of Scholar Press, a Gower subsidiary. He and co-editors Nigel Farrow, 50, chairman of Gower, and Vernon Pratt, a researcher at Lancaster University who is in his 40s, say they compiled their list with the single aim of extending people's enjoyment of reading. ``We all write, teach or publish books for a living but read them for enjoyment,'' Farrow said. ``At the end of the day there is always the worry that we might have left out something important but we have done as much painstaking research as we could,'' Last said. ``We tried to include everything that is first rate of its kind.'' Smith put asterisks against his personal choices in what he called the ``exhilarating wealth of genius in English books.'' The editors of the new edition have not done the same but at the request of The Associated Press, Last and Farrow (Pratt was unavailable) selected their top books in each category. Here they are, with the original publication dates:

_ English and American Fiction: Charles Dickens, ``Little Dorrit'' 1855-57. F. Scott Fitzgerald, ``The Great Gatsby'' 1925. _ World literature in English: the poems of Wole Soyinka, 1960s onwards. _ Children's literature: Lewis Carroll, ``Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' 1865. _ Poetry: William Butler Yeats, 1890s onwards. _ Drama: William Shakespeare, ``King Lear'' 1605. _ Biography: James Boswell, ``The Life of Samuel Johnson'' 1791. _ Autobiography: Robert Graves, ``Goodbye to All That'' 1929. _ Essays and other prose writings: George Orwell, ``Inside the Whale'' 1940. _ Travel: Freya Stark, ``The Journey's Echo'' 1964. _ Literary criticism: Samuel Johnson, ``The Lives of the Poets'' 1781. _ History: David Thomson, ``Europe Since Napoleon'' 1957. _ Philosophy: John Stuart Mill, ``On Liberty'' 1859. _ The Bible: The Old Testament Book of the Prophet Isaiah. About the 8th century B.C. _ Fine arts: E.H. Gombrich, ``The Story of Art'' 1950. _ Reference: ``The Oxford Companion to English Literature,'' 5th edition edited by Margaret Drabble. 1985.

``There was some argument over the American novel, and `Gatsby' was challenged by `Huckleberry Finn' (Mark Twain),'' said Last. ``There was a problem with the poetry as we felt that (Geoffrey) Chaucer, (Philip) Larkin, (Thomas) Hardy and (Andrew) Marvell had a right to the top spot but we agreed that Yeats had the edge. ``It was enormously difficult to choose a play of Shakespeare as all his plays should really be there, and on another day we might have picked `Othello.''' The editors' final advice: ``If you don't like something, don't plow through it. Reading isn't competition, it's enjoyment. The classic you don't like is in our book because it is a classic.'' ``An English Library'' costs $25.50. It is available in the United States from Barbara Church at Gower Publishing, Old Post Road, Brookfield, Vt. 05036.

DOC.HEAD: The Injustice of It All
DOC.TEXT: In spite of the imperfections, Americans generally tolerate their systems of governance and banking, calming their occasional outrage by considering the alternatives. Those alternatives generally are worse than what already exists, defects and all, but sometimes it is hard to accept that verdict. The systems are forever being tested and so, therefore, is the patience of Americans. The latest outrage is expressed by representatives of 37 states and the District of Columbia who will see a net transfer of wealth from their economies to those with the biggest savings and loan collapses. In the abstract, the outrage is muted. This is one great country, it is reasoned, and if the worst of the collapses were concentrated in just 13 states it is still a national issue to be dealt with by all the people. It is when the numbers, the specific dollar amounts, are detailed and then broadast, as they are now, that the muted outrage is expressed in a great roar. This happens, for instance, when residents in certain states stand to lose $1,000 each. It is then that acceptance breaks down and questions and threats begin. Why, asks Connecticut, should our people lose $1,000 each to send money to Texans, who will benefit by several times that amount? Why should areas of the country whose savings and loan associations played by the rules and kept their institutions solvent have to ship money to those areas in which S&Ls squandered their funds on foolish investment schemes? Alas, that is the way the system works, a system that appears to be filled with injustices but which, experience suggests, is still second to none. Yes, outrages abound. In the 1970s, you may recall, the nation humiliated its savers, the salt-of-the-earth types who played by the rules, who lived within their limits and tried to put a few dollars in the bank for a rainy day. For whatever reasons _ it might have been fiscal and monetary stupidity _ the money ``saved'' in the bank was thrown away. Perhaps stolen would better describe what happened to it. Because inflation raged, and because banks paid out in interest far less than was taken away by inflation, the buying power of savers deteriorated every day. Meanwhile, those who borrowed and bought goods with the money of savers enjoyed tremendous appreciation in value. They enjoyed the good life with the money, took tax deductions and repaid the savers with cheaper dollars. The examples are myriad, and they exist right now. _The young couple who postponed buying a house for the past decade, just waiting for prices to stabilize. Now that they have the money to buy, some lenders who had been throwing money around are stiffening their terms because they made so many bad loans in the past. _The small-business person who took the slow but sure and steady course, who proved his financial reliability by foregoing the wildly expansive course taken by his competitor. Now his credit line is shrinking because the bank made so many bad loans, such as to his competitor, that it has decided to assume a more conservative lending policy. _The young worker who is paying increasingly higher contributions to the Social Security system, not simply to finance his own retirement but to make possible the retirements of the generation before. Anyone can cite specific personal examples, especially when insurance or taxes are involved. They can rage against the injustice, threaten legal action, demand reform. But then, somehow, they learn to live with it. It may not be fair but it is the system, a very imperfect one, always in need of fixing.

DOC.HEAD: Henry Mancini's Childhood: July 4th No Big Deal
DOC.TEXT: When Henry Mancini was a kid in the steel town of Aliquippa, Pa., the Fourth of July wasn't that big a deal. He recalls no big parades, no rockets' red glare, no Sousa marches. However, he notes,``I grew up in an almost 100 percent Italian neighborhood'' where patriotism was alive and well, but the big events were the August ``festas,'' parties celebrating the Feast of St. Anthony and the like. Next Wednesday, though, he'll be part of a big July 4 deal on PBS _ a 90-minute musical celebration, ``A Capitol Fourth 1990.'' Hosted by Beverly Sills and broadcast live from Washington, it'll start at 8 p.m. EDT. Mancini will be the guest conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra on the show, the third time in 10 years he's done that. It's a little different from his usual work, which is writing scores for films _ he's done more than 80 _ or collecting Oscars for his music. Nominated 18 times, he owns four Oscars, which go nicely with his 20 Grammy awards. A flutist and pianist, Mancini, now 66, began writing music arrangements when he was 14. He was inspired three years earlier when his father took him to Pittsburgh to see ``The Crusades,'' a Cecil B. DeMille extravaganza. ``That was the first score that I ever heard with a large orchestra,'' he says. ``And that's what kind of stuck in my head in all those early years. I always had that'' _ writing for film _ ``in the back of my mind.'' His first Hollywood effort, in the early '50s, was for a scene in an Abbott and Costello epic, ``Lost in Alaska.'' He had studied composition, theory and harmony and all that, and arranged for big bands. But nobody taught him to write for films. That small omission from his education didn't bother him, he says: ``You had no choice. But then, I didn't want any choice. I just wanted to work.'' Such on-the-job training can be dicey. Film music has to convey the moment and be precisely timed, right down to the nanosecond. This may lead some to think of a Hollywood composer as an ulcer with a stopwatch. But it would do no good for the rousing chase music of one scene to keep going into the next scene's seduction attempt, at least in most cases. Mancini insists that such problems are small. Sure, he says, ``you make mistakes in your timing, and all of a sudden you've got 10 bars too many because you skipped some time, or you don't have enough. But you go in and fix it.'' Such errors usually are caught before the musicians go to work in the soundstage, he adds. He didn't say what happens if the error isn't caught. But when was the last time you saw a seduction scene with chase music? Mancini's musical dossier includes such evergreens as ``Moon River,'' ``Days of Wine and Roses'' and ``Two for the Road.'' But his jazzy score for TV's ``Peter Gunn'' series of 1958-61 is the one that first gained him national attention, with its use of jazz improvisation and such rarely heard instruments as bass and alto flutes. Hollywood being Hollywood, ``Gunn'' music touched off several TV imitators, including ``Shotgun Slade'' _ the only Western ever to have a jazz score. Mancini's film scores, which include ``Breakfast at Tiffany's,'' ``10,'' and Bill Cosby's new ``Ghost Dad,'' generally seem to use the whole range of instruments and have a rich, natural, non-synthesized sound. It may therefore sadden foes of computer music to learn that Mancini, the graduate of big bands, uses synthesizers. ``I've been using them almost since the first time they came out, in one way or another,'' he says. ``They get interesting sounds, and they get better and better. I use them in conjunction with an acoustic orchestra.'' Heresy? No, says the composer: ``I just think they give you a much bigger palette to work from.''

Elsewhere in television ... YOU VIEWER, ME JANE: NBC News, after thinking things over, has decided to call Jane Pauley's five summer specials ``Real Life With Jane Pauley.'' The prime-time specials will start July 17, and then appear July 24, Aug. 7, Aug. 21 and Sept. 4. The shows are be about American lives in the '90s. SAWYER RETURNS FROM IRAQ: Diane Sawyer returned Monday from Iraq, where she interviewed the country's president, Saddam Hussein, for Thursday's edition of ``PrimeTime Live'' on ABC.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Wed PMs, June 27
