DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Capitol-Blue Note has announced the return of World Pacific Records, the sassy label that introduced American audiences to Brazilian and Indian music. The first new World Pacific LP is ``E,'' introducing Brazilian star Gonzaguinha. There also are three reissues: ``The Legendary Joao Gilberto,'' ``Seduzir'' and ``Toniho Horto.'' Other new Blue Note reissues include: John Coltrane, ``Like Sonny,'' an early example of Coltrane's quartet; Bud Powell, ``The Bud Powell Trio Plays,'' containing 16 works never before collected for American release; Louis Armstrong and Duke Ellington, ``The Complete Louis Armstrong & Duke Ellington Sessions,'' an excellent arrangement of Ellington compositions and Armstrong's sextet; Count Basie and Tony Bennett, ``Basie Swings-Bennett Sings''; and Maynard Ferguson, ``Maynard '61.'' Blue Note also focuses on new musicians this month, with drummer Ralph Peterson's contemporary hard-bop on ``Volition,'' and the lyrical tones of pianist Eliane Elias with her samba-laced ``Eliane Elias Plays Jobim.''

Charles Mingus was a composer, bass player and pianist. He also was something of a jazz historian and keeper of the flame, infusing his compositions with the structures and innovations of others such as Duke Ellington and Fats Waller. Mingus died on Jan. 5, 1979 of Lou Gehrig's Disease. A decade later, a 30-year project culminated with a two-hour concert at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall. ``Epitaph'' was an orchestral masterwork. Columbia Records made a live recording of the concert and it is now available as a double-CD. It is a rich translation, mirroring all the tempestuous thunder of Mingus' composition as well as its sweet melodies and contradicting harmonies.

The Museum of Modern Art pays tribute to Twentieth Century Fox this summer with a retrospective of over 90 films made between 1935 and 1965. Opening July 1, ``Twentieth Century Fox: 1935-1965'' traces three key decades in the history of the studio, celebrating the talents of the artists on both sides of the cameras who shaped this period. Formed in 1915, the Fox Film Corporation merged in 1935 with the much younger Twentieth Century to launch a major new studio. The exhibition will highlight the epic biographies of the 1930s such as John Ford's ``The Prisoner of Shark Island'' (1936). Also on exhibit will be a series of Technicolor musicals developed during World War II, featuring such actresses as Betty Grable and Carmen Miranda. The '50s segment shows how the studio maintained its preeminence with an entire new generation of stars _ epitomized by Marilyn Monroe _ and the introduction of CinemaScope, which literally changed the shape of motion pictures for years to come. The retrospective runs through September 11.

Bob Seger's ex-wife says in a lawsuit that the rock singer assaulted her after their divorce and pressured her into having an abortion. Annette Seger's suit, which was filed June 22 in Oakland County Circuit Court, said she told Seger she was pregnant about two weeks after the couple divorced on Nov. 8, 1988. It says that Seger allegedly told her that he would make her life ``a living hell'' unless she had an abortion. The suit also claims Seger provided no help or comfort to Annette Seger before, during or after the abortion, although they were living together. The Segers were married in Las Vegas in November 1987. Frederick G. Buesser III, an attorney who represented the rock star in his divorce, said he couldn't comment on Annette Seger's allegations because he hadn't seen the suit. The suit also claims that Seger threw his ex-wife against a cement wall on Jan. 26, 1989, after she walked out of an unnamed nightclub they had entered together. Seger allegedly followed her outside, and said, ``Come back here! Don't you dare walk out on me, damn it.'' She claims she suffered emotional and physical distress and was hospitalized for four days because of her ex-husband's conduct. Annette Seger, who also claims her modeling career has suffered, is seeking more than $10,000 in damages.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release Anytime

DOC.TEXT: Mid-June sales of North American-made cars and trucks lagged 3.6 percent behind a lackluster sales period last year as the Big Three automakers couldn't match gains at U.S. plants owned by Japanese companies. Domestic automakers said Monday they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 37,962 during the June 11-20 period, compared with an average of 39,392 a day in the same period last year. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said their mid-June sales dropped 6.8 percent to an average daily rate of 34,655. Sales of U.S.-made cars with Japanese nameplates jumped 54.7 percent to an average of 2,854 a day.

The nation's top savings and loan regulator issued rules aimed at making hundreds of struggling thrifts a more attractive investment. Office of Thrift Supervision Director Timothy Ryan told a meeting of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions Monday the rules would allow struggling thrifts to pay some earnings to stockholders on a sliding scale, depending on their condition. Healthy thrifts could distribute earnings without restriction, while clearly weak institutions would be barred from paying dividends without special permission.

Sales of existing homes continued their yearlong drop in May, but falling mortgage rates helped limit the decrease, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Monday that resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.29 million, down 1.2 percent from April's rate of 3.33 million. Sales in April dropped 2.1 percent.

Japan and the United States disagreed over specific plans for structural reforms of the Japanese economy, but a senior U.S. official said progress was made and the talks were ``friendly and cooperative.'' Officials said Monday the first round of the talks, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, focused on Japan's plans for changing policies and business practices that are thought to impede imports and foreign investment. Japan has agreed, at U.S. urging, to spend more on parks, roads, sewers and other public infrastructure, but the two sides differ on how much.

International Lease Finance Corp., a major aircraft leaser, agreed to be acquired by American International Group Inc. for $1.3 billion to gain the financial backing of the insurance giant. AIG, the largest U.S. underwriter of commercial and industrial insurance, also will provide ILFC with $125 million in financing as part of the deal. Analysts and company spokesmen said the deal gives ILFC financial muscle at a time when it must borrow heavily to complete an ambitious expansion.

The Supreme Court decided against exempting the mining industry from some federal environmental rules for treating, storing and disposing hazardous waste. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal Monday by the American Mining Congress and a mining company, Solite Corp. The two challenged a 1987 decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to apply the hazardous waste regulations to the mining industry.

Foxboro Co., a leading international maker of manufacturing control systems, has agreed to be acquired for $656.4 million in cash by the British firm Siebe PLC, the companies said. Under the deal, the Windsor, England, company said Monday it would pay $52 a share for Foxboro's 12.6 million outstanding shares, in a cash tender offer to begin Friday. Siebe stockholders must approve the deal.

If Donald Trump can't convince a German bank to agree to a bailout and debt restructuring plan by midnight tonight, he faces formal default on bonds used to finance one of his three Atlantic City, N.J., casinos. Late Monday night, a French bank, Societe Generale, agreed to the plan, a banking source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Trump and about 60 other banks have today to talk Dresdner Bank AG into going along with the deal that would provide the developer with enough money to make a payment of about $43 million on bonds used to finance the Trump Castle hotel and casino.

Booming business greeted the weekend debut of Sony Corp.'s digital audio tape deck, and many stores were sold out of the biggest item to hit the recording industry since compact discs. Nationwide sales figures had not been compiled Monday, but Sony officials and store owners were pleased.

Stock prices fell broadly Monday on concerns about rising interest rates and the prospect of weak corporate earnings. The Dow Jones industrials average dropped 12.13 points to 2,845.05. Bond prices fell and interest rates rose sharply as the Treasury's resupply auction triggered fears of a bond glut. The dollar was mixed and gold rose. Energy futures were mixed; corn and soybean futures rose; precious metals advanced; copper fell; livestock futures were mixed; and pork bellies declined the daily limit for the third straight day.

DOC.HEAD: Rates on Short-Term Securities Rise to Highest Level in Four Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose at the latest auction to their highest level in four weeks. The Treasury Department sold $8.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.78 percent on Monday, up from 7.74 percent last week. Another $8.6 billion in six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.67 percent, up from 7.64 percent last week. The rates were the highest since May 29, when three-month bills sold for 7.80 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.74 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.05 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,803.30 and 8.09 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,612.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said the average yield for 1-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable-rate mortgages, rose to 8.14 percent last week, up from 8.05 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: T. Boone Pickens, Japanese Target Square Off This Week
DOC.TEXT: Oilman and investor T. Boone Pickens expects to lose his battle with Koito Manufacturing Co. Ltd. at Thursday's annual shareholder meeting. The war, however, will go on. ``As long as you can hold out, remain on the right side of the issue, you'll eventually prevail,'' Pickens said in a recent interview in his downtown Dallas office. Pickens, whose request for a seat on the company's board of directors was denied last year, is asking for four seats on the board at this year's annual meeting. Pickens says his fight with Koito, which makes automobile headlights chiefly for Toyota Motor Corp., is about open investment in Japan. The company's refusal to put him on its board, Pickens says, is an example of Japanese unwillingness to allow outside investors into the country. ``This is about the long term. This is about the future of trade relations between Japan and the United States, about the future of the Japanese shareholder, consumer and working family,'' Pickens said at the Foreign Correspondents Press Club today in Tokyo. He has sought help from Trade Representative Carla Hills and Congress, with little visible impact. ``It has nothing to do with trade issues,'' Hamilton Loeb, Koito's American lawyer, said in a telephone interview from Tokyo. Loeb represented Unocal Corp. when the oil company fought off Pickens' advances in 1985. Koito has rebuffed Pickens by saying he is after greenmail _ having the company buy back its stock at a premium to avoid a takeover attempt. The company also has suggested he is simply the front man for Kitaro Watanabe, whom the company also brands as a greenmailer. The latest salvo in the battle came Monday. Koito issued a statement saying Pickens really is not the company's biggest stockholder as he claims, a charge Pickens quickly denied. Pickens bought his Koito shares from Watanabe, described by Koito president Takao Matsuura as ``an infamous Japanese greenmailer.'' ``We are confident there is a secret agreement. The terms of it we can only speculate about,'' Loeb said. Pickens repeatedly has said he is not after greenmail but is a long-term investor in Koito. The company says his investment does not make financial sense. Although he is a multimillionaire, Pickens' $1 billion investment in Koito is sizable even for him. But he refuses to tell how he financed his purchases of the stock. ``It isn't management's option to question that,'' he said. ``If he were doing this in the United States,'' Loeb said, ``he would be obligated to make disclosures of any agreement he had with anybody about the stock.'' If Pickens owns the 26 percent of the stock he claims, Toyota would be the second-largest shareholder. Pickens contends Toyota leads a keiretsu, or business alliance, and forces Koito to sell its auto parts at depressed prices to the advantage of Toyota profits and the detriment of Koito shareholders. ``I'm a geologist, not an economist, but I do know that whatever you call it: a cartel, a trust, a monopoly, a keiretsu or a zaibatsu, it's wrong,'' Pickens said in Tokyo today. Since being denied a board seat at last year's shareholder meeting, Pickens has sought to inspect Koito's books and increase its dividend. Koito last year agreed to increase the dividend, but only by about half what Pickens sought. Aside from seeking four seats on the 20-member board, Pickens has proposed an anti-greenmail resolution; an annual statement on whether Koito has been forced to engage in anti-competitive activities; an annual shareholder vote on salary and retirement benefits of board members; an annual report on pricing policies; a further increase in the dividend, and an accounting of the ``shito-fumeikin fund,'' which Pickens suggests amounts to an illegal slush fund.

DOC.HEAD: Coming to Your Local Sears: $999 IBM Computer for the Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference at 10 a.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: IBM today launched its second assault on the home computer market, a drive to tap the millions of Americans it says want a home machine but have been scared by the technology. The computers will be priced as low as $999 and, in a departure for the world's largest computer company, will be sold at mainstream retailers such as Sears, Roebuck and Co., Dillards Department Stores and Dayton's Department Stores. The machines were designed for people who have gained some knowledge of computers through their work but don't want to learn all the technical terms and concepts associated with them. International Business Machines Corp. believes the potential audience is huge, said Skip Gladfelter, marketing manager for the new line. ``We think there are millions of families sitting on the sidelines,'' he said in an interview Monday. The computers, called the Personal System-1 line, will go on sale today in stores in the Chicago, Dallas-Fort Worth and Minneapolis-St. Paul areas, IBM said. The national rollout will come in September. IBM's first assault on the home market turned into a bitter failure. Production of the machines _ dubbed the PCjr _ was halted about a year and a half after they were launched in 1983. PCjr was criticized for a toylike keyboard, limited memory and a too-steep price. This time around, IBM executives say they plan to succeed. Their first step was to determine what went wrong with PCjr. ``We all got Ph.D.s in PCjr,'' said Robert Amezcua, product manager for the new PS-1 line. Then a group of about 50 IBM employees in Lexington, Ky., began trying to figure out what consumers wanted, Gladfelter said. Since the fall of 1988, about 3,000 consumers had a say in the new line's design through interviews and participation in focus groups, he said. Among the features requested was ease of use, a low price, sufficient computing power to handle popular office-computer software and availability at non-computer stores, he said. Like the more expensive Macintosh from Apple Computer Inc., the PS-1 line can be set up in minutes. Also like the Mac, the computers feature graphics and a hand-held device called a mouse, which manipulates an arrow on-screen to let users to chose the function they want to run. The computers are built around the Intel Corp. 80286 microprocessor, used in millions of office computers. They also use the popular DOS operating system, making them compatible with thousands of applications programs for home and office use. Each machine contains a built-in modem, which allows computers to hook up to distant computers or data services via phone lines. One such service, jointly owned by IBM and Sears, is Prodigy. It provides such things as home banking, shopping and airline reservations. The PS-1 line contains a built-in program that provides an automatic linkup to Prodigy. The computers also include a popular software package from Microsoft Corp. that combines a word processor, a spreadsheet, a database program and a communications program to run the modem. The two cheapest PS-1s lack a hard disc, which is used to store many of the programs on the two high-end models. That means users of these models must insert a diskette containing the software after they turn on the machine. On the more expensive models, the programs automatically are pulled off the hard disc when the computers are turned on. Two of the models have black-and-white screens, while the other two offer color. The most expensive model, with a suggested retail price of $1,999, has more memory in addition to the hard disc and color monitor. All four machines feature full-size keyboards. But none has a printer, which computer industry consultant Sam Albert said could be a drawback for some potential purchasers. Industry analysts say that although many families may want a home computer, it may compete on a wish list with other expensive electronics devices, such as camcorders, laser disc players and large-screen TVs. Analysts also say IBM may have a rough time marketing the computers as consumer spending is declining due to economic uncertainty. Albert, a former IBM executive, said IBM may have solved the ease-of-use problem, but it still needs to show consumers why they need a home computer, ``besides keeping up with the Joneses.''

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Sales Trail in Mid June
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: The sluggish economy continued to dampen the automobile market as sales of North American-made cars and trucks fell 3.6 percent in mid-June from the same period last year. And once again, the Big Three automakers bore the full brunt of the slowdown as transplant vehicles, made in U.S. plants by Japanese companies, snapped up whatever sales gains were to be found. Continuing incentive programs failed to stem the weak sales trend at General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., said automotive analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Hutton. ``We are still unable to bloody the nose of the imports,'' he said. Overall, domestic automakers said they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 37,962 during the June 11-20 period, compared with an average of 39,392 a day during the same period last year. Car sales trailed by 4.5 percent and light truck sales lagged 2.2 percent. GM, Ford and Chrysler said their combined mid-June sales dropped 6.8 percent to an average daily rate of 34,655 from 37,192 last year. Sales of U.S.-made cars with Japanese nameplates jumped 54.7 percent to an average daily rate of 2,854. Honda and Toyota paced the Japanese makers with increases of more than 60 percent. For the year through June 20, North American-made car and truck sales ran 4.4 percent behind last year's, with car sales trailing 5.7 percent and light truck sales down 2.1 percent. The decline was despite a 40.4 percent rise in transplant car sales. ``I'm hearing more people starting to use the ``R'' word, meaning recession, with respect to the fact that the economy is just sort of muddling along,'' Phillippi said. ``Not a bad one, but just modestly in that gray area of being in a recession.'' Chrysler reported the sharpest drop, with mid-June vehicle sales 15.5 percent behind last year's pace. Car sales dropped 18.3 percent. Sales of light trucks, including the minivans that provide much of the company's profits, dropped 12.9 percent. For the year, Chrysler's car and light truck sales trailed last year's pace by 13.2 percent, with car sales down 18 percent and truck sales down 8.5 percent. GM said combined mid-June car and truck sales were off 6.2 percent. Car sales were down 7.8 percent and light trucks sales were down 2.9 percent. For the year, GM said it sold 4.8 percent fewer vehicles than a year earlier. Car sales were down 7.5 percent and truck sales were up 0.6 percent. Ford reported a 2.8 percent mid-June drop in car and truck sales. Car sales lagged 7.4 percent while truck sales were up 4 percent. Ford said its vehicle sales were down 8.4 percent for the year, with cars off 12.4 percent and trucks down 2.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: DAT Sales Kickoff Revives Fight Over Royalties, Copying
DOC.TEXT: Sales of Sony Corp.'s new digital audio tape decks are off to a strong start, but not everybody's happy. Songwriters fear the machines _ which allow consumers to make near-perfect pirate copies of compact disks _ will rob them of royalties. ``We will seek court relief from the equipment being brought into this country,'' said Edward Murphy, president of the National Music Publishers Association in New York. A version of the DAT recorder has been sold in Japan and some parts of Europe since 1987, and has been available through unofficial channels in the United States. But manufacturers held back from launching the machines openly in this country because of a dispute over copying. In a concession to record companies, the manufacturers agreed to offer machines that can make only copies of CDs, not copies of copies. Sony became the first to offer popular priced recorders to American consumers Friday. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. _ the Japanese firm that produces the Panasonic, Technics and Quasar brands _ hopes to have a competitively priced DAT recorder in U.S. stores by September, a spokesman said. Sony's DTC-75ES, priced at $950, includes circuitry that ``flags'' digital tapes copied from compact disc to prevent the tapes from being copied. Including that technology was part of an agreement between manufacturers and the recording industry that seemed to remove the threat of lawsuits from record companies. But the accord, and bills in the House and Senate that would write the agreement into law, did not resolve the festering issue of royalty payments for home taping. George David Weiss, representing the Copyright Coalition, told a Senate subcommittee two weeks ago that the Senate bill ``forces songwriters to give away copies of our music without payment of any kind.'' Murphy said his group was collecting information on the models available or soon to hit the U.S. market to prepare for legal action. ``We have several legal options. We will pursue some form of legal remedy,'' Murphy said, without elaborating. The debate apparently didn't hamper sales in the first weekend. ``I don't think people stormed the doors, but it was generally very successful,'' said Shari Haber, spokeswoman for Sony in Park Ridge, N.J. Manny Couto, sales manager at a Sound Advice store in Miami, said interest in the decks was ``tremendous.'' ``It took our company, which is represented in Florida with 17 stores, three days to sell out of about 40 pieces,'' Couto said. ``A lot of people bought. A lot of people are looking.'' In Portland, Ore., and Seattle, Magnolia Hi-Fi was the only store to carry the DTC-75ES. Another version selling for about $50 less, the DTC-700, will be available in more stores this week. Dave Kaplan, vice president-purchasing for Magnolia, said he sold one-third of his machines over the weekend without advertising. ``We got off to a pretty good start with the DAT machine,'' Kaplan said. He would not say how many machines his store received, calling it proprietary information. Magnolia sold the machines for $900, he said. Chris Brezil, the manager at Stereo Exchange in New York, said he sold his first shipment of ``five to 10'' digital audio tape machines before they arrived. ``The response seems to be quite good,'' said Brezil. Bill Ramsay, manager at Point Electronics in the Detroit suburb of Grosse Point Woods, said he's trying to get more even though he has three of his original four left. ``We received tremendous promotional support from Sony and we just haven't taken advantage of it yet,'' Ramsay said. ``We've had a lot of interest, and we'll sell these without any trouble once people know they're here.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Concern Buys Jetliner Leasing Outfit
DOC.TEXT: International Lease Finance Corp., the biggest U.S. aircraft leaser, has agreed to a $1.3 billion buyout by American International Group Inc. to gain the financial backing of the insurance giant. AIG, the largest U.S. underwriter of commercial and industrial insurance, also will provide ILFC with $125 million in financing as part of the deal. Analysts and spokesmen for the companies said the deal gives ILFC financial muscle at a time when it must borrow heavily to complete an ambitious expansion. ``They've found someone with lots of cash, low cost of funds, and willing to take some greater risk in return for greater rewards,'' said Daniel A. Hersch, a securities analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. in Los Angeles. ILFC has grown strongly in recent years as airlines have relied more on leasing because of the high cost of and long wait for new aircraft purchases. The company owns 98 jetliners worth more than $3 billion and averaging only three years of age. It also has placed $10 billion worth of firm orders for planes to be delivered over 10 years, and has another $4 billion in options. That means ILFC, which has had to borrow heavily and issue new stock to finance past deals, will need much more capital at a time when it is harder to come by. ``I think that having a strategic alliance with a backer of the stature and credit-worthiness of AIG should instill a greater confidence in the financial markets,'' Jay Jacobsen, a spokesman for ILFC, said in a telephone interview from New York. AIG's triple-A debt rating, the highest possible, will enable ILFC to borrow funds more cheaply to finance new aircraft purchases, said Maurice R. Greeberg, chairman and chief executive officer of the New York-based insurer. That's important with the pricetag for planes reaching as high as $125 million for Boeing's new 747-400, he said. The deal also helps AIG increase its business in financial services other than insurance, Greenberg said. ``It's a perfect fit,'' he said. AIG had operating income of about $150 million in financial services other than insurance last year out of total operating income of nearly $2 billion, Greenberg said. The company hopes to boost that figure to close to $500 million in the next couple of years, he said. The buyout price of $32.50 a share is about 15 or 16 times expected earnings for this year, at the top of the recent trading range for ILFC stock, Hersch said. The stock closed at $26.87{ in over-the-counter trading Monday. It had sunk as low as $19.37{ in the past year. Jacobsen said the stock had been undervalued because of investor worries over debt, despite the fact that ILFC's purchase agreements for Boeing and other planes are at extremely good prices. ``The asset values were substantially above the stock price,'' he said. ILFC's management will be unchanged and the company will continue to be based in Beverly Hills, operating as a wholly owned AIG subsidiary. It is 53 percent owned by three men, all of whom have approved the merger: Leslie L. Gonda, the board chairman; Steven F. Udvar-Hazy, president and chief executive; and Louis L. Gonda, executive vice president. The definitive agreement has been approved by AIG's executive committee, by ILFC's directors, and by a special committee of ILFC's independent directors, the companies said in a joint news statement. Under the deal, ILFC shareholders can receive $32.50 a share in cash or 50 cents a share plus 0.3 shares of AIG common stock. The amount of AIG stock to be exchanged can be adjusted depending on AIG's share price at the time the deal closes. ILFC's three controlling owners have agreed to accept AIG stock for their holdings, Jacobsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Groups Call for Jeep CJ Investigation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Three consumer groups are accusing Chrysler Corp. of withholding evidence of rollover problems in 300,000 Jeep CJs, but the company and the government say the safety advocates have nothing new. Brandishing a 3-inch-thick pile of internal Chrysler and American Motors documents, the auto safety advocates filed a petition Monday for a full-scale federal investigation into the CJ and Chrysler's actions. The Institute for Injury Reduction, the Center for Auto Safety and Public Citizen turned over the documents, which they said prove that AMC and Chrysler knew of problems with the CJ-5 and CJ-7. The papers came from court cases against the CJ. Tim Hurd, spokesman for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said the government already had all the material in its inquiry into the safety of Jeep CJs built by American Motors between 1971 and 1986. Chrysler took over AMC in 1987. ``We are very well acquainted with this vehicle, and we are reviewing any information which comes to us,'' Hurd said. The agency conducted a safety analysis of the CJs a decade ago and has turned down two previous requests to reopen the investigation or to conduct a new one, Hurd said. Benjamin Kelley of the Institute for Injury Reduction, said the CJ ``epitomizes the worst in both vehicle safety and manufacturer indifference. Joan Claybrook of Public Citizen called the CJs ``deathtraps.'' Representatives of the three consumer groups appeared at a news conference with a 42-year-old electrician who said he had been crippled in a Jeep rollover. ``I went from a productive member of society to what you see,'' said Ed Keller of Hughesville, Md., who struggled to the podium on forearm crutches. Keller said a 1981 rollover in a Jeep CJ-5 broke his back. The groups cited problems with a shackle pin on the CJ that ``could induce or aggravate the likelihood of rollover.'' Shackle pins connect the Jeep body to its suspension system. They also said the vehicles' rollbars are inadequate to protect drivers in a rollover. Ms. Claybrook, who formerly headed NHTSA, said the CJ-5's high center of gravity and narrow track give it little resistance to rolling over. She said 203 people died in CJ accidents last year, 75 percent of them in rollovers. A study cited at the news conference maintained that the CJ-5 is 20 times more likely to roll over than an average car and that the CJ-7 is 12 times more likely. A videotape played for reporters showed a CJ-5 rolling over as it swerved at 32 miles per hour on a flat, dry roadway. Chrysler responded that the CJ ``is a safe vehicle _ always has been and still is'' and that the groups' charges ``are hardly worth responding to again.'' ``These organizations, which derive significant support from plaintiffs' attorneys, are simply trying to generate more business for these supporters,'' the company said in a statement distributed outside the hotel conference room where the groups announced the petition.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the yen but gained against the West German mark in European trading this morning. Gold prices were lower. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 155.23 yen, down 0.39 yen from Monday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 155.00 yen. The dollar declined in Tokyo trading mainly because of selling in an attempt to take profits from its overnight rise in New York, dealers said. In New York, the dollar closed Monday at 155.40 yen. Investors also bought the yen and sold the West German mark to take profits from the rising West German currency, helping the yen firm against the dollar today, said Noriaki Ebisui, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. DOC.HEAD: Stocks Remoubnd, Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index rebounded sharply today, while the dollar inched down. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average regained 447.58 points, or 1.44 percent, closing at 31,571.77. The index, which lost 570.38 points on Monday, rose in part Tuesday from arbitrage buying by investors seeking to take profits from price gaps between the spot and the futures markets, traders said. Yoshio Ogawa, chief trader with Nikko Securities Co., added, ``Stability in the yen and the slip in the yield of the government bonds reassured investors.'' The Bank of Japan also bought $1.3 billion worth of Japanese government bonds today, he said, and investors ``saw the action as indicating the central bank's policy to allow no further rises in the nation's short-term interest rates.'' Trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 400 million shares, up from Monday's 300 million. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 155.23 yen, down 0.39 yen from Monday's 155.62-yen finish. It opened at 155.30 yen and ranged between 154.98 yen and 155.43 yen. The dollar had gained a total of 1.90 yen in the previous four trading days. The dollar declined in Tokyo trading mainly because of selling in an attempt to take profits from its overnight rise in New York, dealers said. In New York, the dollar closed Monday at 155.40 yen, up from 154.90 yen Friday. Investors also bought the yen and sold the West German mark to take profits from the rising West German currency, helping the yen's strength against the dollar Tuesday, said Noriaki Ebisui, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. He said, however, that trading was not very active in the absence of market-affecting news. Chemical Bank dealer Akiyoshi Sakai said market players had little incentive to buy more Japanese currency because of uncertainties over current trade talks. Japan and the United States have been having trouble agreeing on how much Japan should spend on public works to bring down its trade surpluses. About $9.37 billion changed hands in spot trading. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.12 points as of 5 p.m. from Monday's 86.91-point close. The yield declined to 7.160 percent from 7.205 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators May Make Charges Public Against S&L Officers
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS dropped `s' in `sons' in lead
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan regulators are considering publicly releasing administrative charges against thrift officers, including one of President Bush's sons, before the cases are judged. Timothy Ryan, director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, told reporters Monday that in the next week or two he expected to decide on a policy governing when and if the agency publicizes such charges. House Democrats last week called on him to release conflict-of-interest charges concerning Neil Bush and Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. But, Ryan said he preferred to set a broad policy rather than decide the matter on one case. Separately, Ryan's agency issued rules aimed at making hundreds of struggling S&Ls a more attractive investment. Such thrifts will now be permitted to pay some earnings to stockholders on a sliding scale, depending on their condition. Healthy thrifts can distribute earnings without restriction, while clearly weak institutions would be barred from paying dividends without special permission. Regulators allege that Neil Bush's interests as an oil and gas developer in Colorado conflicted with his duties on Silverado's board. Silverado made loans, which were not repaid, to Bush's business associates. Bush has denied wrongdoing, but the OTS is pursuing administrative actions against him. Currently, the agency publicizes administrative penalties after they are imposed; however, it rarely releases the charges while an accused executive is contesting them. Hearings on charges before administrative law judges are almost always private. Ryan said the new policy could spell out when charges would be released and hearings conducted in public. Historically, regulators have been reluctant to release charges before they are decided for fear of scaring depositors, he said. But in the case of an institution already closed by the government, such as Silverado, there presumably would be less impact on depositors, Ryan said. The new dividend regulation aims to strike a balance between struggling institutions' need to pay dividends to attract capital from new investors and their need to retain earnings to build capital. Under the rule, 1,185 thrifts that already meet tough new capital standards taking effect in 1994 could freely distribute earnings to shareholders, while 716 that fail current capital requirements would be barred from paying dividends unless the OTS approved a special application. An additional 612 thrifts that comply with the current standard but not the future standard could distribute 25 percent to 75 percent of their income, depending on how close they are to meeting the 1994 rules. Ryan announced the policy to the U.S. League of Savings Institutions, the thrift industry's chief trade group. It was his first public speech since taking office April 9.

In over-the-counter trading, International Lease Finance Corp. was up 3| to 30}. AIG was down 2 to 94{ on the NYSE. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.39 to 193.99. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .75 at 358.14.

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybeans Retreat On Moderating Weather Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices slipped in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid diminishing prospects for an extended Midwestern heat wave. Wheat futures rose slightly. The corn and soybean markets fell sharply at the opening, then recovered somewhat as the market absorbed new weather forecasts, including the National Weather Service's latest six-to-10-day outlook. That forecast, released late Monday, predicts near-normal temperatures for the Midwest during the period July 1-5. The NWS forecast and similar projections by private meteorologists reduced fears of an extended heat wave that helped drive corn and soybean futures up sharply Monday. ``For the moment, the excitement is out of here,'' said John Frazier, director of the agricultural trading division of Gerald Inc. in Chicago. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.34{ a bushel; corn was } cent to 2 cents lower with July at $2.86 a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with July at $1.37} a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 5 cents lower with July at $6.11 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent to .18 cent higher with August at 73.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .13 cent higher with August at 84.60 cents a pound; hogs were .10 cent to .40 cent higher with August at 58.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent to .88 cent higher with July at 57.65 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mostly lower Monday while hog futures advanced and pork bellies fell sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Reported Ready to Impose Delays in Offshore Oil Leasing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with new material and editing.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided to impose long delays in offshore oil leasing off California and Florida, according to an administration official. The White House was preparing an announcement later today. The delay in granting new leases for offshore oil drilling would apply to one large area off south Florida, one region off Southern California and one off Northern California, the offical said. Moratoriums of up to a decade would be imposed in most of the area under consideration, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Administration sources said earlier that Bush wanted to forestall new oil drilling in those areas pending more study on potential impact to the environment. The area covered by the decision includes a 6.7-million-acre section of ocean off Southern California, 1.2 million acres off Northern California, and 13 million acres in the Gulf of Mexico near the Florida everglades. Officials have said Bush was leaning toward imposing the longest waiting period off the Florida Keys _ until the year 2002 or beyond. Bush named a task force last year, headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, to work with the National Academy of Sciences in studying the environmental impact of opening the three areas to new leasing. The task force concluded that more study of the environmental effects was needed. Bush has repeatedly stated his wish to protect environmentally sensitive areas, but also has said the nation should not have to depend on foreign oil. Bush postponed announcing a decision in the wake of a recent massive tanker spill off Galveston, Texas. A Norwegian tanker was rocked by an explosion June 8, spilling 3.9 million gallons of oil. It created a 30-mile oil slick some 18 miles offshore. Most of it was skimmed off, burned, or evapaorated. The entire Florida congressional delegation and most of the California delegation have urged delays in new leasing. Republicans were especially sensitive to political fallout likely from any decision to open new oil-drilling regions in an election year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says More Tax Revenues Needed to Cut Deficit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 8th graf pvs, ``The budget ... to UPDATE with budget talks resuming Wednesday; picks up 9th graf pvs, Deficit estimates...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that ``tax revenue increases'' must be included in any deficit-reduction package that the White House works out with congressional negotiators. Bush's initial statement did not provide specifics on taxes, but Democrats immediately hailed it as presidential acceptance for a tax increase. ``The president has concluded that tax increases are necessary and we share the president's view,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who, along with other congressional leaders, met with the president. ``We are not willing to give it any definition,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of Bush's statement. ``That's a matter for the negotiators.'' ``No decision has been made with respect to any specific measures,'' Mitchell agreed. The president issued the statement as he met at the White House with top congressional leaders to review the sluggish negotiations on a plan to reduce the deficit. Bush also called for cuts in spending for federal benefits as well as other domestic and defense programs, and said congressional leaders agreed with him. Fitzwater and congressional leaders said the talks would resume Wednesday with the hope that they might be completed by the time lawmakers take their August recess. Deficit estimates have increased substantially since Bush unveiled his proposed 1991 budget in January and red ink may total more than $200 billion in the next fiscal year. Until now, when asked whether the president would accept higher taxes, Bush and his aides have repeatedly said that they have stopped using Bush's campaign pledge of ``No new taxes.'' At a news conference, congressional Democratic leaders refused to say whether they thought he had broken his campaign pledge. However, they also made clear they thought the political landscape had changed. ``Someone who is complaining about taxes being raised in the budget summit will have to complain against both parties and the president if they wish to make that kind of complaint,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. Other elements that Bush said must be included in a deficit-reduction plan were cuts in federal benefit programs, other domestic initiatives and defense; reforms in the federal budget process and ``growth incentives.'' The term growth incentives is often used to describe a reduction in the capital gains tax, which Bush has fought for since taking office last year. The president says such a cut would stimulate economic growth, while opponents say it would simply be a gift to the wealthy, who own most of the real estate and other property that would qualify for the reduction. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, called Bush's statement ``an important step in the right direction.'' ``It is clear to me that any program comprehensive enough to make a significant dent in the deficit will have to include both spending cuts and tax increases,'' said Rostenkowski, D-Ill., who did not attend the meeting with Bush. ``I am pleased that the president shares that view.'' The fiscal 1991 budget Bush unveiled in January contained $19.7 billion in new taxes, user fees and other revenues. Some congressional leaders have complained throughout seven weeks of budget negotiations that that amount is insufficient to take a serious bite out of the deficit. The Gramm-Rudman law will trigger widespread spending cuts on Oct. 1 _ the start of fiscal 1991 _ unless the gap is kept to $74 billion or less. In his statement, Bush also said he agreed that ``orderly reductions in defense expenditures'' were needed. But he did not specify the amount of cuts he would favor. Bush has proposed reducing defense spending next year by $3 billion below what it have grown to if it kept pace with inflation. Congressional Democrats would like the cut to be about $10 billion or more. Bush held a morning meeting at the White House with House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash.; Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine; House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo.; Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. A budget bargaining session between White House and congressional representatives set for Monday was canceled. No further meetings were scheduled. The cancellation came four days after the last negotiating session, which ended with Democrats rejecting the administration's $51 billion deficit-reduction proposal for next year as inadequate.

The stock market headed higher today, after declines in the last two sessions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 12.13 points on Monday, was up 11.39 points to 2,856.44 at noon on Wall Street. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 8 to 5 in trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 808 up, 493 down and 515 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 71.75 million shares, compared with 66.02 million shares at the same time Monday. Analysts said the market benefited from a surge in the bond market, which on remarks by President Bush that gave traders hope for falling interest rates. Bush, after meeting with congressional leaders, conceded tax increases will be needed to bring the federal deficit ``under responsible control.'' A lower deficit generally means less borrowing by the federal government and more room for interest rates to fall. Analysts also say the Federal Reserve would be more inclined to lower interest rates if Congress approves a package to cut the deficit. Analysts also said the stock market was adjusting after losses Friday and Monday. The market had slipped over concern about higher interest rates and weaker corporate earnings. Caterpillar, which led Monday's decline with a 5-point drop, fell another 6| to 51~ in heavy trading. Caterpillar said Monday that the company was expecting sharply lower earnings in the second quarter. IBM was up | to 117\, as the computer giant launched a home computer to sell for $999 in mainstream retail stores. Among other active issues on the NYSE, Philip Morris was up \ to 46~; Commonwealth Edison was up [ to 32|; General Motors was down ~ to 47; and Boeing was up \ to 57{. In over-the-counter trading, International Lease Finance Corp. was up 3} to 30~. Late Monday, the aircraft leasing company said it had agreed to a $1.3 billion buyout by American International Group Inc., the nation's largest commercial and industrial insurance underwriter. AIG was down 1| to 94{ on the NYSE. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks rose .88 to 193.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .50 at 357.89.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Bank Corp. Eliminates 900 Jobs in Cost-Cutting Move
DOC.TEXT: Continental Bank Corp. said today it is eliminating about 900 jobs and several product lines as part of cost-cutting measures expected to save $75 million a year. The bank holding company said it anticipated a second-quarter loss as a result of the moves. Continentnal said it would no longer engage in futures and options execution and clearing, a business the company began to exit with the sale of Securities Settlement Corp. last year. Continental also said it plans to sell First Options of Chicago Inc. The bank holding company already has announced in Tokyo it would discontinue trading U.S. Treasury securities and foreign exchange trading for its own account there. The company said it will establish a special pretax reserve of $50 million to cover the cost of eliminating the various product lines. Establishment of the reserve will result in a loss for the second quarter, Continental said. Jobs being eliminated include positions in trading, marketing and support staff, said Continental spokesman Ted McDougal. About one-third of the staff reductions will take place outside of Chicago, most of them overseas, McDougal said. Before the cuts began, the company had 6,720 employees, excluding First Options' 700 workers. The cuts are expected to result in a savings of $25 million in the second half of this year, and $75 million annually beginning in 1991, Continental said. The company said its goal is to increase revenue and reduce expenses to achieve ``its longstanding financial goals of a 30 percent operating margin and return on common equity of 15 percent.'' ``Continental's product review reflects the realities of the marketplace,'' said Chairman Thomas C. Theobald. ``It's a market reality that a client needs change over time. ``We aren't altering our corporate and institutional strategy. All we're doing is aligning our services with the customers' changing demands,'' Theobald said.

DOC.HEAD: Fort Wayne Insurer Begins Alliance with Japanese Company
DOC.TEXT: Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Co. is acquiring a 9.6 percent stake in Lincoln National Corp., the biggest investment yet by a Japanese insurer in a U.S. insurance company, Lincoln announced Tuesday. Dai-Ichi will acquire the stake in Fort Wayne-based Lincoln National through a $312 million convertible preferred stock transaction. The two companies also will enter into a series of business relationships to offer investment management services, reinsurance, pension products and group health products, Lincoln National said in a news release. ``This is a very attractive arrangement for both Lincoln National and Dai-Ichi Mutual Life,'' said Ian M. Rolland, president and chief executive officer of Lincoln National. ``It offers strategic opportunities for both of our companies.'' Dai-Ichi Mutual Life is the world's third largest insurance company. It reported assets of $110 billion and revenue of $23 billion in its fiscal year ended March 31. Lincoln National reported assets of $25.1 billion and revenue exceeding $8.1 billion in the year ended Dec. 31. The companies will exchange trainees to improve understanding of their respective markets, Rolland said. ``We are hopeful this will give Lincoln National greater visibility in the international equity markets and provide better business opportunities, particularly in Japan,'' he said. The agreement, which must be approved by federal regulators, calls for Dai-Ichi to purchase a 5 percent share of Lincoln National through the first series of convertible preferred stock and a 4.6 percent share through a second series within a year. ``We think Lincoln National is a highly regarded and soundly managed company,'' said Takahide Sakurai, president of Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Co., in a statement from Tokyo. ``This transaction offers us a good investment opportunity.'' Lincoln National and Dai-Ichi entered into a reinsurance agreement in 1987. The two companies' relationship dates to visits by Dai-Ichi officials to Fort Wayne almost 30 years ago, Rolland said. ``This is an alliance for two companies who are familiar with each other's strengths and values,'' he said. ``We both believe that good customer service is vital. We both believe that sound investment practices are the key to our businesses. ``And we both believe that future growth and prosperity relies upon our finding new opportunities in our industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Trade Talks Expected To Continue Into Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese negotiators tackled Japanese pricing mechanisms and American shortfalls in savings and investment today as talks on structural trade problems moved into their second day. Although the talks originally were scheduled to end today, they were continuing into the night and appeared likely to extend through Wednesday. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said in a speech Monday to a Washington trade conference sponsored by the Institute for International Economics it may be necessary to hold another round of talks on broad reforms to reduce Japan's $49 billion surplus in trade with the United States. ``We will continue to talk until the job is done. If there needs to be another meeting, so be it,'' she said. Hills warned there could be a backlash against Japanese imports in the United States if the trade talks fail to expand foreign business opportunities in Japan. ``Japan isn't open and until we get that parity of opportunity we will have an enormous buildup of antagonism that creates a backdrop for very bad public policy,'' she said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said the talks were ``very intensive'' and he welcomed comments Monday by U.S. officials that the talks had been friendly and cooperative. ``This underlines that our response has been very positive,'' Watanabe said. Nonetheless, the two sides had failed to agree on the level to which Japan would increase spending on public works. Watanabe said Tuesday's session opened with a discussion of why Japan tends to have higher prices than the United States on similar products. In the afternoon, he said, the negotiators covered such problems on the U.S. side as the government budget deficit, low savings and investment rates, excessive consumption, low competitiveness of U.S. products and poor training of U.S. workers. ``Our position is that the U.S. side also has some tasks,'' he said. Such basic factors in the two countries' economic systems are among many topics in the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative talks, launched last September. Japanese and U.S. negotiators agreed on an interim report in April that both sides hailed as a strong step toward a final pact. But since then, Washington has said Tokyo was not following through fully on a pledge to increase public works spending. And on Tuesday, Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto reportedly said Washington apparently was ducking the problem of the huge U.S. government budget deficit. Kyodo News Service said Hashimoto told reporters after a Cabinet meeting that the United States had said in the interim report it would eliminate its budget deficit by 1993, but the pledge did not appear in Washington's draft of the final report. Later, senior U.S. officials said they had told the Japanese side Washington wants to look beyond eliminating the budget deficit by 1993, and to envision a budget surplus. Speaking on condition of anonymity, they said there had been a ``good exchange'' of views Tuesday, but did not indicate whether agreements had been reached on any of the areas under discussion. The U.S. budget deficit is regarded as a spur to U.S. consumption that increases demand for Japanese imports and thus contributes to the trade imbalance. At the same time, U.S. savings and investment levels are lower than Japan's. That means greater modernization for Japanese industry, increasing its advantage in efficiency. An increase in Japanese public spending is expected to boost imports and soak up some savings. The two countries disagreed over how high the increase should be, with the Americans asking for 500 trillion yen, or $3.22 trillion, over the next 10 years. Japanese officials indicated they favored spending between 400 trillion and 415 trillion yen, or $2.58 trillion to $2.68 trillion. Among other things, Japan has agreed to ease restrictions on opening large retail stores, revise land use policies to curb high land prices, speed up processing of patent applications, crack down on allegedly unfair business practices by corporate groups, and open complicated pricing mechanisms. All the measures are thought likely to increase foreign opportunities for trade and investment in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with close
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended mixed on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday, as an early rally faltered. Shares jumped in early trading on a surge in the stock-index futures market and bullish news in the brewery sector. But there was little siggnificant buying by institutions to support the rally, dealers said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 1.3 points, or 0.05 percent, at 2,399.8 at the close. Volume was 461.2 million shares, up from 379.1 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell Communication Posts Annual Profit of 101.1 Million Pounds
DOC.TEXT: Maxwell Communication Corp. PLC, the British publishing and communications concern, said Tuesday it had a profit of 101.1 million pounds, or about $175 million at current exchange rates, in its latest fiscal year. Robert Maxwell, chairman and chief executive, said the results were ``highly satisfactory'' for a year which saw the company complete its move out of printing and into international publishing. He said the company hopes to raise $950 million from further asset sales to reduce debt, but declined to identify what properties are for sale. In reporting its results for the year ended March 31, the company provided for comparison results from a 15-month period ended March 31, 1989 when it said it earned 190 million pounds. The company has changed to operating on a fiscal year rather than calendar year basis. The latest profit figure reflected an extraordinary loss of 25.7 million pounds, or $44 million, in the latest year resulting from the sale of the last of the company's printing businesses. The latest figures were converted to dollars at the current exchange rate of $1.73 to the pound. In the previous 15-month period, the company had an extraordinary gain of 42 million pounds. Sales were 1.24 billion pounds, or $2.1 billion, for the latest year, and 1.39 billion pounds for the previous 15 months. The company said its pre-tax profit was 172.3 million pounds, or $298 million, compared with a pre-tax profit of 192 million pounds in the previous 15-month period. It said its pre-tax profit rose 12 percent on an annualized basis. The company completed a series of U.S. acquisitions including the 1988 purchase of the publisher Macmillan Inc. in recent years. Maxwell said the company now derives about 80 percent of sales and operating profit from North America. Maxwell said that the company had borrowings of 2.1 billion pounds, or $3.6 billion, or March 31 compared with 2.7 billion pounds in September.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Plans To Sell Four Jets, End Service to Seven Cities
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc. plans to sell four jets by the end of the month, cut back its flight schedule and end service to seven cities by Oct. 1, a top official told the airline's pilots. In a letter to the members of the TWA branch of the Air Line Pilots Association, TWA Chief Operating Officer William Hoar said the company ``cannot and will not allow TWA to bleed to death.'' ``Left with no choice, we can no longer delay our decision to either grow or downsize,'' he said TWA owner Carl Icahn has said in recent months he would shrink or dismantle the airline unless the pilots agreed to pay cuts and other concessions. Icahn has said he would modernize and expand the airline if the pilots agreed. Icahn has said that 10 percent pay cuts and other concessions would save the airline $80 million a year. Hoar said the moves were being forced by pilots' resistance. He said union leaders Kent Scott and Bill Compton had made misleading statements about TWA's financial condition to create panic in the ranks and build support for an employee buyout. ``These ambitious pilots have decided that they want to control TWA and will go to almost any length to attain that goal,'' he wrote in the letter, dated Friday. Scott on Tuesday called Hoar's comments ``ridiculous. ... ``It's pure fantasy and an obvious divisive tactic.'' He said the pilots union had never been interested in buying the airline in its current financial situation. TWA, whose hub is in St. Louis, lost $298.5 million last year, largely because of burdensome interest payments on its $2.7 billion in debt. The airline lost $143 million in the first three months of 1990. Hoar's letter said TWA would end service to seven cities and reduce its flight schedule by 7 percent on Oct. 1. The seven cities have not yet been identified, but Scott said they probably would include Nassau and Freeport in the Bahamas, and Syracuse, N.Y. Hoar also said the airline would sell four jets _ two Boeing 747s, one Lockheed L-1011 and one Boeing 727 _ by the end of June. At least four more Boeing 727s will be sold in the next quarter, he said. TWA previously had announced it was eliminating the two 747s and the L-1011 from its fleet, but didn't say when. The 727s are among a group of 20 that the airline put on the market earlier this month. Hoar said TWA still was trying to find buyers for the other 15 727s. He also confirmed that the airline was negotiating to sell gates and operating slots at LaGuardia Airport in New York and National Airport in Washington D.C. TWA will not need all of its gates and slots at those airports after it cuts back its flight operation in October, he said. ``This is not the direction I want to see TWA going and more importantly, it is not what has to be,'' Hoar wrote. ``We can stabilize and grow this company together.'' Hoar said the company planned to obtain new jets to replace its old ones if the union would help reduce overhead and improve efficiency. TWA, which is based in Mount Kisco, N.Y., has been negotiating for several months to acquire 70 Airbus Industrie A-320s but will not complete the deal without concessions, Hoar said. TWA also has talked with McDonnell Douglas Corp. and several leasing companies about adding more MD-80s to its fleet and has determined that some jets will be available within a few months, he said. Hoar also said TWA was looking at other possibilities for strengthening its competitive position, including building or buying a hub in the eastern United States; merging with another airline or buying another airline; adding domestic and international flights from St. Louis; and expanding into the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and the Pacific.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Bars New Oil Leasing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after pvs 9th graf, Further, with Lujan comments; INSERTS one graf after pvs 18th graf, Although the, to include oil resources and reserve estimates from affected areas; Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today barred new oil leasing off much of California and Florida, the North Atlantic coast, Washington and Oregon until after the year 2000. ``Further steps to protect the environment are needed,'' he said. Bush also canceled planned government oil lease sales in an area stretching south from San Francisco to Monterey Bay and said he would permanently block any drilling in a 2,200-square-mile proposed marine sanctuary that lies within that region. However, Bush said tracts in the Santa Maria Basin and Santa Barbara Channel of Southern California would be available for leasing consideration at the beginning of 1996 if studies show the environment can be protected there. Southern California is the only area involved in Bush's decision today where oil drilling is now going on. ``The combined effect of these decisions is that the coast of southwest Florida and more than 99 percent of the California coast will be off limits to oil and gas leasing and development until after the year 2000,'' Bush said. Lisa Speer, senior staff scientist for the Natural Resources Defense Council, called Bush's decision ``a major step in the right direction.'' But she said ``it falls short in several crucial respects.'' Environmentalists want a permanent ban imposed on offshore drilling. Spear complained that Bush did not address some areas where lease sales are upcoming, including the Mid-Atlantic coast, North Carolina, New Jersey, Alaska's Bristol Bay, and northern Florida. In the case of Florida, where the government already has sold 73 leases to oil firms in an area off the Florida Keys, Bush said he is directing Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan to begin a process that ``may lead to the buyback and cancellation of existing leases.'' Further, he said, ``Any development after the year 2000 would be pursued only if it appears viable based on the guiding principles'' of environmental protection, energy needs and significant potential for oil production. ``We will work with the state of Florida to buy back existing leases in the Eastern Gulf of Mexico off the southern tip of Floria,'' said Lujan. Barry A. Williamson, director of the department's Minerals Management Service, estimated the lease buybacks would cost between $100 million and $200 million. Republican Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida previously has rejected any state responsibility to buy back leases sold by the federal government. Along the New England coast, Bush announced a delay that administration officials already had signaled. He said a sale of leases in the Georges Bank area east of Cape Cod, Mass., will be canceled until at least 2000. ``This will allow time for additional studies to determine the resource potential of the area and address the environmental and scientific concerns which have been raised,'' Bush said in his statement. Georges Bank, an underwater plateau that is about 175 miles long and lies 50 to 150 miles east of Cape Cod, is one of the world's richest fisheries. Congress has protected the region from oil drilling for the past several years by imposing moratoriums. Earlier this year, representatives of Washington and Oregon, federal agencies and Indian tribes negotiated an agreement that would cancel a Northwestern lease sale planned for 1992 and call for about seven years of environmental studies. They submitted the agreement to Lujan. The administration had not formally responded before today. In California, Bush's long-awaited decision calls for canceling all planned government sales in Northern California, and in Southern California south of the Santa Barbara Channel, so new oceanographic and scocioeconomic studies can be conducted. These areas could not be considered for new leases until after 2000. The decision closely follows the recommendation of a task force Bush appointed to study the oil exploration question last year. It recommended that more studies be conducted in California and Florida before new oil-producing activity be allowed. Bush said he had received the report of the interagency Outer Continental Shelf Task Force on Leasing and Development off the coasts of Florida and Califronia, and had ``accepted its recommendation that futher steps to protect the environment are needed.'' Although the task force was not charged with studying Oregon and Washington and the Georges Bank, the administration expanded the decision to include those regions. The Interior Department estimated the total potential oil resources for the areas affected by the decision at 8.2 million barrels, with proven reserves of 2.6 million barrels. Bush also announced he will revise the process by which the government conducts offshore leasing to: _ More carefully target ``areas with truly promising resource potential.'' _ Ensure environmental protection where oil drilling is allowed. _ Take into account the ``concerns and needs of local areas affected by offshore development.'' The administration will propose congressional legislation to give local communities more of a voice in the plans for oil development off their coasts and to provide them ``with a greater share of the financial benefits of new development.'' Bush postponed announcing a decision on oil-leasing in the wake of a recent massive tanker spill off Galveston, Texas. A Norwegian tanker was rocked by an explosion June 8, spilling 3.9 million gallons of oil. It created a 30-mile oil slick some 18 miles offshore. Most of it was skimmed off, burned, or evapaorated. The entire Florida congressional delegation and most of the California delegation have urged delays in new leasing. Republicans were especially sensitive to political fallout likely from any decision to open new oil-drilling regions in an election year.

DOC.HEAD: Boone Co. Set for Showdown With Japanese Business Culture
DOC.TEXT: Some 50 shareholders in T. Boone Pickens' private investment firm arrived Tuesday to join the Texas oilman and takeover strategist in his battle with the Japanese business establishment. Officially, the fight is for managerial control of Koito Manufacturing Co., an auto parts company affiliated with Japan's largest automaker, Toyota Motor Corp. Pickens' firm, Boone Co., owns the largest share in Koito and Pickens has been demanding, among other things, a corresponding share of seats on its board of directors. Pickens and 52 other Americans own 26 percent of Koito's 160.36 million outstanding shares. They will face their Japanese counterparts Thursday in an annual shareholders meeting at Koito's headquarters in central Tokyo. The fight has come to symbolize to some Americans the trials faced by investors in Japan at a time when many Japanese companies are buying U.S. businesses and property. The clash also reflects fundamental differences in how Americans and Japanese conduct business and accumulate wealth. It is one of the cases raised by some U.S. officials in urging Japan to reform its economic policies to encourage more foreign trade and investment. In current talks on reforms in both economies, Japan has promised to crack down on collusive business practices conducted by ``keiretsu.'' Keiretsu are corporate families bound by mutual shareholdings and other financial ties, and by cooperative business strategies. Many Japanese believe that keiretsu are crucial to Japan's entire just-in-time system of production and supply, in which parts are delivered as needed, not stockpiled into costly inventories. Koito belongs to the keiretsu surrounding Toyota. The auto company is its second largest shareholder, after Boone Co., with about 20 percent of Koito's shares. It also buys about half the auto lighting equipment Koito sells. Critics such as Pickens say the keiretsu tend to exclude outsiders, especially foreigners. They also say the big-name companies at the top of the manufacturing pyramid squeeze their smaller subcontractors mercilessly and deprive shareholders of their fair share of profits. ``While Americans have acquired a taste for many Japanese products, keiretsu is one thing we will never accept,'' Pickens told reporters Tuesday. ``Of course, there are people who claim that keiretsu are a major part of Japanese culture and that the rest of the world should just accept it,'' he said. ``I disagree. A keiretsu is a cartel is a cartel is a cartel. Whatever you call it, it's wrong.'' Pickens says he resorted to a public campaign against Koito's management after top executives of Koito, Toyota and other major Japanese firms refused to meet with him or accept his proposals. ``Give me a chance. Is that an unusual request?'' he said. ``Take me to the backroom. I can't get into the backroom,'' he added, responding to suggestions that he take a less confrontational approach in dealing with Japanese business. Koito officials accuse Pickens of acting as a front for Japanese investor Kitaro Watanabe, who they say has twice tried to greenmail them. Greenmailers buy large amounts of a company's stock in an effort to force the company to buy the shares back at a premium to maintain control. Pickens does not deny he may have a relationship with Watanabe. But he refuses to disclose any details of the financing involved in his purchase of the Koito shares from Watanabe. Shareholders on Thursday will vote on Picken's request for four seats on Koito's 20-member board and his proposals for an anti-greenmail resolution; an annual statement on whether Koito has engaged in anti-competitive activities; an annual shareholder vote on salary and retirement benefits of board members; an annual report on pricing policies; a further increase in the dividend, and an accounting of what Pickens suggests amounts to an illegal slush fund. Pickens said he had received proxies from more than half of individual Koito shareholders, who hold a total of about 4 million shares in the company, indicating support for his proposals. Koito's board has rejected all Pickens' proposals as unnecessary.

The stock market headed higher today, strengthening on President Bush's remark that tax increases will be needed to reduce the deficit. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 12.13 points on Monday, was up 6.68 points to 2,851.73 at 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 6 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 750 up, 666 down and 519 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 117.45 million shares with an hour of trading left. Bush said this morning that higher tax revenues were necessary to assure the deficit ``is brought under responsible control.'' His statement was issued as he met with congressional leaders at the White House. DOC.HEAD: Japanese Investors No Panacea For Trump's Troubles
DOC.TEXT: As the clock winds down on Donald Trump's immediate financial problems, the flamboyant landlord and developer faces a possibly much more lasting problem: How to win back Japanese investors. Japanese doctors, businessmen, even well-paid stewardesses flush with savings and land riches from sky-high Japanese real estate prices, led a wave of investment in condominiums and other small properties in the United States during recent years. Trump was one of many who exploited the trend, attracting Japanese funds to help finance his purchases of apartment buildings, hotels and casinos. He also has cashed in on the notorious Japanese preference for brand-name goods. But Tokyo real estate agents say an increasing number of investors are repelled by Trump's highly publicized financial and marital troubles, his disparaging comments about Japan, and _ most of all _ high prices for Trump condomiums in the depressed New York market. ``The value of Trump is going down,'' said Wataru Iwamura, a sales representative for overseas projects at Haseko Corp. The firm is a Japanese developer and seller of condominiums and a sales agent for Trump properties. ``I think it started from the divorce thing. Now they are talking about bankruptcy,'' he said. Besides, ``Trump is not saying good things about Japan. That does not help at all.'' Not all agents agree. Some say Japanese will continue to buy his properties for their prime locations, regardless of what happens to his family life and personal fortune. Trump has touted his properties in Japan in person, in print and on the water. In addition to taking out Japanese-language print advertising, he appeared in person at a Tokyo hotel to promote his properties and sent his plush yacht, the Trump Princess, cruising for a buyer through Japanese waters. The yacht left without taking down its for-sale sign. Trump also has tapped Japanese banks for financing. A report in the Nippon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's premier financial newspaper, claimed Trump owed a third of his debts to Japanese banks. It was not only relentless self-promotion that drew Japanese investors to Trump's properties, some agents say. ``When he built Trump Tower, at the same time, Japanese were putting their money into condominiums and Trump had good condominiums,'' said Seishi Matsuo, general manager of the international marketing department of Kyodo Advertising Co. The company is publisher of a magazine for investors in overseas property. ``Japanese are looking for location. At the Trump Tower, the Trump Parc, the location is very good,'' said Hisao Yamamoto, vice president of House Port Seiyo, a brokerage that handles Trump properties. Brokers said the slump in the New York real estate market, rather than Trump's problems, has sent would-be Japanese buyers looking for more promising buys in other parts of the United States, such as Seattle and California. Interest in Europe also is growing, with the approach of German unification, the 1992 Common Market consolidation, and the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain. But even if the New York real estate market recovers, some Japanese buyers will not be interested in the Trump brand name at current prices. Trump Palace condominums start at $350,000 for a studio, or about the same price as a one- or two-bedroom apartment in some other Manhattan buildings. ``The Japanese are studying the U.S. real estate. They learned that Trump property is quite expensive compared to other (property),'' said Masayuki Kusunoki, of Nomura Real Estate Development Co. But there is a bright side for would-be investors. ``He's in a bad position now, so maybe investors could take advantage of it,'' Iwamura said.
