DOC.HEAD: Structural Trade Talks Extended
DOC.TEXT: Japanese and U.S. officials agreed to extend trade talks after failing Tuesday to reach final agreement on substantial economic changes aimed at narrowing the trade imbalance between the countries. The meetings, originally were scheduled to end Tuesday, were extended as negotiators struggled to resolve differences over specific strategies to dismantle structural trade barriers. ``We would have to be extremely efficient to finish the talks Wednesday,'' a senior Japanese official said, speaking anonymously. ``We have received many comments from the U.S. side on the contents of our report, and will have to work on it.'' On Tuesday, second day of the talks, U.S. and Japanese negotiators discussed Japanese pricing mechanisms and American shortfalls in savings and investment that hurt the competitiveness of U.S. industries. U.S. officials at the talks said they explained efforts to tackle the U.S. federal budget deficit, which is seen as one reason for a shortfall in investment in U.S. industry. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they told the Japanese that Washington wants to look beyond eliminating the budget deficit by 1993, and to envision a budget surplus. Officials on both sides described the discussions as cooperative. Nonetheless, at the end of two days of intensive talks, the two sides failed to reach agreement on any of the areas under discussion, including the level of Japan's spending on public works, officials said. Public spending and other basic economic policies are among many topics in the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative talks, launched last year. Japanese and U.S. negotiators agreed on an interim report in April that both sides said represented major progress. They have since been fine-tuning a final report on the talks. On Tuesday, officials first discussed reasons why Japan tends to have higher prices than the United States on similar products. They later dealt with problems on the U.S. side, including the budget deficit, low savings and investment rates, excessive consumption, low competitiveness of U.S. products and poor training of U.S. workers. ``Our position is that the U.S. side also has some tasks,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said. Officials said they were still debating Japan's proposals on easing restrictions on opening large retail stores, revising land use policies to curb high real estate prices, speeding up processing of patent applications, cracking down on allegedly unfair business practices by corporate groups, and simplifying complicated pricing mechanisms. All the measures are thought likely to increase foreign opportunities for trade and investment in Japan. The most difficult issue, however, was expected to be Tokyo's plan to boost spending on public infrastructure such as roads, parks and sewers. An increase in such spending is expected to boost imports of construction products and counter Japan's high savings rate. The two countries disagreed over how high the increase should be, with the Americans asking for 500 trillion yen, or $3.22 trillion, over the next 10 years. Japanese officials indicated they favored spending between 400 trillion and 415 trillion yen, or $2.58 trillion to $2.68 trillion. Last year, Japanese sales in the United States exceeded U.S. sales in Japan by $49 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Bank Eliminating 900 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: The Continental Bank Corp. said Tuesday it is eliminating about 900 jobs and some trading operations in cost-cutting measures expected to save $75 million annually. The company also said it would establish a special $50 million reserve to cover the cost of eliminating the product lines, resulting in a second-quarter loss. As part of its belt-tightening, the company said it no longer intends to engage in futures and options execution and clearing, a business Continental began to exit with the sale of the Securities Settlement Corp. last year. Continental also plans to sell First Options of Chicago Inc. The company already has announced in Tokyo that it will discontinue trading U.S. Treasury securities and foreign exchange trading for its own account there. Jobs being eliminated include positions in trading, marketing and support staff, Continental spokesman Ted McDougal said. About one-third of the staff reductions will take place outside of Chicago, most of them overseas, he said. Reductions began in the second quarter and should almost be completed by the end of the year, McDougal said. Before the reductions began, the company had 6,720 employees, not including First Options' 700 workers. Most of the special reserve will cover the costs of providing assistance to displaced employees, including job search and severance packages. A smaller percentage will be used to pay for equipment and facilities no longer needed and any loss on the sale of certain assets. The cuts are expected to result in a $25 million savings in the second half of 1990 and $75 million a year beginning in 1991, Continental said. Continental Bank Corp. is a Chicago-based bank holding company which, through its subsidiaries, arranges financing and processes cash and securities for customers worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Dip in Sluggish Trading
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures sagged Tuesday in slow trading as conflicting signals left brokers with little incentive to buy or sell heavily. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, dropped 24 cents to $17.14 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It had lost 8 cents on Monday. Other crude contract months also declined. Among refined products traded on the exchange, the July contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline fell 0.95 cent to 61.32 cents a gallon, wiping out Monday's gain of 0.90 cent. Contracts for later delivery also settled lower. Wholesale home heating oil for July delivery fell 0.43 cent to 48.49 cents a gallon after gaining 0.26 cent Monday. Contracts for delivery during August through October also fell. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.507 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.516 Monday. Brian Tagler, an energy options specialist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the oil market seems to be stuck in a holding pattern, with activity winding down before the Fourth of July holiday. ``It sort of drifted lower out of neglect,'' Tagler said. ``We've got all the ingredients for a dead market.'' Among ingredients that curbed trading interest were weekly supply and demand statistics, which were due after the market closed Tuesday. The report was expected to show a bearish buildup in stocks combined with a modest drawdown. Speculation about what might occur at a possible emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on July 5 made traders reluctant to sell heavily. The possibility that the cartel might undertake measures to lift the slumping oil market has put a floor under the market.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Announces Plans for Worldwide Cellular Phone System
LaserPhoto NY16, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. said Tuesday it plans to build a satellite-based cellular phone system that will connect users with telephones anywhere in the world. The system could supplement conventional phone service in nations where it is poor, such as in Eastern Europe, and provide mobile phone service in rural areas where it is not offered, Motorola officials said. Target users include traveling business people, passengers of ships and aircraft, disaster-relief workers and residents of underdeveloped nations. The system, called Iridium, would use a network of 77 satellites that would receive calls from hand-held telephones resembling today's cellular phones. The phones would cost as low as $3,000 _ compared with about $400 for today's cheapest cellular phones, Motorola said. The electronics company said it would launch test satellites in 1992, and expected full service to be available as soon as 1996. ``We see the potential of Iridium as nothing short of revolutionary,'' John F. Mitchell, a Motorola vice chairman, told reporters at a news conference. But the system faces several obstacles. Motorola needs regulatory approval to operate the satellites from various government groups worldwide. It also must come up with the $2.3 billion it says it will cost to build the system. Motorola says it wants to take on four or five partners that each would provide funding in exchange for a stake in the venture. In addition, it is envisioned that several of these partners would be satellite operators that already have the necessary government operating authority. The partners have not been selected, but Motorola said it has signed agreements with three satellite operators to explore constructing the system: American Mobile Satellite Corp. of Washington, D.C., International Maritime Satellite Organization of London, and Telesat Mobile Inc. of Canada. These three satellite groups may become partners in Iridium, said Durrell W. Hillis, a Motorola vice president who heads the satellite effort. Motorola also said it is negotiating with other potential partners, including Great Britain's principal phone company, British Telecommunications PLC, and organizations in Australia, Hong Kong and Japan. Iridium would be connected to existing phone networks. However, customers probably would not want to use Iridium phones to make local cellular calls in areas served by existing ground-based systems because the cost per Iridium call would be much greater, Hillis said. In addition, Iridium phones would not be compatible with existing or planned ground-based cellular phone networks, so users could not tap into these networks directly by bypassing the expensive satellite system. As a result, Iridium customers probably would need to carry two cellular phones while traveling. That could provide a huge potential new market for Motorola, which already is the world's largest maker of cellular phones. The Schaumburg, Ill.-based company also would make the communications gear for the satellites and the computerized control sytstems that would operate them. Hillis said Motorola knows of no other similar system in the works. John Pemberton, an analyst with the research firm Gartner Group of Stamford, Conn., said American Telephone & Telegraph Co. is believed to be working on plans for a satellite-based cellular phone system that would use two giant satellites fixed in position over the Earth. The Iridium satellites would orbit the planet. Pemberton said he was impressed with Motorola's plans and called them achievable. However, he said he believed the system would need more than 77 satellites to provide sufficient capacity. The Iridium system, under development since late 1987, would operate like a cellular phone network in the sky, passing calls from one to the other as do the transmission towers located in each ``cell'' of a ground-based cellular phone network. The satellites would be located 413 nautical miles above the Earth, considered a low orbit for satellites. The low orbit would allow the use of small hand-held phones with tiny antennas rather than the satellite dishes required to beam signals to existing satellites. The satellites would pass a call around the globe to the intended recipient. If the recipient has an Iridium phone, he would receive the call directly; otherwise, the call would connect with a conventional, land-based phone system to be completed. Each Iridium user would be given a personal telephone number. For someone to reach a user, they would simply dial the number and would not have to know the user's location, Motorola said. Iridium _ named after the 77th element on the periodic table _ would not have the capacity to replace conventional cellular phone systems in urban areas, Hillis said. Motorola has extensive experience in satellite and outer-space communications. It made the communications equipment for every U.S. space mission, Hillis said.

DOC.HEAD: Cable Company Asks CBS For Affiliate Status
DOC.TEXT: In the second such request to a network this month, Continental Cablevision Inc., asked CBS on Tuesday if it could become the first cable affiliate in CBS' history and serve Concord, N.H. CBS has ``no comment'' on the request, said CBS spokeswoman Susan Tick in Los Angeles, where the network's top executives are attending the annual CBS affiliates convention this week. Last week, Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable system operator, asked NBC to let its systems become NBC affiliates in some cities that have no NBC-affiliated broadcast station. However, that cable company didn't specify which cities it had in mind. NBC Cable and Business Development president Thomas S. Rogers said NBC didn't think TCI's request was serious. A TCI official said it was. Frank Anthony, senior vice-president for Continental, the nation's fourth-largest cable operation, said his company's CBS proposal wasn't prompted by TCI's earlier action, but ``it helped us crystallize our thinking.'' ``Our proposal is much more specific,'' he added. ``We're talking about a distinct market which does not have a CBS affiliate in it.'' New Hampshire is among states with a higher-than-average number of cable households. According to A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates, 62 percent of its 410,000 television households have cable. CBS broadcasts received in Concord now come from CBS affiliates WHDH-TV in Boston and WGME-TV in Portland, Me., Anthony said. Concord briefly had a CBS-affiliated UHF station in 1988, but that outlet went out of business, he said. He said his Boston-based company asked to become CBS' affiliate in Concord because of the network's strength, ``its solid news operation'' and because CBS ``had already recognized the (Concord) market as being somewhat underserved.'' If its request were granted, Continental wouldn't drop the Boston and Portland affiliate signals from its Concord cable operation, he said. But as a local CBS affiliate, that operation, deriving its income from local advertising and cable subscriptions, would function as does as an over-the-air CBS affiliate. That includes payments from CBS for carrying the network's shows, Anthony said. Although CBS officials declined comment on Continental's request, it is doubtful they would grant it. Among other things, they have repeatedly said their company has no interest in cable and that CBS' core business is broadcasting. Anthony, who said Continental has yet to receive a reply from CBS, said network affiliation requests from cable companies could become commonplace. ``I think they could,'' he said. ``But I think for CBS or anybody else to consider them, they need to be serious proposals'' to serve markets that don't now have network-affiliated stations of their own.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against all major currencies Tuesday after the markets became pessimistic about Congress reaching a budget accord, traders said. Gold bullion prices fell domestically and overseas on reports of selling in the Middle East. The reports could not be confirmed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for June delivery closed at $350.40 a troy ounce, off $3.40. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted a troy ounce of gold at $350.10, off $2.70, as of 4 p.m. EDT. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar rose earlier in the day on reports that President Bush might be ready to ease his opposition to raising taxes in order to gain a compromise on reducing the federal budget deficit. But the market learned later that Bush's comments were vague, sending the dollar down, said Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Co. in New York. ``What appeared to first be positive turned out negative,'' he said. Simon said the major movement in the currency markets Tuesday was toward the West German mark, which gained on a statement by the West German central bank that it would accept higher domestic interest rates. Higher rates tend to make a currency more valuable relative to other currencies. The mark also has been supported by optimism about the outcome of the plan to unify the currencies of the two Germanies next month, traders said. In Tokyo, the dollar eased to 155.40 Japanese yen from late Monday's 155.62. In London, the dollar was lower at 155.20 yen. Later, in New York, the dollar closed at 154.55 yen, down from 155.40 yen late Monday. In London, one British pound cost $1.7360 late Tuesday, more expensive for buyers than Monday's late rate of $1.7300. In New York, a pound cost $1.7430, more than the $1.7305 late Monday. Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.6618 West German marks, down from 1.6775; 1.3975 Swiss francs, down from 1.4100; 5.5770 French francs, down from 5.6315; 1,217.50 Italian lire, down from 1,228.25; and 1.1719 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17705. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.6690 West German marks, down from 1.6775; 1.4025 Swiss francs, down from 1.4110; 5.6035 French francs, down from 5.6335; 1.8790 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8830; 1,222.25 Italian lire, down from from 1,228.50; and 1.1730 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1792. In gold trading, dealers in Zurich said the metal appeared to have fallen into a lower trading range of between $348 and $353. The late bid price for gold in London was $349.50 a troy ounce, down from $353.50 late Monday. The late bid price in Zurich was $350.00, down from $353.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, before the Middle East selling reports emerged, gold closed higher at $353.25 bid, up from $351.05. DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Futures Slip as Heat Prospects Fade
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices fell modestly Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, giving up some of the previous session's sharp gains as fears of an extended Midwestern heat wave faded. Wheat futures advanced slightly. On other commodity markets, cocoa futures surged; energy futures retreated; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed. Soybean futures settled 4\ cents to 6{ cents lower in Chicago with July at $6.08 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1\ cents lower with July at $2.85} a bushel; wheat futures were { cent to 3{ cents higher with July at $3.34 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents lower to { cent higher with July at $1.37 a bushel. Traders took their cues largely from the National Weather Service's latest six-to-10-day outlook, which predicts normal temperatures and above-average rain in Midwestern growing regions during the first half of next week. Those conditions would be ideal for crop development after farmers complete their soybean planting in the hot, dry weather forecast for the rest of this week, analysts said. Corn and soybean futures soared Monday amid fears that the mostly dry, 90-plus-degree weather headed for the Midwest this week could remain in the region for a week or more, stressing young crops. But after traders saw the weather service forecast, ``the excitement is out of here,'' said John Frazier, director of the agricultural trading division of Gerald Inc. in Chicago. Selling in the corn and soybean markets also reflected profit-taking after Monday's steep gains, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Cocoa futures rallied strongly on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, rebounding from sharp losses posted late last week. Sandra Kaul, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the surge mainly reflected a lack of significant selling interest. She said the market fell last week to levels at which cocoa dealers had established delivery positions to lock in prices on their 1990-91 sales commitments, effectively creating a floor of trade buying interest. Cocoa futures settled $44 to $48 higher with July at $1,226 per ton. Energy futures sagged in slow trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange as conflicting signals left brokers with little incentive to buy or sell heavily. Among ingredients that curbed trading interest were weekly supply and demand statistics released after the market closed. As expected, the American Petroleum Institute report showed a modest 531,000-barrel decline in U.S. stocks of crude oil, an even smaller decline in gasoline stocks and a 2.4-million-barrel increase in supplies of petroleum distillates. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 3 cents to 24 cents lower with August at $17.14 a barrel; home heating oil was .34 cent to .53 cent lower with July at 48.49 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .50 cent to .70 cent lower with July at 61.32 cents a gallon. Pork-belly futures steadied on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after limit losses of 2 cents a pound in each of the three previous sessions. Traders said they expected the belly market to gain some ground Wednesday after a weekly Merc report showed a larger-than-expected decline in supplies of bellies in commercial freezers outside of Chicago. Hog futures advanced while cattle futures were narrowly mixed. Live cattle settled .20 cent lower to .18 cent higher with August at 73 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 84.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent to .43 cent higher with August at 58.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .65 cent lower to .68 cent higher with July at 57.15 cents a pound. Gold futures gave up most of Monday's strong gains on New York's Commodity Exchange amid slack investor buying interest; silver was barely changed. Gold settled $3.30 to $3.40 lower with June at $350.40 a troy ounce; silver futures ended 0.1 cent lower to 0.4 cent higher with July at $4.825 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Sonat Agrees to $300.5 Million Settlement for Offshore Fire
DOC.TEXT: Sonat Inc. has agreed to pay $300.5 million to settle claims stemming from a 1989 fire that killed seven people and destroyed a production platform operated by Arco Oil and Gas Co. off the Louisiana coast, officials said. Arco announced the settlement Monday. A Sonat spokesman confirmed that the Birmingham-based company had reached an agreement in principal to settle all claims against Sonat and litigation involving the fire on March 19, 1989. An April report released by the Minerals Management Service, U.S. Coast Guard and Office of Pipeline Safety said a number of factors led to the accident, according to the Oil & Gas Journal. Problems began in February 1989 when an anchor ruptured a Sonat pipeline. In repairing the damage and clearing the pipeline, the report said, the pipeline released a mix of gas, liquid hydrocarbons and water. In March, the mixture ignited and spread to an Arco facility, Platform Baker, located 20 miles southeast of Venice, La. The flames caused an explosion that reached an adjacent platform connected by a 50-foot causeway. Of the 42 people on the rig, five Arco workers and two contract employees died; another 10 workers were injured. Platform Baker suffered extensive damage, while the second platform was slightly damaged. Arco, which also was forced to halt production of 18,000 barrels of oil a day, sued Sonat, two subsidiaries and a contractor in April 1989. Under the terms of the settlement, Sonat will be assigned Arco's claims against other parties involved in the accident who are not involved in the settlement, the Sonat spokesman said. Sonat said no adverse effects are expected on earnings or the company's financial condition because insurance would cover the settlement.

DOC.HEAD: NYSE Accepts Soviet Invitation for Securities Seminar
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange said Tuesday it has accepted an invitation from the Soviet government to organize a seminar in Moscow on developing securities exchanges and capital markets. Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin, who is chairman of the State Economic Reform Commission, invited NYSE Chairman and Chief Executive Officer John J. Phelan Jr. to lead a delegation in October, the exchange said. ``The development of a new economic structure at home, and the Soviet Union's expansion into world financial markets, will provide increasing opportunities for cooperation between our two nations,'' Phelan said in a statement. The seminar is to be sponsored by the exchange, the Soviet Ministry of Finance and the Soviet state bank Gosbank. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said earlier this month that the Soviets plan commercial and securities laws that will create a ``normal commercial economic environment'' for Western business by the end of the year. Phelan, who is vice president of the Association of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges, has visit exchanges throughout the world, including Japan, Singapore, Spain and West Germany, and plans to visit Eastern Europe this summer, an exchange spokesman said. Phelan's last visit to a non-capitalist country was to China in 1986. The spokesman said ``high-level delegations'' from the Soviet Union have visited the NYSE in the last two years.

DOC.HEAD: S&P Downgrades Chase Manhattan Debt Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. on Tuesday downgraded its ratings of several types of debt of Chase Manhattan Corp., the nation's second-largest banking company. Two weeks ago, Moody's Investors Service Inc., the other major credit-rating agency, downgraded Chase's debt ratings. Other major banks, including Citicorp, the nation's largest, also have seen their credit ratings downgraded in recent weeks due to concern over the softening economy. In the latest action, S&P said it downgraded about $7.5 billion worth of Chase debt securities and preferred stock, including senior debt, subordinated debt and commercial paper. The action involves securities issued by Chase itself and several subsidiaries. A lower credit rating can force a bank to pay more interest on its securities, increasing its cost of borrowing. ``The downgrades reflect S&P's expectation that loan quality, particularly in the real estate areas, will deteriorate significantly,'' S&P said in a statement. Moody's also cited concern over real estate debt for its downgradings. S&P said Chase's profitability has been weak due to low business volume in wholesale banking, ``although the recently announced plan to cut $300 million of expenses should go a long way toward remedying the problem.'' It also said Chase's reserves for domestic loans are thin. ``Thus, while the company has successfully navigated through LDC-related difficulties, it is not as well prepared to deal with a new wave of problems domestically,'' it said, referring to Third World debt. It said the concerns are partially offset by Chase's addition of $1 billion in capital since September through an equity issue and dividend reinvestment plan. The bank's highly profitable consumer banking operations also provide some stability, it said. Chase spokesman Steve Rautenberg said, ``We're disappointed, particularly in light of our capital-building activities over the past two quarters.''

DOC.HEAD: President Bans Much Drilling Until 2000
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS grammar in 9th graf, which is 2nd bullet graf: ``_Southern California,'' ``are'' sted ``is;'' SUBS lede to make it ``at least the year 2000'' sted flatly 2000; INSERTS grafs 20-21: ``In a,'' with Chevron statement. Also on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday blocked new oil drilling off the coasts of much of California, Florida, Washington, Oregon and New England until at least the year 2000. In addition, he permanently blocked any drilling in a proposed marine sanctuary in California's Monterey Bay, and ordered a moratorium on new leases until 1996 for one section off southern California where drilling already is under way. ``My desire is to achieve a balance between the need to provide energy for the American people and the need to protect unique and sensitive coastal and marine environments,'' Bush said in a written statement announcing his long-pending decision. The president called for more environmental studies to settle the question of whether leases might be offered after 2000. The election-year ban was likely to come as a relief to Republican candidates in both California and Florida, who were concerned about possible negative voter reaction to new drilling in a year that has seen a steady parade of oil spill news stories. But the announcement fell somewhat short of what environmentalists were hoping for, a permanent ban on offshore drilling they contend is the only way to protect sensitive environmental regions and beaches. Based in large part on the recommendations of an inter-agency task force he appointed to study the California and Florida coastal drilling prospects, Bush announced he is suspending until at least 2000 any new leases to oil companies in federal waters off: _Northern California, 1.1 million acres off Mendocino and Humboldt counties. _Southern California, 6.7 million acres south of the Santa Barbara Channel to the Mexican border. Not included are the Santa Barbara Channel and the Santa Maria basin, where drilling is under way. Bush said he would delay new leases until at least 1996, pending further study, in those areas. _Central California, from San Francisco south to Monterey Bay, originally scheduled for a lease auction next March. Bush further permanently barred oil exploration in the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary. _Southern Florida, 14 million acres off Collier, Monroe and Dade counties in the Gulf of Mexico. _New England, 12.8 million acres of Georges Bank off Cape Cod, an important fishing ground vigorously defended by Massachusetts officials and believed to far more likely to contain natural gas than oil. _Washington and Oregon, where state and federal agencies recently agreed that further environmental studies are needed. The White House said that the moratorium could be suspended in the event of ``external events, such as supply disruptions,'' prompting environmental groups to complain that a loophole had been built in. But White House spokesman Steve Hart said that the intention was only to protect against a dramatic interruption in the nation's oil supply like the 1973 embargo by Arab producers. ``We don't anticipate there's going to be any gas lines and we don't anticipate just scrapping the whole thing. I believe that we can handle it,'' Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan told reporters. The California and Florida areas probably contain 1.3 billion barrels to 2.8 billion barrels of oil, equivalent to 75 to 160 days of consumption, and 2.2 trillion cubic feet of gas, about a 42-day supply, according to a White House fact sheet. Figures were not given for the other areas. In the Florida area, oil companies already have purchased 73 leases that could not be worked while Bush was studying the issue. It may cost $200 million to buy them back, officials have said. The president announced that he is directing Lujan to begin discussions with the state for a joint federal-state repurchase effort. In a statement in San Francisco, Chevron Oil Co. said initial reports of Bush's decision indicated ``the president's actions seem to go too far.'' ``But we certainly realize there is great concern by the American public over this issue, and we're anxious to see the various parties to the offshore development controversy work together to find long-term solutions that will need for a sound U.S. energy policy and for protection of the environment,'' the company said. Bush said he believes ``there are significant offshore areas where we casatisfy both then and must go forward with resource development.'' He did not say what areas he was referring to, but his administration has indicated it will go forward in Alaska and the long-productive Gulf of Mexico, where Bush himself pioneered offshore drilling many years ago. Bush also said he is implementing an overhaul of the leasing system, to include ``rigorous scrutiny'' of potential oil yields before any leasing occurs, assurance that drilling and exploration practices will not pose a risk to ``unique natural resources,'' priority for development in the regions with the highest potential yield and a study of national security needs. Members of Congress from New York and New Jersey complained that the Atlantitruth) and we're all now going to have to pay the price for that,'' Dukakis said in Boston. Democratic Party Chairman Ron Brown said Bush's statement was candid and sober and ``gives no one comfort. It's no time for partisan gloating.'' Budget talks are scheduled to resume Wednesday, and the White House expressed hope for a final agreement by the August congressional recess. Bush issued his statement after a breakfast session with top congressional leaders and following a weekend of meetings between Democrats and White House budget negotiators. ``It is clear to me,'' Bush said, ``that both the size of the deficit problem and the need for a package that can be enacted require all of the following.'' He listed ``tax revenue increases,'' cuts in spending for federal benefits as well as reductions in other domestic and defense programs, reform of the budget process and ``growth incentives,'' a term often used to describe a cut in the capital gains tax rate. Bush, asked about his statement as he left a photo session, said the written statement ``speaks for itself'' and declined to specifically address reporters' questions about his position. ``I want to see this economy grow,'' he said. ``I want jobs. I want to see the deficit down. And this bipartisan statement speaks for itself. Now we're going on to some serious negotiation.'' He hailed congressional Democrats for the ``good faith'' spirit of the budget talks and said it was ``essential that these talks get moving.'' From the outset of the budget talks, Bush had said that everything was on the table for negotiation. Until now, however, he had refused to say explicitly that tax increases must be included in the deficit-reduction formula. The White House refused to acknowledge that Bush had scrapped his no-new-taxes pledge. ``Are you crazy?'' Fitzwater good-naturedly asked reporters. However, Fitzwater said Bush's statement amounted to ``a refinement'' of his earlier remarks. ``We've got to deal realistically with this problem,'' he said. On the other hand, Fitzwater said, ``I don't think that it (Bush's statement) is that big a change. We're still a long way from the final details of a settlement.'' There is a general consensus among budget negotiators that they need to reduce the deficit by $45 billion to $60 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and about $400 billion to $600 billion over the next five years. Technically, the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law would require far deeper cuts, based on current revenue and spending projections. By law, the government will be forced to absorb deep, across-the-board spending cuts unless the deficit is kept to $74 billion in fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.1 million tons during the week ending June 16, down 2 percent from the 20.5 million tons produced in the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported. The industry produced 18.2 million tons in the same week last year, the department's Energy Information Administration said Monday. Kentucky ranked first among the 26 coal-producing states with 3.4 million tons produced. West Virginia was second at 3.3 million tons and Wyoming was third at 3.2 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 462.5 million tons, 5 percent ahead of last year's pace.

DOC.HEAD: Judges Would Get Discretion to Dismiss Civil RICO Suits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also ran on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee voted Tuesday to give federal judges more discretion to dismiss as frivolous some civil suits under the nation's anti-racketeering laws. On a unanimous vote, the Judiciary Committee's 10-member subcommittee on crime approved legislation that would narrow the definition of racketeering in civil suits to exclude ordinary commercial disputes and contract cases. ``Ordinary businessmen are being branded as racketeers simply because they have become embroiled in a commercial dispute,'' said Rep. Frederick Boucher, D-Va., the bill's chief sponsor. The bill would revise the 1970 Racketeer Influence and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) to effectively deny plaintiffs in many civil suits the ability to recover triple they amount of damages they incurred. Under the legislation, a judge would be required to dismiss a civil RICO suit if a defendant had not been convicted of criminal racketeering or if the judge could not find that triple damages were warranted because of the magnitude of the injuries. Boucher called the current statute one of the most abused provisions of federal law, having ``made its way into domestic disputes between spouses, inheritance disputs among family members, disagreements among church members and litigation involving landlords and tenants.'' The bill would apply the new proposed ``gatekeeper'' provisions retroactively to some 1,500 currently pending civil suits. On a 6-4 vote, the committee defeated an amendment by Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., to deny retroactivity. Supporters of the failed amendment said it was needed to preserve the RICO suit of some 23,000 bondholders who lost $200 million in the parent company of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association against the thrift's owner, Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr., and his associates. ``Given the inherent ambiguities in the `gatekeeper' provision, there is no assurance that a judge will not later on deprive my clients of a meritorious verdict,'' the bondholders' attorney, William Lerach, said in a letter to the subcommittee. ``To give Charles Keating and Ferdinand Marcos another bite of the apple is ridiculous,'' said subcommittee member Chuck Douglas, R-N.H., referring to another suit now pending against the estate of the deceased former dictator of the Philippines. Making the changes retroactive also was opposed by the state attorneys general and state insurance commissioners. The Senate Judiciary Committee last January removed a retroactivity provision from a similar bill written by Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., one of five senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committees over their involvement with Keating. Rather than give judges more discretion to dismiss civil RICO suits, the Senate bill would simply eliminate triple damages except in cases brought by the government.

DOC.HEAD: Midwest Federal Officials Indicted on Fraud, Conspiracy Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throuhout with quotes from Thornburgh and defense attorney, details of charges.
DOC.TEXT: The former chairman and three top executives of Midwest Federal Savings and Loan were indicted Tuesday on federal fraud and conspiracy charges involving financial losses sustained by the failed thrift. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced the 40-count indictment returned by a federal grand jury. ``This indictment is a further demonstration of our determination to pursue serious allegations against savings and loan ripoff artists across the United States,'' Thornburgh said. Midwest Federal, which had assets of $3.5 billion, is being liquidated by the government at an expected cost of $1 billion. The thrift was about $1 billion in debt when it was seized by regulators in February 1989. Indicted were chairman Harold W. Greenwood Jr.; Charlotte E. Masica, former executive vice president and managing officer; Donald J. Snede, former senior vice president and chief financial officer; and Robert A. Mampel, former executive assistant to the chairman. Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency created to bail out the nation's failing thrifts, put Midwest up for sale in April. The S&L has 30 branches in Minnesota, nine in Iowa, eight in Oklahoma and two in California. Greenwood, Mampel, Masica and Greenwood's daughter, former Midwest Federal Vice President Susan Greenwood Olson, were ousted when the savings and loan was declared insolvent and seized by regulators. Greenwood Olson was indicted in March on 10 fraud counts involving $15 million in loans to the Jockey Club marina and resort in Miami. Prosecutors allege the loans far exceeded the value of the resort and that false documents were drafted to hide Mdwest Federal's shaky financial condition. Much of Tuesday's indictment centered on Midwest Federal's ties with Green Tree Acceptance Inc., a St. Paul-based company that finances mobile homes. In early 1987, Greenwood, Masica and Snede hid from regulators a $47 million shortfall in finance income expected from a $1.5 billion portfolio of mobile home loans, the indictment alleges. Midwest had purchased the loan service rights to the portfolio from Green Tree for $188 million. The executives also inflated the thrift's net worth and made unsound loans to delinquent borrowers to avoid writeoffs ``so as to preserve'' their bonuses, the indictment said. The indictment also charges the four with misapplying funds to pay for personal airline flights and club memberships, and to pay ``excessive levels of compensation to themselves'' and lend themselves money without proper approval. Regulators say deposits at Midwest Federal have dropped 10 percent since the takeover. As of May 31, the thrift's retail deposits were about $1.9 billion. Gov. Rudy Perpich has tried to distance himself from Greenwood, who was one of Perpich's biggest campaign contributors before the S&L collapsed. The Democratic governor was granted use of Midwest's corporate jet and Perpich had appointed Greenwood to the Metropolitan Airports Commission and the Greater Minnesota Corp. board. Perpich said Monday he had no business dealings with Midwest and that the state does not regulate savings and loans. William Mauzy, attorney for Greenwood, said the indictment was ``a Republican prosecutor's attempt to blame a high profile Democrat.'' He said Greenwood's actions were ``never fraudulent.''
